story:
Short Summary

        REVELATION will premiere at the Solo Creation Festival at Son of Semele Theater this July. It is a movement based piece connecting three generations of women in my family walking the knife’s edge of insanity and inspiration. As an actor, original work gives me the fuel to continue my artistic career by asking questions that matter. How can we glorify and shun insanity at the same time? Are we so far from our own natural concept of balance that we must be told what that means? Can mental health  can be explored in a subconscious, creative, and personal way? How can a family mythology be mined for truth? My goal is to develop this into a full length piece that can be performed in numerous locations and by contributing to this campaign you will be part of the genesis of a larger project. Strongly establishing REVELATION in its premiere will help my applications for grants and fellowships, expanding this piece and reaching a larger audience. With the proper budget, I will be able to achieve the aesthetic and overall feel of the piece and set a high standard for the entire life of this project. Right now the piece’s only budget is out of my pocket so any contribution will help!


What We Need & What You Get


        This project has a lot of small elements that add up to $1,500 but the largest part will go to the set, which involves a few key pieces. Se Oh, a talented young designer working in LA is working with me to make this the best set possible. Innovative lighting will add to the traditional lights of theater using actual pieces on stage. The sound designed by Fionnegan Murphy will add to the environment of the play. The talented video designer Keith Skretch will oversee the projections envisioned by the director, Gabe Figueroa, and myself. With the proper budget we can find the best costumes to heighten the story. E.B. Brooks has generously offered to serve as a liaison for wardrobe which well help further define the characters. If I exceed my goal, I could even pay these amazing artists who are working with me! (we do this for the love of theater but it is always good to get a little more compensation!). Some marketing materials are provided by Son of Semele but with added funding I can reach even more people to fill the audience for the run and future performances. To ensure that future, this campaign also covers the cost of applications fees for fellowships and grants to develop a full length piece next year. The festival allows us to rent the space and with your assistance we can spend more time rehearsing there to make this show the best it can be!

          In return for your donation you will be an active participant in supporting every aspect of this story. You can contribute to the soundscape of the piece with your own voice, have a VIP reserved seat, even original artwork, and a boatload of other perks depending on what you are able to contribute. Whenever possible your name will be included in future programs. Any support for this piece is helping share a personal story that is too often oversimplified, wrapped up into neat and tidy packages that are easy to throw away and forget about. Help me unpack this, dust it off, and show that we all have a hidden side to ourselves that scares and inspires us!


The Impact

        This piece is based on a performance I created as part of my MFA training at USC. I was fortunate enough to work with award-winning playwright and solo artist Luis Alfaro to establish the eight minute seed that has grown into REVELATION. After my short performance in 2011, multiple people came up to me and shared their experience of mental health struggles either personally or with family and loved ones. I was struck by how many people related to something that was a seemingly unique experience for me.  At the very least, I hope that people take away some compassion for what mental illness is and in doing so perhaps shed some of its stigma.

The Artist

        My original work is always deeply personal and in solo performance I can demand the most of myself. My first original work was a site specific performance with video installation entitled ELEUSIS, which won the Tryon Prize for New Media and was funded by the theater department at Smith College. While studying in Spain, I co-directed, translated, and starred in the Iberian premiere of 4.48 Psychosis by Sarah Kane. In New York, I directed a performance piece at Galapagos Art Space and adapted a reading of Philip K. Dick’s UBIK performed at The Bushwick Starr for the SITE festival. I have extensive training in creating original work as an ensemble and that enriches my work as a solo artist. This will be my first public performance of a self-generated work in Los Angeles and I expect it to meet and exceed my previous standards. Since getting my MFA in acting at USC I have found new freedom in my work and I am thrilled to see where this next chapter of work goes!


Risks & Challenges


        There are usually unforeseen challenges in theater, always working on a tight budget with a short amount of time. Luckily, we have the eternal mantra, “The show must go on!” and the show will go on, come opening night, July 18th, I will be on stage performing this piece.  Having worked in theater on a shoestring for over a decade I know how to creatively solve problems. Finding the specific look of this piece with the limited budget we have set will be difficult but where there is a will there is a way and with this piece I certainly have a will! Even if we don’t meet our goal, Indiegogo will release the funds and I feel confident that with the team of people working on this piece we will find a way to make it the best possible premiere!


Other Ways You Can Help

        Times are tough but any amount helps. Even the price of a coffee or latte. If that isn't possible for you currently, please help us by using Indiegogo’s share tools to spread the word. If you live in LA please come see the show in July! You can find info on my Facebook page or Son of Semele here:http://www.sonofsemele.org/shows/scf2016.html

Thank you so much for being a part of REVELATION, hope to see you in the audience or cheering from afar through this campaign!

story:
Short Summary

Hi Friends,

We are part of the biggest and best division in Tom James Company. Our quarterly meetings are world class and the entertainment is very important in making a large division like ours extremely close. We are launching this 45 day campaign to purchase our own lighting and audio equipment. Up to this point, we have rented audio equipment that sometimes works and sometimes doesn't, we use Home Depot work lights with colored plastic over them for lighting. This isn't world class. This isn't like us. I have found some top notch equipment at a great price. Will you help our division be the best it can be?

What We Need & What You Get

We only need $1600. With 330 salespeople in the division, that's less than $5 a person. 

  • With this money, we will be able to get speakers, microphones, cables, sound mixers, lighting trestles, lights, dimmer boards, and more cables! This makes a better looking, better sounding show for you!  

The Impact

Even though we make up 60% of the entire sales force, I'm pretty sure we're not finished growing. I have to believe Steve will continue to build this division and we want our newer, younger partners to have an experience that truly says "World Class". Your coffee money for today can help with that.

story:
DONATIONS and PERKS:

Your donation goes directly to indiegogo.com, which will make a single payment to Stand Tall, and it is not tax-deductible as a charitable donation.  We thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

 

All promotional items are provided directly by the Stand Tall writing team as a gift to supporters.  

Our Story

It’s David vs. Goliath – but not a slingshot in sight! When shepherd boy David is prophesized to become the next king… heck, he’d rather be a rock star, anyway. Not that tough guy Goliath’ll let some freakin’ sheep-lover take the crown, setting the stage for the biblical rivals to clash in an epic Guitar Hero battle! Following a successful run in the UK, this family-friendly rock musical takes on the issue of bullying as it spins its tale of a little guy who must overcome obstacles, face fears and finally: Stand Tall!

In 2009 the Stand Tall writing team had an idea to write a musical for everyone with a topic that everyone on the planet can relate too…bullying. Almost everyone you know has experienced bullying in some way either as a victim or as a bully. Stand Tall the musical was inspired by all of these people and was written for people of all ages with a hope it would inspire everyone to stand up and break the cycle.

In 2010 Stand Tall was performed under the name David V Goliath by a group of exceptionally talented young drama students in Oxfordshire UK. These young talented performers were inspirational in their delivery of the subject matter and received justified critical acclaim for their performance. The show also won the Princess Diana Award for Anti-Bullying due to its efforts in tackling an issue in such an engaging way.

In 2011 Stand Tall received its first professional production in London UK. A hugely successful 5 week run was again critically well received and the writing team had very little time to sit back and take stock at how their show idea in 2009 was being performed in London in less than two years.

Now in 2012, Stand Tall has been invited to the New York Musical Theatre Festival, this incredible story continues…

The Impact

Using Musical Theater as a medium, and with the help of the New York Musical Theatre Festival the Stand Tall team plans to spread this message to a worldwide audience. We won't stop until as many people as possible know about Stand Tall and its important universal message. The David against Goliath story has never been so relevant to so many people.  Not only do we tell a familiar tale with a twist of lemon, it includes an eclectic and uplifting score. 

What We Need & What You Get

Stand Tall is at a crucial time in its development.  It has been offered a world renowned festival theater stage on which to fully mount this work for the first time in the US. It will be given the sets, lights, and costumes that a show of this magnitude requires.  For the first time, hundreds of people will be able to sit, every night, and watch this groundbreaking musical. But we need your help!

The New York Musical Theatre Festival has invited the writing team mount the US Premiere of Stand Tall.  Your contribution will play a key role in the financing of such a large undertaking. With your donation, large or small, you will pledge that you believe, like us, that this inspirational story has to be seen by as many people as possible.  By supporting us, you will become a member of the ever-growing Stand Tall family, and you will stand beside us as we spread our message.

In recognition of your support, certain "perks" will be made available.  Everything from recognition on our highly trafficked website to VIP tickets to the opening night of Stand Tall are available as a thank you for your contribution.  Please, pledge today.  We deeply appreciate your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about us!  Talk about the show and its message with your families and friends.  Please visit our website (http://www.standtallmusical.com) to learn more about the show and watch the trailer, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We can't spread our message with out your help.  Pledge to Stand Tall today!

story:
LA RINASCITA (ree-NAH-shee-tah; it means rebirth.) is a performance group that aims to develop new, actor/director-generated theater pieces that combine strong narrative with an avant-garde sensibility. La Rinascita seeks to define for themselves what it means to be an American artist.

LA RINASCITA has embarked on a major project--spending 3 months in the mountains at the Montana Artists Refuge creating new pieces.  With us are co-founders David Conison and Anne Veal, as well as Jon Riddleberger (actor, puppeteer) and Kyle Encinas (fight choreographer, actor, technician).  Actor Matthew Baldiga will be joining us for November/December.  This is an incredibly exciting experience and we have some big plans for 3 months of uninterrupted time for creation:

--A site-specific installation piece inspired by Dante's INFERNO; this piece will use the history of the area (the Marias Massacre of Blackfeet Indians, the mining culture, early American vigilanteism) to explore American ghosts and guilt: An American Inferno.

--Working with high schoolers at local Jefferson High School to create their own work based on Shakespeare; we will be encouraging imagination and improvisation as well as writing.  With this project we also hope to expand their definition of what "theatre" is.

--An entirely new piece roughly described as an Elizabethan alt-history neo-noir.  We will be incorporating elements of Shakespeare, Mongolian history, the detective story, and serialized story-telling into a new universe of our creation in MARCHPAINE.

Our problem is, of course, funding.  We can conceptualize as much as we want, but without capital turning these ideas into breathing pieces of theatre is impossible.  And, of course, once we have completed our Montana sojourn we will look to produce them in big, expensive cities.

That's where YOU come in!  Help us to make all these lofty goals a reality!  Get amazing perks!  Your money will help pay for:
--transportation and lodging for artists
--prop, costume, and set materials
--performance space rental and insurance
--administrative costs (fractured atlas fees, application fees, etc.)

story:
Our Story:

Hello! We are Shawna Cormier, Kristi Funk Dana, marcus d. harvey, Amanda Holston, Layla Khoshnoudi, Jeremiah Maestas and Skyler Sullivan. We are the Master of Fine Arts Acting class of 2012 at Brooklyn College. 

On March 12-14, 2012, we will host our MFA Acting Showcase. As actors, a crucial part of our career starts with the people we know and the connections we make. In order to do this, we invite members of the New York City Industry to our showcase, allowing us to expand our professional network, which in turn, gets us hired and cast. We are raising money to make this showcase the best it can be. Our showcase is instrumental in the pathway towards a flourishing future. In the past, this showcase lead to actors getting cast and signing with agents, thus joining the highly competitive and passionate ranks of working and successful actors. 

During this campaign, we need to raise $2,500. This money will go towards the rental of a theatre space within the Abingdon Theatre Complex, conveniently located in the heart of Midtown Manhattan. The showcase will take place over three days, with two performances on each of these days. Other costs include the snacks, water and much needed wine for the invitees at every performance. (These people are extremely busy and deserve a little respite!) 

The good news?! You are welcome to come and see the showcase! You would have been directly involved in the creation of a successful showcase. After all the preparation we will have done, it will be one heck of a show! 

Because of your help, we will create an event that will change our lives. Thank you, we are immeasurably appreciative of your support. Please tell your friends and family about our cause!

story:
PDragonfire!

Jennifer Himes is a puppeteer based in Orlando, Florida. This is her first public theatre production.

“Dragonfire stems directly from my desire to express myself and my faith in a unique way. I knew had something important to say, but I didn’t know what it was or how to say it. The idea of that desire burning inside gave me the idea for the character Kenna (which is an old Celtic name meaning born of flames), from her came the dragons, from them came the story.” Dragonfire asks, “how do stories help the suffering?” And answers by showing a little girl finding her very own dragonfire inside, using it to call on the Third Dragon herself and send a demon dog running. 

The project has received a small grant from the Experimental Puppetry Theatre Program for all other expenses, so it is a guaranteed to be on stage. When you support Dragonfire, however big or small, you will be helping Jennifer and her team bring the story to life by giving toward practical needs like food, housing and travel while in Atlanta for the performances.

What We Need & What You Get

You might be asking, “If you’ve already received a grant, why do you need more money?” The grant will cover the cost of materials, but there are other needs. Here is where your donation will be put to use.

  • The Dragonfire team is mostly based in Orlando, Florida. Our first priority is money for travel, food and housing while on the road. 
  • Payment for the Orlando-based performers giving their time to develop, rehearse and perform the show.
  • This show is happening. If this campaign is not fully funded, the show will be done. This campaign is to make the financial impact on the team to be as soft as possible. 

Those who donate will receive the perks listed on the right. Click on a level of donation to see what you will receive in return for your generosity.

Other Ways You Can Help

“But I cannot give money right now, is there something else I can do to help?”

  • Share this campaign! Seriously, send it all over creation! Thank you!

Share this campaign! Seriously, send it all over creation! Thank you!

story:
Our Story

We are packing our bags and traveling to Scotland this summer to the world's largest theater and arts festival in the world, but we could use a little help getting there.  The Spielpalast cabaret has been producing its own independent theatre successfully in the US for 10 years and we are thrilled to announce that we have been invited to present our show at The Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August. The competition is tough, so we are very grateful for the opportunity.  Myself and my son Amir have been fortunate to work with this amazing group of actors, singers, and dancers and are looking forward to performing with them at the Fringe!


http://www.edfringe.com/about-us


The Impact

You will directly be helping a group of committed and excited artists live out an amazing dream. The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is generally regarded as an absolute must for those passionate about cutting-edge theater and performance. For us, sharing our work at the festival is a vital part of our development as performers, as creators, and as individuals.  Thanks in advance for any help you can give to support our adventure!


What We Need & What You Get

Each cast member has been asked to take on their own individual fundraising campaign to help cover the cost. There are approximately 20 members traveling with the show and will an estimated upwards of $2000 cost per person, in addition to booking and other associated fees, so as you can see it can quickly get very expensive.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help with a financial contribution, or even if you can, please consider passing along this information to anyone you think might be interested in helping us to further our campaign.

story:
Liquid Sky and Sky Gym present Dante's Inferno, an aerial theater production based on the epic poem by Dante Alighieri, in the style of nouveau cirque. 


The performance will be held Easter Weekend, April 2-5, at 7 Stages in Atlanta, GA. 


This dark tale probes the depths of human sin, revealing that hell is not only for condemned souls, but also for the living. It explores how we as mortals can create our own hell through the loss of faith. The torments of hell are thus ravaged upon our own minds, making us beg for guidance. Ultimately, however, it is a message of hope: a plea to overcome our demons through reason, faith, and love.


What We Need & What You Get

All the funds received will go directly to the production of the show, including set design, venue, costumes, etc. This will help to alleviate the financial burden on the production team and cast members, allowing for greater flexibility and quality of production.

You truly will become a partner in helping us bring a new look on circus arts to Atlanta. Become a part of our production by seeing behind the scenes footage, getting backstage access, and attending one of several meet and greets with the entire production team and cast. We invite you to take your love for the circus arts with several perks ranging from private aerial lessons to private aerial performances.

The Impact

With your help, we will be able to shine a light on the amazing talent Atlanta has to offer for the circus world. Liquid Sky and Sky Gym are creating opportunities for local artists to show their talents in an accessible manner for all of Atlanta. This approach empowers both the audience and smaller productions for a greater variety and affordability. Thus we can avoid the corporate white-washing of artistic performance, and instead let the performers speak from the heart.

Other Ways You Can Help

Above all else, helping us spread the word on this unique collaboration, whether it be Facebook, Twitter, email, or just old fashion word of mouth. For that, we could not be more appreciative. We could not do this without your support!

story:
WHO ARE WE AND WHAT ARE WE DOING HERE?

So you've probably heard of The Room, you may have even seen it. 

It is routinely cited as the best worst film of all time. It is a brilliant, beautiful disaster (and highly recommended by us). For the first time ever (at least as far as we can tell), this cult phenomenon has been turned into an all-singing, some-dancing musical. 

Adapted by BBC-award nominated writer, Ed Greenwood, The Room: The Musical retells the classic love story between man and woman, best friend and unofficially adopted son. 

The candles, the music, the sexy dress - this new musical embraces memorable moments of the original and attempts to find new meaning in places where perhaps there is none. Whether you're new toThe Room or a die-hard spoon-wielding maniac, this show is guaranteed to make you laugh until your spurt Scotchka all over your badly-fitting tuxedo.


SO WHAT ARE WE DOING WITH IT?

This summer,we are taking The Room: The Musical on a tour of the UK including dates at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, Buxton Fringe and Great Yorkshire Fringe.

Everything else is in place. We have a script, score, fully rehearsed cast and band and even tour dates! We want as many people to be able to come and have fun with us but due to registrations, venue rentals, marketing, insurance and all the other boring stuff - we need a little bit of financial assistance. That's where you come in.

Our company is completely non-for-profit and our entire team is paying for their own housing and travel and, after five months of performing, none of us will be taking a single penny from the project. So any possible donation you could give would be enormously appreciated. 


AND WHAT WILL YOUR DONATION PAY FOR?

Two Spoons Productions' ethos revolves around bringing entertainment to people for as little as possible and we've reduced our budget as much as possible but there are still some necessities we need a little help covering. Anything you can give will help:

£1 will pay for 8 party hats for the iconic birthday party scene.

£3 will pay for 500 rose petals

£5 will pay for a Tommy Wiseau wig for our lead actor

£8 will pay for a lion onesie (just wait and see...)

£10 will pay for an American football

£12 will pay for a sexy red dress

£20 will pay for a sofa for the set

£40 will pay for our venue deposit for the Great Yorkshire Fringe

£50 will pay for our projector - a vital piece of tech

£60 will pay for all our props

£70 will pay for our registration to Buxton Fringe

£80 will pay for our Edinburgh Fringe Venue for a month

£110 will pay for our venue deposit at Buxton Fringe

£130 will pay for all our set

£180 will pay for all our costume

£250 will pay for our printed marketing and merchandise for the full tour

£295 pays for our registration to the Edinburgh Fringe

£5,000 will pay for our court fees to Tommy Wiseau (just kidding, we're protected by Parody Law!)


IS THERE ANYTHING ELSE YOU CAN DO?

Of course!

You can follow us on Facebook and Twitter, check out the show website or the company website. 

Or you can even come and see us perform at any of these dates:

Basement, York, 16th April

Underground Venues, Buxton Fringe, 20th-22nd July

Great Yorkshire Fringe, York, 31st July

City Cafe, Laughing Horse Free Fringe, Edinburgh, 7th-31st  August (link pending)

(And don't forget to come and say hi to us afterwards, we'd love to meet you!)


SO WHAT HAPPENS FROM HERE?

We're hoping to tour The Room: The Musical further across the UK. This year will help us develop the reputation of our company to allow us to do that.

Two Spoons Productions are dedicated to providing a platform for new comedy writing and we hope to be able to go forward into the future expanding the company and supporting student and graduate talent.

If you'd like to get involved, please don't hesitate in contacting us.



To explain how grateful we are, we will use the words of Tommy Wiseau: 'We love you, darling!'

Ed, Stephanie, Shaun & Charles (and the team).

Two Spoons Productions

story:
Hello Friends, and people I wish were my friends.

I'm Laura Levites and I am comedian.  I have been invited to perform at the Gilded Ballon for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, which is the largest arts festival in the world. (by the way, and if you don't believe me google it.)  It's an honor to be performing at the Gilded Balloon, because it's responsible for launching the careers of many great comics and performers.  I'd like to be one of those people.

I'm producing my own show, "Selfhelpless" and boy it's expensive.  So this is me asking for your help.  I need some money, well lots of it.  So if you have any that you can spare, I will gladly take it off your hands and make good use of it.

I need plane fare, train tickets, lodging, promotion materials, flyers posters etc...

I know it sounds like a lot of money, but keep in mind that it's in the UK, Scotland and well the U.S. dollar is worthless there, so take the dollar amount and cut that in half.  Yep, cut in it half which means a burger that costs 10 pounds is actually 20 dollars.  I think they are getting back at us for declaring Independance from them.

Why should you help me?  Because my shrink says that I'm worthy of being helped, but I'm not sure I believe him yet.  Asking for help is a very difficult thing to do.  My show is called "Selfhelpless" and it's about my journey of self help and questioning whether or not it can be achieved.  Everyone needs help once in a while.  So I'm asking for it, please help me. 

This is what the Press say about me.  I'm just glad it's Press and not my mother, because she would say something much different.

“Laura Levites is a truly distinct new voice on the UK comedy scene.  Definitely one to keep tabs on.”-The Scotsman

“A very funny girl” -The Skinny

“I have a feeling that this lady could be a major player in the near future.” -One4Review

“Levites is both loveable and crazy and her delivery and character is just as entertaining as her storytelling.”  -Broadway Baby

“It’s Levites disarming honesty and vivacious personality that inexorably captivates you, making you care for her and her story.”  -The Examiner

“You’ll laugh loudly as you enjoy the scatty narrative of this womans hilarious journey of self discovery.” -StageWon

I made it bigger because I need to remind myself that people say nice things about me.

Check out my show here. 

https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/comedy/laura-...

 I'm on facebook here.  (Please click the like button)

https://www.facebook.com/OfficialLauraLevites

I'm on twitter here.

https://twitter.com/LauraLevites

My website is here.

www.LauraLevites.com 

Thank you. xoxoxox Laura

story:
We're a hit in New York...

Mara's in Berkeley wrenching on cars, when true love knocks her on her butt, not once, but twice. Plug in the guys at work who bust her chops, and her dad's death hanging over her, and you've got one juicy story. This love triangle was a huge hit in New York, they're asking for more, but first we're going to test out the changes for a month in Chicago. Then film it in Berkeley. Then bring it back to NY. Help us continue this wonderful story and terrific journey.

I'm Miranda Jonte, an East Bay girl who went to grad school in New York and never left. I write, act, run, eat chocolate, and have found what it is I most want to do in the world: produce good theater.

  • We're a team of Bay Area, Michigan, Missouri, and more, folks who live for good  storytelling, and constantly work professionally all over the country. (they're talented, amazing people!)
  • Our campaign is meant to take our team of directors, actors, & designers across the country to tell Mara's story again and again. 
  • Your help will allow us to kick off the second leg of Greasemonkey. This project has garnered such a loyal- and growing- following, we want to keep it going. 

We're doing it again due to demand!


What We Need & What You Get

Putting up a show takes a lot of time and, yes, money. Now, add in transporting it to a different time zone! 

  • We'll need not only a publicist, but advertising to get this 2nd City audience to see our show. We're going newspapers, magazines, radio, the works.
  • Rental- 2 weeks of NY rehearsal, and a MONTH of performances at the Greenhouse. Yay!
  • Flying our crew to Chicago, driving our costumes, props & set pieces there.
  • Paying EVERYONE involved. They deserve it. 
  • YOU get: Thank you cards, Greasemonkey shirts, poetry books that inspired the play, posters, tickets to the show, a fun basket full of Northern California goodness, and a producer credit.
The Significance

Our contributors for the first leg of the show are still on board- they provided, we delivered!

  • Putting a smart female character on stage is GREAT for women AND men to see. Especially one who is working in what is, traditionally, a guy's field..
  • Our fundraising cabarets last year were sold out, and with every performance of Greasemonkey, the audience got bigger and bigger. People are still asking for more shows, six months later. The enthusiasm just keeps growing!

Stephen Brotebeck (Director) went to Penn State, & worked on 'Peter & the Starcatcher' on Broadway. Campaign $$ will help fund his donut obsession.


Kerry Flanagan (Leann) helped found the Cry Havoc company & sings like a rock star.


Leajato Robinson (Steve) has toured the show 'Tap Dogs,' & was seen on Boardwalk Empire. Psalm 18: 1-3


Josh Bywater (Daniel) worked with the Steppenwolf Theater this Summer, & lives in Chicago. Likes monkeys.


Miranda Jonte (Mara) is from Northern CA. She is writing her next play & drinks too much coffee. Prefers dogs to cats.


Elliott Mayer (Don) was seen on Boardwalk Empire, is an unconfirmed bachelor who would call his band 'The Iceman Cometh.' He is not in a band. 


All music by singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Theresa Andersson.


Other Ways You Can Help

Folks, we know sometimes donating money just isn't an option. We get it. We would love to enroll you in telling THE WORLD, or at least, your friends, family, coworkers, about us and our mission. Word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter, anything- any and all support is warmly welcomed. 

And that’s all there is to it. Thank you for your enthusiasm and cheerleading!

Check us out: http://greasemonkey.weebly.com/

Follow us! https://twitter.com/MaraSoFar

story:
The Generic Ensemble Company in Partnership with The VORTEX Presents: WHAT'S GOIN' ON?!

World Premiere

Fri-Sun, May 16-18; Thu-Sun, May 22-25; Thu-Sat 29-31; 2014. 8pm all days at The VORTEX. Get ready to move around!

Directed by kt shorb

Devised by the ensemble, featuring: Morgan Robyn Collado, Kannou, Olivia Jimenez, James McMaster, Smalls McCoy, Saray de Jesus Rosales, and Wendy Vastine. 

Stage management by Shelina Widner and Tamara L. Farley.

WHAT'S GOIN' ON? remixes epic journeys, cable TV, and Brecht's The Good Person of Szechwan in a roving, site-specific, pro-consent interactive, evening-length experience. The mostly-queer, mostly-people-of-color ensemble transforms the VORTEX compound into ships, boxing rings, a "workroom," and more. We think about money, virtue, opposites, gender expression and desire. If you often find yourself wondering how you can be a good person when living is just so effing expensive, you'll like our show. 

The Generic Ensemble Company engages the community in the creation and execution of this work. There will be singing, there will be dancing, there will be awkward pauses. We may ask you to work, but you'll be glad you did!

Let's Talk About Radical Rush

We are so proud to be partnering with The VORTEX on their Radical Rush program that reserves a bloc of free tickets every performance night in the spirit of sustainability, accessibility, and participating in the gift economy. Radical Rush tickets are released an hour before the performance starts--first come first serve. Your donation to this campaign allows us to offer our show to all patrons, regardless of their socio-economic status. 

How Can We Be Good When Everything's So Expensive?

We love making art, but ART IS WORK! Just under a month before the show and each member of the ensemble has already put in close to 200 hours of blood, sweat, and tears into this project. Some of us have been working on this for over 18 months! Donations from this campaign will go directly toward paying creative collaborators, that include seven actors, a director, two stage managers, and three designers. Even with modest stipends, we need well over $6,000 just to pay our creative staff. We have already received a grant from the City of Austin, which will cover the other half of our stipend budget, plus material costs. We are grateful to The VORTEX for underwriting our project through providing performance space and other material goods so we can direct most of our resources toward paying talent. It is the goal of the Generic Ensemble Company to make creative labor sustainable for all collaborators. Love makes art good, but you can't eat it. Money helps.

Why We Are So Cool

The Generic Ensemble Company (GenEnCo) is one of the few troupes in Austin, and nationally, that centers queer-identified people of color bodies and experiences in physically engaged, experimental, ensemble-based performance. GenEnCo has some grants and awards under its belt, and director, kt shorb, has presented work nationally. This is the most recent project aimed at asking profound questions toward social change through rigorous, dangerous, and community-conscious theatre. Ask yourself, when was the last time you saw a bunch of brown gender queers doing experimental, site-specific, physical work? (If the answer was yesterday, please tell us where you live). 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help out with donating to our cause, we are looking for volunteers to run the house, be backstage, and distribute media material. Do you have a blog, radio show, or column? Talk to us and share our project with your audience!

Ticket Info

You can reserve a seat by going to The VORTEX ticketing page.
story_txt:
The Generic Ensemble Company in Partnership with The VORTEX Presents: WHAT'S GOIN' ON?!World PremiereFri-Sun, May 16-18; Thu-Sun, May 22-25; Thu-Sat 29-31; 2014. 8pm all days at The VORTEX. Get ready to move around!Directed by kt shorbDevised by the ensemble, featuring: Morgan Robyn Collado, Kannou, Olivia Jimenez, James McMaster, Smalls McCoy, Saray de Jesus Rosales, and Wendy Vastine. Stage management by Shelina Widner and Tamara L. Farley.WHAT'S GOIN' ON? remixes epic journeys, cable TV, and Brecht's The Good Person of Szechwan in a roving, site-specific, pro-consent interactive, evening-length experience. The mostly-queer, mostly-people-of-color ensemble transforms the VORTEX compound into ships, boxing rings, a "workroom," and more. We think about money, virtue, opposites, gender expression and desire. If you often find yourself wondering how you can be a good person when living is just so effing expensive, you'll like our show. The Generic Ensemble Company engages the community in the creation and execution of this work. There will be singing, there will be dancing, there will be awkward pauses. We may ask you to work, but you'll be glad you did!Let's Talk About Radical Rush
We are so proud to be partnering with The VORTEX on their Radical Rush program that reserves a bloc of free tickets every performance night in the spirit of sustainability, accessibility, and participating in the gift economy. Radical Rush tickets are released an hour before the performance starts--first come first serve. Your donation to this campaign allows us to offer our show to all patrons, regardless of their socio-economic status. How Can We Be Good When Everything's So Expensive?We love making art, but ART IS WORK! Just under a month before the show and each member of the ensemble has already put in close to 200 hours of blood, sweat, and tears into this project. Some of us have been working on this for over 18 months! Donations from this campaign will go directly toward paying creative collaborators, that include seven actors, a director, two stage managers, and three designers. Even with modest stipends, we need well over $6,000 just to pay our creative staff. We have already received a grant from the City of Austin, which will cover the other half of our stipend budget, plus material costs. We are grateful to The VORTEX for underwriting our project through providing performance space and other material goods so we can direct most of our resources toward paying talent. It is the goal of the Generic Ensemble Company to make creative labor sustainable for all collaborators. Love makes art good, but you can't eat it. Money helps.Why We Are So CoolThe Generic Ensemble Company (GenEnCo) is one of the few troupes in Austin, and nationally, that centers queer-identified people of color bodies and experiences in physically engaged, experimental, ensemble-based performance. GenEnCo has some grants and awards under its belt, and director, kt shorb, has presented work nationally. This is the most recent project aimed at asking profound questions toward social change through rigorous, dangerous, and community-conscious theatre. Ask yourself, when was the last time you saw a bunch of brown gender queers doing experimental, site-specific, physical work? (If the answer was yesterday, please tell us where you live). Other Ways You Can HelpIf you cannot help out with donating to our cause, we are looking for volunteers to run the house, be backstage, and distribute media material. Do you have a blog, radio show, or column? Talk to us and share our project with your audience!Ticket InfoYou can reserve a seat by going to The VORTEX ticketing page.

story:
My name is Amanda Baker I am the president of the Save the Star-vu committee in El Dorado, Kansas.  Our Committee was set up to help raise funds to keep our beloved Star-vu Drive-in up and running and to be able to convert our Drive-in to Digital. 

 The Star-vu Drive-in was opened in 1949 and is the 2nd oldest drive-in in the state of Kansas. 

   We were a part of the Project Drive-in contest that Honda sponsored. We did not win so there fore we need Help to be able to buy a new digital projector.  The cost for the projector runs close to 80,000.  This is a crazy amount of money to pull out of pocket.  We need your help to be able to stay open and to keep our beloved icon from closing. 

    If we don't reach our goal we will close and the property will be torn down.  WE REALLY DON'T WANT THAT!!! Our community really wants us to stay open and be able to provide quality entertainment.

    If we don't meet our goal all proceeds that have been collected will be divided up and given to local charities. No one person will benefit from the proceeds.

   If you can't contribute please feel free to share this with friends and try and make some noise about what we are trying to do.

Thanks so much!

story:
The Eclectic Company Theatre is proud to support:

V-Day (Valley Village) 2014

Presents A Benefit Reading of

A MEMORY, A MONOLOGUE, A RANT AND A PRAYER:

Writings To Stop Violence Against Women and Girls

Join Us as we RISE, RELEASE, and DANCE to Demand Justice for Women and Girl Survivors of Violence

About V-Day: V-Day is a global activist movement to end violence against women and girls that raises funds and awareness through benefit productions of Playwright/Founder Eve Ensler’s award winning play The Vagina Monologues and other artistic works. The V-Day movement has raised over $100 million; educated millions about the issue of violence against women and the efforts to end it; crafted international educational, media and PSA campaigns; reopened shelters; and funded over 13,000 community-based anti-violence programs and safe houses in Democratic Republic of Congo, Haiti, Kenya, South Dakota, Egypt, and Iraq. V-Day has received numerous acknowledgements and awards and is, one of the Top-Rated organizations on both Charity Navigator and Guidestar.  V-Day’s most recent global campaign, ONE BILLION RISING, galvanized over one billion women and men on a global day of action towards ending violence against women and girls. vday.org


 A Memory, a Monologue, a Rant, and a Prayer will be performed on February 14, 2014, show starts at 8 pm.

On February 16, 2014 at 7 pm the Eclectic will perform readings of original monologues, stories, poems, spoken word, music, and art.

   Tickets are $15 general/ $12 students/seniors.

The funds raised here will go toward production costs such as poster, postcards, printing costs, and possible rights for a third night of benefit shows. All leftover proceeds will go to support Haven Hills, a women's support organization.

We know not everyone can give, but everyone can help! Please spread the word about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools. Visit us on Facebook at V-Day Valley (MMRP) 2014. Come see the shows! Bring a friend! Rise Up!

story:
About Sit & Spin Productions 

Sit & Spin Productions is one of Northwestern University student theatre boards. Dedicated to expanding the definition of theatre at Northwestern University by giving artists opportunities to explore unconventional, risk-taking works, Sit & Spin Productions is made up entirely of undergraduate students who are passionate about creating refreshing and challenging pieces of theatre. 


Plot Summary

Happy Birthday, Wanda June. This is a simple minded play about men who enjoy killing - and those who don't. Harold Ryan disappeared eight years ago and even Mutual of Omaha thinks he's dead, but his specter hangs over his wife and son. This black comedy from the American prophet, Kurt Vonnegut, explores issues ranging from violence to gender roles to orange juice. It is his only work written for the stage and it challenges us to imagine a world in which the heroes are the peace lovers and the healers. 


The Help We Need

Because the Executive Board, Production Team, Cast, and Crew are made up entirely of Northwestern undergraduate students, our resources are limited. Any amount you are willing to contribute would truly make an impact on our ability to afford to produce a spectacular show.

Your donation will help tremendously in a variety of ways:

  • Purchasing lumber, paint, and scenery to construct our set.
  • Renting sound and lighting equipment for the productions.
  • Obtaining fabric and accessories to be used as costumes.
  • Collecting props from thrift shops and rental stores.
  • Paying for the rights to perform the show.
  • Assisting our publicity campaigns as well as marketing in and around the Northwestern and Chicago area.
  • The possibilities are endless!


The Team

CAST:

  • Penelope Ryan: Natalie C. Houchins
  • Paul Ryan: Russell Kahn
  • Harold Ryan: Scott Wolf
  • Colonel Looseleaf Harper: Jake Drummond
  • Herb Shuttle: Drew Guerra
  • Dr. Norbert Woodly: Ford Altenbern
  • Wanda June: Bridget McNamara
  • Major Siegfried von Konigswald: Dylan Pager
  • Mildred: Alexandria Frisch

PRODUCTION TEAM:
  • Producer: Claire Huntington
    • Assistant Producer: Rob Cassie
  • Director: Dylan Pickus
    • Assistant Director: Elliott Hartman
  • Stage Manager: Amalie Vega
    • Assistant Stage Manager: Linnea Hodge

  • Set Designer: Melissa McSweeney
    • Assistant Set Designer: Josh Light
  • Lighting Designer: Melissa Hahn
    • Assistant Lighting Designer Madeleine Kenyon
  • Master Electrician: Stephanie Kahn
  • Sound Designer: Jon Schneidman
    • Sound Designer Mentor: Sammy Zeisel
    • Sound Technician: Conor Keelan
  • Costume Designer: Samantha Spoll
  • Props Designer: Bex Siegel
    • Assistant Props Designer: Michael Fagan
  • Technical Director: Pernell Myers
  • Dramaturg: Michael Rogerson
  • Dialect Coach: Sam Douglas
  • Process Fairy: Daphne Kim
  • Publicity Director: Tristan Chiruvolu
    • Publicity Team: Katie Incardona
  • Fundraising Director: Jacob Trauberman
  • Graphics Designer: Collin Rice
  • Photographer: Justin Barbin
  • International Social Chair: Ari Shapiro
  • American Social Chair: Amalie Vega
  • International Relations: Francesca Mennella


SIT & SPIN EXECUTIVE BOARD:

  • Brandon Powers, Executive Director
  • A.J. Roy, Business Manager
  • Abby Pajakowski, Production Manager
  • Scott Wolf, Directing Chair
  • Jessie Klueter, Company Manager
  • Justine Gelfman, Technical Director
  • Gianna Petrosino, Technical Director
  • Lena Krause, Outreach Coordinator
  • Becca Maier, Marketing Brand Manager
  • Ari Shapiro, Communications Director
  • Natalie Robinson, Special Events Coordinator
  • Sam Douglas, Development Director
  • Natalie C. Houchins, Archivist
  • Francesca Mennella, International Relations Chair




    • THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR GENEROUS SUPPORT!

    Sincerely,
    Jacob Trauberman
    Fundraising Director

story:
Our Story

5 SIRENS: BEWARE OF ROCKS is a collection of short plays united by universal themes. World premiering at the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival, this collaboration was created especially for the Fringe by USC Master of Professional Writing grads and playwrights Sarah Dzida, Autumn McAlpin, Kiera Nowacki, Caron Tate, and Laurel Wetzork, and will be directed by Laura Steinroeder. Through the eclectic lenses of alien encounters, terminal nerd-dom, sibling rivalry, sub/dom relationships, and devastating family illness, 5 SIRENS delves into our deep-rooted human desires for connection and communication but recognizes the fact that sometimes, no matter how hard we try, no matter what we're willing to do, those desires may not be met.

WE NEED YOU!!! to support us as we bring our stories to life onstage. Your contribution will help cover the costs of our rehearsal and production space and costs, marketing expenses, and help us feed and pay our amazing professional actors and crew. THANK YOU for donating, liking, and sharing our campaign as we aim to captivate you with our song!

Support female playwrights and support our Sirens' song at the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival -- L.A.'s largest celebration of the Performing Arts.

THE STORIES:
DON'T PANIC by Sarah Dzida
When put-together Paige announces she might die, it’s up to her sister to calm her down.

TEN YEARS LEFT by Autumn McAlpin
A woman struggles to find her voice as she interacts with her doctor, family, and agent after being diagnosed with a debilitating disease.

OUT OF HERE by Laurel Wetzork
A bi-sexed Alien and a guy from Missouri have different ideas about inter-species communication, with dire results.

WHATEVER WORKS by Caron Tate
A man with dangerously out of control anger issues knows he needs help, but is he getting it soon enough for the woman he’s involved with?

SPOCK AT BAT by Kiera Nowacki
A man and a woman meet at a company softball championship, but find they have very little in common as they each try to translate jock and nerd speak into terms the other will understand.

THE SIRENS:

SARAH DZIDA started out in the theatre biz as a critic for KXLU's Center Stage with Mark Gordon, but the siren song of writing hooked her out of it. Since then, she's written a lot. Her fiction has appeared on The Huffington Post. Her poetry can be found online and one time in an exhibit at the Architecture + Design Museum in 2012. Her creative nonfiction has appeared in MARY: A Journal of Writing and Sushi and Sake Magazine. She's working on her second novel, and when not writing, she's probably reading.

AUTUMN McALPIN is an award-winning playwright, filmmaker, and author. A soon-to-be graduate of USC’s Master of Professional Writing program, Autumn’s play, IN FRONT OF THE CHILDREN, won first place at this year’s Writing for Stage and Screen competition at USC. She also co-wrote and produced the upcoming feature film WAFFLE STREET, starring James Lafferty, Danny Glover, and Julie Gonzalo, which she adapted for screen from James Adams’ 2010 memoir of the same name. A mother of four, Autumn also runs the non-profit Aspire Higher, which matches families to volunteerism causes.

East coast or west, LAUREL WETZORK's been involved in the stage and screen. She's studied it—a BA from USC's film school in cinema production, and a Master of Professional Writing (USC), with a concentration in stage and screen. She's worked in it—as an award-winning writer, feature-film director, member of the Dramatists Guild, as a volunteer onstage editor for LAFPI (Los Angeles Female Playwrights Initiative). She also supports writers and playwrights as a member and volunteer of the International Centre for Women Playwrights. She puts sirens in most of her work (the police and female kind).

CARON TATE produced and appeared in her first full-length play BUMPS back in her days as a performer of stage and television in the Washington DC/Baltimore area. More recently, she is a graduate of the USC Master of Professional Writing program. While at USC, her play POWER POINTS won first place for the Writing for Stage and Screen Annual Competition. Her poetry received an Honorable Mention in the Edward W. Moses poetry competition. Caron's published work includes fiction, poetry, and memoir. She is also a Gamma to two perfect grandbabeeze.

KIERA NOWACKI studied theater at Rhodes College in Memphis, TN, where she wrote and directed an adaptation of Ernest Hemingway's short story, Hills Like White Elephants. She also studied masked theater in Arezzo, Italy at the Academica dell'Arte, an experience which informs her comedic sensibility. She is a recent graduate of USC's Master of Professional Writing program, where her short play, A HUNDRED MAYS, received second runner up in the Writing for Stage and Screen Annual Competition in 2013.

OUR DIRECTOR:

LAURA STEINRODER is a Los Angeles-based theatre director. Laura has a passion for new play development and contemporary work as well as reimagining the classics for contemporary audiences. She also likes to work with companies that showcase female playwrights and voices that are not often heard. Her focus is on plays that deal with human connection and relationships in addition to working on non-traditional forms of theatre which include immersive theatre and using different mediums and media to tell a story.

She has curated several twitter chats for Howl Round’s weekly Howls on the topics of new play development, director/playwright relationships, and self-producing. Laura created the Facebook group, Theatre Director Resources to assist directors in finding and posting upcoming opportunities, as well as to provide an opportunity to share and discuss issues and inspiration. You can follow her on twitter at @LSteinroeder. Alum of the National Theater Institute at the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center. SDC Associate Member. www.laurasteinroeder.weebly.com


OUR CAST:

   

Robert Seeley (Ten Years Left, Whatever Works, Spock at Bat)

Tora Kim (Ten Years Left, Out of Here, Whatever Works)  www.torakim.net

Jenny Curtis (Ten Years Left, Spock at Bat)

Bart Tangredi (Ten Years Left)

Kara Ludke (Don't Panic, Ten Years Left)

Henry Kemp (Out of Here)


Julianna Robinson (Don't Panic)

What We Need & What You Get

Quality productions demand quality investment, and while we are keeping our costs to the bare minimum, here is what we can't avoid:

Rehearsal space $340

Performance space and Insurance $880

Fringe fees $250

Advertising and marketing $290

Cast and Crew Fees $1500

Food and Miscellaneous $250

Indiegogo Perks and Expenses $400

Total Needed for Production: $3,910

(You'll see our needs surpass our goal; we're relying on ticket sales to cover the remainder.)

What's in it for you? Besides being noted as a generous patron of the arts and esteemed supporter of a playwright you may know and love (or want to know and love), based on your donation level, you will receive: 

a handwritten thank you on a lovely postcard 

tickets to our show (which you know you're going to buy anyway) and VIP preferred seating

mention in our program

a poster

set of notecards 

a signed limited edition giclee on museum-quality paper, or an original signed painting

*All perks feature the beautiful original print you see here, painted by our multi-talented Siren, Laurel Wetzork.

**Donors of $25 or more will be contacted within one week of donation to select your preferred date(s) to attend the show.

Thank you for helping us reach our goal!


The Impact

By supporting us, you're supporting a team of professional female playwrights whose award-winning work has been performed in locations onstage and onscreen throughout the country. Too often, people overlook the power of story to unite our communities; we appreciate YOU for valuing the power performance art has to convey universal themes that bond us as a society. Thank you for supporting the arts to help bring our stories to life!


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate any and all contributions, but if you're all washed up right now, please support us by:

  • Sharing our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools
  • Link to our campaign on your social media sites
  • Follow us at: twitter.com/5sirens
  • facebook.com/5sirens
  • fivesirens.weebly.com
  • COME SEE OUR SHOW, performing live throughout June at the Asylum lab in Hollywood! You can also purchase tickets to the show at the Fringe site: www.hff15.org/2125

You can follow her on twitter at @LSteinroeder. Alum of the National Theater Institute at the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center. SDC Associate Member. www.laurasteinroeder.weebly.com

OUR CAST:
   
Robert Seeley (Ten Years Left, Whatever Works, Spock at Bat)

Tora Kim (Ten Years Left, Out of Here, Whatever Works)  www.torakim.net

Jenny Curtis (Ten Years Left, Spock at Bat)

Bart Tangredi (Ten Years Left)

Kara Ludke (Don't Panic, Ten Years Left)

Henry Kemp (Out of Here)

Julianna Robinson (Don't Panic)  What We Need & What You Get Quality productions demand quality investment, and while we are keeping our costs to the bare minimum, here is what we can't avoid:
Rehearsal space $340
Performance space and Insurance $880
Fringe fees $250
Advertising and marketing $290
Cast and Crew Fees $1500
Food and Miscellaneous $250
Indiegogo Perks and Expenses $400
Total Needed for Production: $3,910
(You'll see our needs surpass our goal; we're relying on ticket sales to cover the remainder.)
What's in it for you? Besides being noted as a generous patron of the arts and esteemed supporter of a playwright you may know and love (or want to know and love), based on your donation level, you will receive: 
a handwritten thank you on a lovely postcard 
tickets to our show (which you know you're going to buy anyway) and VIP preferred seating
mention in our program
a poster
set of notecards 
a signed limited edition giclee on museum-quality paper, or an original signed painting 
*All perks feature the beautiful original print you see here, painted by our multi-talented Siren, Laurel Wetzork.
**Donors of $25 or more will be contacted within one week of donation to select your preferred date(s) to attend the show.


Thank you for helping us reach our goal!
    
The Impact By supporting us, you're supporting a team of professional female playwrights whose award-winning work has been performed in locations onstage and onscreen throughout the country. Too often, people overlook the power of story to unite our communities; we appreciate YOU for valuing the power performance art has to convey universal themes that bond us as a society. Thank you for supporting the arts to help bring our stories to life!

    
Other Ways You Can Help We appreciate any and all contributions, but if you're all washed up right now, please support us by:  Sharing our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools
Link to our campaign on your social media sites
Follow us at: twitter.com/5sirens
facebook.com/5sirens
fivesirens.weebly.com
COME SEE OUR SHOW, performing live throughout June at the Asylum lab in Hollywood! You can also purchase tickets to the show at the Fringe site: www.hff15.org/2125

story:
Short Summary

In our tenth year of creating theatre, our clown duo Morro and Jasp (performed by Heather Marie Annis and Amy Lee and directed by Byron Laviolette), have recently been called "The Amy Poehler and Tina Fey of Canadian Clowning" (Globe and Mail).  We have won a Dora Award (the Canadian version of a Tony Award), a Canadian Comedy Award, a Gourmand Award, and  received 5-star reviews across the country (you can visit our press page here).

This summer we will take off on our greatest adventure yet: we have secured a spot at one of the top venues at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival - the legendary Gilded Balloon (celebrating its 30th Anniversary this year) - where we will be taking our hit show Morro and Jasp do Puberty. We are so excited!

 What We Need & What You Get

Crossing the pond is expensive. Over the course of this project, we will have to pay for a laundry list of things, including flights, accommodations, publicity and marketing materials, venue costs and hired help, costumes and props, meals and much more. Since we will be in Edinburgh for a full month, this will be by far the most expensive undertaking we have ever attempted but we are committed to making it worthwhile. After 10 years, we have learned how to stretch (and re-stretch) a dollar but we know enough to know we can’t do it alone. 

Our goal is to raise $30,000. This campaign for $10,000, in addition to fundraising events and arts grants, is one of our many initiatives to reach this goal by the end of July. 

 Some of our expenses will include:
  • Venue Rental $6,000
  • UK Publicist $5,000
  • Accommodations $5,000
  • Flights $6,000
  • Marketing Costs $4,000
We need your help to make this clown dream a clown reality! We have a variety of perks to show our appreciation for your generosity including tickets to our summer show in Toronto, T-shirts, and personalized gifts from Morro and Jasp and from Scotland. 

The Impact

The Edinburgh Festival is the largest theatre festival in the world. Presenters from all over the globe flock to the three-and-a-half week festival looking for the next big hit and we think it’s our time to shine!  

Our presence at this festival will give us exposure in some of the biggest publications in the world, help us create connections with international theatre presenters and aid us in establishing relationships for future touring. 

If you know us, you know that we are dreamers who work every day to bring our dreams of love and laughter to life. Any help in bringing this dream to an international audience would mean the world to us. 

Risks & Challenges

As this is the largest project that we have taken on both financially and in scope, we have taken great care to do it properly.  

We are thrilled to be working with Derrick Chua, a seasoned theatre producer - not to mention one of Toronto's top entertainment lawyers - who has managed several successful Edinburgh tours in recent years. 

We will also be working with Prospero Communications, a UK-based publicist, to ensure that we can stand out among over 3,000 shows that appear at the festival. 

We currently have posters and flyers being designed, extra costumes in the works, and ukelele songs in rehearsal (in addition to our show) so that we are prepared to shine both when we are promoting on the streets and when we are performing each night at 8pm. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to make a donation, DON'T WORRY!  You can still help. Please share our campaign online via social media and/or email. It is really important for us to get the word out about our campaign so your participation in this is extremely valuable. 

Feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools below or copy and paste the links. 

If you are going to be at the Edinburgh Fringe or know anyone who will be, here’s the link to information about our show in Edinburgh:  https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/morro-and-jasp-do-puberty)

Thank you from the bottom of our clown hearts!

story:
About Us

Uncharted Dance Company was founded in the summer of 2012 by Chelsea Cousineau with the hope of sharing her passion with others.  With her college dance career ending, Chelsea saw the opportunity to begin to bring her dreams to reality while giving herself and others in a similar situation a place to dance while beginning the next chapter of their lives.  
 
Uncharted Dance Company looks forward to an exciting future!

What We Need & What You Get

Starting a dance company can be quite expensive and we need all the help we can get.

Just to name a few of the things the funds will be going to:

  • Costumes
  • Transportation
  • Insurance
  • Space/Rental Fees
  • Entrance Fees
  • Props
  • Videographer Fees

Though we have set a monetery goal any funds raised, whether they reach the goal or not, will be put towards these areas of our company!  We all dance as members for free out of love and the hope to inspire others - we are just looking for money to get our feet off the ground. Any and all contributions are greatly appreciated more than you could ever know.

The Impact

Through Uncharted Dance Company we are hoping to continue to carry on our passion for dance and performance (and for some of us that even means after college).  We want to show people that a group of college aged young adults can have a passion that they take seriously, dedicate their efforts to and produce something tha they can be proud of.  We would like to inspire others to pursue their dreams and show that if you really want and work hard for something you can acheive it. We are a small town company with big dreams and hopefully a bright future.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone will have the ability to donate actual funds to our campaign and that is perfectly okay!  We would like to thank you for taking your time to check it out and hope that you will be willing to pass it on to everyone you know and help us spread the word! 

 

Thank you for your support from the bottom of our hearts!

story:
Kirov Academy of Ballet of Washington, DC is at a crossroads.

Although we are known around the world for producing professional-level ballet dancers, many people in our own backyard are unaware of the Kirov Academy of Ballet. By Getting to the Lisner Auditorium, George Washington University's 1,500 seat world-class venue, we will increase awareness of the school in the Washington, DC community so that we can secure coveted funding from individual donors, build an endowment and reaffirm our spot as one of the top classical ballet academies in the world, for generations to come.

Getting to the Lisner is make or break for our school. After having produced a major performance off campus only one other time, we are now attempting to do something that has never been done in the 23-year history of the school—mount a second consecutive major production off campus at a main stage venue, instead of holding it on campus as we usually do. We are planning to present our 2013 Spring Performance Series at the Lisner Auditorium - featuring La Sylphide Act II and George Balanchine's Allegro Brillante, May 23-25, 2013.  If we are successful, we know that the heightened local awareness will help solidify the school's reputation and attract the types of funders who can help us grow. Because, honestly, we are a leading ballet academy with student dancers who can perform on par with those at professional companies.

But this move to the Lisner and the enhanced visibility that it will bring us requires an investment—a bigger investment than we've ever made before for a single production. Bottom line: we need $75,000 to make these performances a reality. 

Production costs can add up quickly. For example, we need $30,000 to secure the venue, $5,000 to pay the guest choreographer, $20,000 for scenery and costumes, and $20,000 for media buys and printing to promote the show. 

Your support will help us pull it off.

In return you'll experience some awesome perks including:

  • Roundtrip airfare for 2 to St. Petersburg, Russia to visit the famed Mariinsky Theatre
  • a 3 Night Stay in Washington, DC at the luxurious Dupont Circle Hotel
  • VIP tickets to our performances
  • Exclusive KAB gear, and much more… 

If we are successfully able to produce this spring performance series, we KNOW that we will significantly enhance the school's credibility and visibility, and signal that we have truly arrived on the scene.

Your contribution is a vote of support that we need to move to bigger venues, woo larger audiences, and create the groundswell of support required to help our academy continue to thrive. 

We would value your contribution - no matter how small! And in addition to donating money to the campaign, you can help us in the following ways:

  • Share our campaign with your friends on Facebook and Twitter
  • Send an email to friends who you think would support our cause
  • Tell people about our amazing school and students

Thank you for your support!

*The “Getting to the Lisner” campaign will run through June 4, 2013.

*All donations will be acknowledged with a thank-you letter, which will serve as your receipt for tax purposes.

The Kirov Academy of Ballet of Washington, DC is a nonprofit organization and is tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) of the IRS code. Our federal tax number is 54-1424487. Your very generous contribution to our “Getting to the Lisner” campaign is tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

story:
The Project

What if we could walk with Brad Majors and Janet Weiss all the way from Betty and Ralph's wedding to and throughout Frank’s mansion?

Brisbane Management Group (BMG) is raising funds to produce an immersive, interactive production of The Rocky Horror Show in the style of a Haunted House tour, to run throughout the month of October, just in time for Halloween. BMG’s goal is to produce art that improves community. By setting the production in various undeveloped and secret spaces in Munhall, we hope to bring Pittsburgh patrons to a new location to participate in theater to bring the Munhall community together in pride as they host a one-of-a-kind theatrical experience, and to encourage patrons to enjoy some of the wonderful things the Munhall area has to offer, including the impressive architecture and community programs housed in the Carnegie Library of Munhall, the beautiful park adjacent, and of course excellent restaurants like Rock Bottom lining The Waterfront, and much more!

To fully realize the bridge between art and community, the spaces we discovered will be entirely dressed by both local and visiting artists as art installations, so that as the audience walks through the space, their senses are engaged not only by the actors, but also by the music and environment surrounding them. Art installations will be key in setting the backdrop for the spaces we use.

The Pitch

We need your help to make this vision a reality. As they say in the show, “Don’t dream it, be it!” We already have the rights fully paid for by a generous donor (that’s $2000 already raised!). We have a talented team assembled. We have the backdrop for our production and our spaces secured. Now we need to turn several raw, undeveloped spaces into gripping, fully-functional pieces of our haunted-house-esque puzzle. We have many challenges to overcome, including rigging sound and lights throughout a traveling show, hiring top-notch performersand filling out a production team with excellent crew to ensure that each and every patron has a safe, memorable, and truly unique experience.

October performances at 8pm on 10th-12th, 17th-19th, 24th-26th, 30th, and two closing shows on Halloween at both 8pm and midnight.

Every single gift is deeply appreciated and is tax-deductible to the amount permitted by law. Even $10 goes so very far to help us get the materials we need, so please give what you can to help us realize this ambitious vision. Here's what we're looking at:

The Budget

Where's all this money go, you ask? Great question. First and foremost, we think it's important to pay artists, and we hope you agree. The largest portion of our budget goes toward paying performers and crew. Here's the remaining breakdown:

   Salaries: 40% 

   13 Performers, Director, Musicians, Designers, Running Crew

   Rental Costs: 10%

   6 separate performance areas and rehearsal space

   Materials: 30%

   (Sets, Costumes, Props, Equipment for Sound and Lights)

   Marketing & Publicity: 10%

   (Programs, Flyers, Posters, Design, Printing, Paid Listings/Advertisements,                     Distribution)

   Royalties: 10%

   (Licensing fees and rights to perform the show)


What Else You Can Do

Share, Share, Share

Share this campaign on Facebook: Click here

Tell your friends on Twitter: Click here

Volunteer

Become a volunteer! We need volunteers of all backgrounds and interest levels to help sell ad space in programs, handle ticketing, serve as traveling ushers, hang posters and place promotional materials…the list goes on and on. Tell us what you’re interested in and we’ll find a good fit for you. Donate as much or as little time as you want.

Click here and fill out the form to volunteer your time for The Rocky Horror Show.

Whether through your donation of time, your financial support, or even just by spreading the word, we’re thankful to have you join our team!

The Team

Kelli Brisbane (founder/artistic director, BMG)

Jackie Baker (producing associate)

Lisa Ann Goldsmith (director)

Pixie Colbert (technical director)

story:
Who we are

We are three theatre artists, sharing our love for acting, clowning and creating fun work: Joey Lespérance (actor, clown, creator), Emilie Leclerc (actor, clown, creator) and Alison Kelly (actor, clown, creator and director).

All of us are Jessie Richardson Award Nominees, we live and work in Vancouver, B.C.  We are proud to be part of the artistic fabric of our community.

Our project

Performed en français with English surtitles, Cucci & Cabana is a theatrical clown show about body image and its societal pressure. In this production, we meet Cucci and his neighbour Cabana in their restless quest of Beauty. We are very passionate about the theme of this show and our real world experiences feed and inspire this clown universe.

Our world

We live in a world where youth is power. We live in the world of, tummy tucks, implants of all kinds (even calves), hair plugs, facial peels, Brazilian waxing (ouch!), anus bleaching (it's true), teeth whitening, hair removal (anywhere and everywhere) and lipo-suctions are the norm. We find this reality extremely inspiring for a clown show. Come and laugh with us as we look at ourselves.

Support

Although this project benefits from Le Conseil des Arts du Canada (Canada Art Council), a bit more money is needed for the full production of Cucci & Cabana. We secured FREE rehearsal space for the development and part of our rehearsals, a saving of a few thousands of $$$. Also Joey and Emilie developed Cucci & Cabana with no pay to ensure the lowest cost of this production.

 Need

To complete this production and perform we need another $4,000.00. That's all! It will contribute for the designers, technician, stage manager and the theatre space (Studio 16 in Vancouver) where Cucci & Cabana will be performed.

Your perks

On top of a warm and fuzzy feeling that comes with helping others, everlasting good karma and being part of this amazing team you'll be gratefully thanked in the program, receive personal email, pictures of Cucci & Cabana in their best outfits and balloon delivery (Vancouver area).

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. You could also use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.

Please note that this production will be en français with English surtitles. Cucci & Cabana opens at Studio 16, Vancouver, on May 3th 2013.

Our project
Performed en français with English surtitles, Cucci & Cabana is a theatrical clown show about body image and its societal pressure. In this production, we meet Cucci and his neighbour Cabana in their restless quest of Beauty. We are very passionate about the theme of this show and our real world experiences feed and inspire this clown universe.
Our world
We live in a world where youth is power. We live in the world of, tummy tucks, implants of all kinds (even calves), hair plugs, facial peels, Brazilian waxing (ouch!), anus bleaching (it's true), teeth whitening, hair removal (anywhere and everywhere) and lipo-suctions are the norm. We find this reality extremely inspiring for a clown show. Come and laugh with us as we look at ourselves.
Support
Although this project benefits from Le Conseil des Arts du Canada (Canada Art Council), a bit more money is needed for the full production of Cucci & Cabana. We secured FREE rehearsal space for the development and part of our rehearsals, a saving of a few thousands of $$$. Also Joey and Emilie developed Cucci & Cabana with no pay to ensure the lowest cost of this production.
 Need 
To complete this production and perform we need another $4,000.00. That's all! It will contribute for the designers, technician, stage manager and the theatre space (Studio 16 in Vancouver) where Cucci & Cabana will be performed.
Your perks
On top of a warm and fuzzy feeling that comes with helping others, everlasting good karma and being part of this amazing team you'll be gratefully thanked in the program, receive personal email, pictures of Cucci & Cabana in their best outfits and balloon delivery (Vancouver area).
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. You could also use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.
Please note that this production will be en français with English surtitles. Cucci & Cabana opens at Studio 16, Vancouver, on May 3th 2013.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Jayda Jeske and I have been dancing since i was 3 years old. It's a goal of mine to become a professional dancer in a company such as Alvin Ailey. I currently dance 6 days a week, (7 sometimes during performances) at Minnesota Dance Theatre doing mostly classical ballet and graham-based modern.

I have wanted to train with Alvin Ailey ever since I took their Horton master class last year. I am lucky enough to have received a full scholarship to the professional program based on my audition and also they are contributing $1,000 to my housing which is incredible! I'm so thankful for this opportunity and feel that it would be a waste to not accept this offer. The program is 6 weeks so I would be there for approximately 42 days.

Unfortunately, my mom, being a single mom caring for me and my younger brother, cannot afford the rest of the housing and a few other necessary expenses. 

Any help you could provide would be greatly appreciated, even spreading the word to others! 

What We Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise at least $1,600 (9% will be going to indie gogo if I do not meet my goal) 

This money would be going towards:

The rest of my housing, meals, airfare, and other necessary items that are dance related (pointe shoes, leotards, etc.)

If I do not reach my goal, I will use this money to go to a summer intensive that is closer to home and less costly. However, I REALLY am hoping to go to Alvin Ailey, especially since I received a full scholarship to be able to attend.  

If I exceed my goal, I will donate the extra money to the Alvin Ailey school.

The Impact

If I can go to this intensive, I have a feeling this would impact my whole future as a dancer. 6 weeks studying with THE Alvin Ailey school?? It would be impossible not to improve! I would be forever grateful to attend this summer program. 

I have been to other summer intensives too, such as Alonzo King LINES in San Francisco, (I've been for 2 summers and enjoyed every second of it!), and these intensives really helped me discover my passion for improvising and doing more contemporary ballet versus the more classical style that I've been doing my whole life. Alvin Ailey would be an ideal place to go since they too are more focused on the contemporary ballet aspect. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you so much for your contributions! Even if you cannot donate money, just spreading the word would help very much! Please share this on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or any other way you can!

Thank you!

story:
Hi! My name is Marta and I am a theatre director. I set up Foxtrotter Theatre Company with the aim to promote Spanish new writing in London. This is our second production and we are going to perform at the Park Theatre from the 15th of April until 11th of May. To make this happen, we need your help!

We need a contribution from you to reach our target of £4,000. This will allow us to put on a full professional production and will pay for branding and promotion and hire sound and lighting equipment.

The play was staged in Barcelona and sold out at the Grec Festival season. 

"Archimides' Principle is the hit of the Grec Festival." La Vanguardia 

"The play shows us the social paranoia that we are sorrowed by. One of the best shows of The Grec festival." El Periodico 

"Magnificient, Unmissable." Time Out 

"The sensitivity of the play is amazing." El Punt Avui 

We are already in our third week of rehearsals and we are all really excited about this production.

Please help us reach our target and you check out the benefits listed on the side. 

THE PLAY
How safe are our children in the care of a stranger? How much do we know about the people we work with? How far would we go to protect ourselves? A town that's haunted by an incident at the nearby Scouts centre. Regular swimming lessons come to a halt when a swimming instructor is accused of inappropriately touching a child during a lesson – and the dangers of Facebook creep to the surface. When history appears to repeat itself what can we do but expect the worst. Put on your water-wings, listen to the evidence and decide for yourself...
