story:
The Company

Arrowwood Theatre Co. is a new theatre company based in Windsor, Ontario. Composed of several University of Windsor students, Arrowwood Theatre Co. aims to create theatre that is challenging, yet accessible to all audiences. With training in many movement techniques, including contact improvisation and Viewpoints technique, the members of Arrowwood are interested in the stories that our bodies can tell and the meaning that is held in the way we touch one another. The company hopes to create theatre that inspires people to look deeper into the everyday and find meaning in every interaction.

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign was created in the hopes of generating enough fundraising to make our dream of filling the Al Green Theatre come true! The fundraising from this campaign will go toward creating and devising, lighting and sound engineering, but mainly, towards publicity. The Toronto Fringe scene can be hard to crack for a group of students from Windsor, but we feel that with your help, we can do anything!

We are hoping to raise a minimum of $1,000. As mentioned above, a majority of this money will go towards publicity, but will also support the company by giving us more flexibility in the creating process with lighting and sound design as well as costume design. Our goals for publicity revolve around a low-waste, low-paper consumption model that will allow us to spread the word about our show without spreading waste!

We will be offering some perks for those who are generous enough to contribute financially to this project! 

The Impact

Sponsors are not simply donating money, they are backing ideas and supporting theatre that investigates important questions. They are backing dreams. 

This is an ambitious project that we believe will challenge the Canadian theatre scene. As of today, contact improvisation and movement theatre makes up a very small amount of the theatre being produced in Canada. We hope to change this by creating a show that demonstrates how accessible this type of theatre can be to all kinds of audiences. By helping us grow this production, you will be helping us share the beauty of the human body. We want to showcase just how wonderful it is to tell stories through movement and touch and how important it is to move our bodies and reconnect to the animal in all of us.

This show found incredible success in front of Windsor audiences and we hope, with your help, it can reach this same success in Toronto!

Other Ways You Can Help

We at Arrowwood Theatre Co. understand that not everyone is in the position to contribute financially. 

If you are unable to contribute financially, please consider:

  • Sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc with your friends and family
  • Following us on Facebook and Instagram at @ArrowwoodTheatreCo !
  • Contacting us concerning ways you can help us advertise at your job, school, city, and so on!
  • Contributing your services and/or products! (we are always looking for other artists to collaborate with!)

story:
A Ngaire & Naureen Prisontime Special

GET CLEAN, GET GOD, GET OUT!

Too drunk to live, but too stubborn to die, Ngaire and Naureen are putting their combined 140+ years of experience on men, drinking, race relations, men, religion, drinking, politics, men and drinking on stage, from May 16th at Auckland’s Basement Theatre.

The lovely ladies have been chosen to share their advice at this year's New Zealand International Comedy Festival - but need your help in getting there! It doesn't look like there'll be enough in the Te Awamutu Ladies’ Society kitty to fund the show AND Ngaire's drinking problem, so donate* to support these beauties and New Zealand comedy at its finest!

Talkback radio’s favourite acid-tongued advice-mongers are making the leap from the airwaves to the stage for the most noble of reasons; charity, helping those in society who really can’t, or can’t be bothered, to help themselves. The ladies of Waikeria Prison are the lucky recipients of this advice; advice that’s sometimes hard to hear, but it’s always the truth that hurts most. Ngaire and Naureen pull no punches - unless that huckmole Maisy Smith’s involved. She deserves everything she gets, and that includes a face-full of Ngaire’s fist. Drawing on real life experiences, writer and actor Samuel Christopher and Mark Covich bring the stories of elderly women in rural New Zealand to life in a satirical, dark, hilarious comedy skewering Kiwi culture, celebrity, sex and death..

There are some real goodies up for grabs for our supporters. Who knows? If you donate-for-a-date, you may end up the future honey of one of these darlings.

 “The Ngaire & Naureen Helpline Hour is without a doubt the funniest play I have been to in a long time. Samuel Christopher has tapped into a sense of nostalgic kiwiana to create characters that are both endearing and edgy. He walks the line without crossing it, and the results are hilarious. This is kiwi comedy at it’s finest."

- TJ McDonald, Billy T Nominee, 2011

Everyone knows a Ngaire or a Naureen - in the tradition of Paul Henry, they’re just saying what everyone’s thinking, dear. You will love, hate, and love to hate Ngaire and Naureen.

If you can’t donate to the campaign then that’s alright, dear - there’s still the opportunity to see the show!

AUCKLAND  
Dates:                          Wed 16 – Sat 19 May 2012, 10pm daily
Venue:                         The Basement, Lower Greys Ave, City
Tickets:                         Adults $20

Show:                          50 minutes
Bookings:                     0800 842 538 or                                                                 http://premier.ticketek.co.nz/shows/show.aspx?sh=NGAIRENA12&fb_ref=Show&fb_source=home_oneline#.T1_5j8xQAy5

For more information contact: 
Name: Natalie Braid                   
Phone: 0212307208                                
Email: natalie.braid@gmail.com               
Website: www.facebook.com/pages/Ngaire-Naureen/332264380147417

 

* Donations are in US Dollars.

story:
Blackout Theatre Company... A brief history. 

Blackout Theatre Company may have started as a small group of college students from the University of New Mexico doing mostly improv and comedy sketches, but in five short years we have grown leaps and bounds. We host a monthly comedy and improv labratory, create our own ensemble original works, run a multimedia internal training program, orchestrate a youth education program that will reach over 800 students this year, and we make award winning and viral internet videos like "Sh*t Burquenos say."

But we waste so much paper!

We want to give our 12 compnay members each a tablet for their job. Not only will they get us more organized, they will eliminate printing costs from office paperwork, dozens of scripts and rewrites, and student paperwork.  Lets go digital and do away with all that!

The Power of Technology

In order to aquire twelve (12) tablets and their necessary applications, we need $500 per company member, $6,000.With a tablet for every company member we could eliminate scripts and most internal paperwork entirely!  But even if we only reached a portion of our goal, with a few tablets, our company could use them for:

  • Note Taking and Review at Staff and Board Meetings 
  • Inter-Office Presentations
  • Grant Proposal Presentations
  • Theatrical Set Construction and Planning
  • Credit Card Machine for Theatrical Patron's Convinence 
  • Administrative Uses Such as Budgeting, Mileage Counting, Shipping Tracker, Invoicing and Reimbursment.
  • Theatrical and Media Lighting Design Planning and Execution   
  • Remote Focusing Unit for Larger Lenues (Remote Control for Light Boards)
  • GPS Map Maker for Touring
  • General Purpose Reference Books 
    • Dictionary, Translators, Spell checker, Thesaures’s.
  • General Company Uses Such as Syncronized Quick Reference Calendar, Address Book, Contacts, and Multimedia 
  • Production Sound and Lighting Playback Including Sound fx, Pre-Show Music, Lighting Cues, and Video
  • Consice Lesson Planning with Syncorniztion and Consolidation
  • Paperless Script Editing and Sharing
  • Teaching Tools for the Classroom
  • Teaching Tools for Internal Company Use
    • Design, Directing, Writing, and Acting Reference 

Should we not meet our goal of $6,000, Blackout Theatre Company will use whatever funds accrued to buy as many as possible, with the most relevant applications. We sincerely believe that with this new technology, Blackout Theatre Company can improve its impact on the Albuquerque community.

We need your Help!
Blackout is a 501(c)(3) non profit organization, we are all volunteers with day jobs and we need your help!  If you can't donate, please consider passing this along to someone who can!

story:
Short Summary

You did it!  You met and surpassed our pre-production fundraising goal! 

But there's still a chance to help.  The money raised so far will cover our festival fees, but we're going to need a total of $1600 to cover the artists' stipends and technical elements as well.

Ed Krystosek's hilarious and heart-touching new play No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying explores the power and limits of human bonds through the 30-year friendship of "Player 1" and "Player 2", life-long friends who happen to play an awful lot of Super Mario Brothers.  Accompanied by 8-bit music, we meet the men at the age of seven in World 1-1 and follow them all the way through college, marriages, and families to the tearful but uplifting ending in World 8-4.  Along the way, virtual princesses will be saved and metaphorical dragons defeated.

The play is making its World Premiere this August in the Chicago Fringe Festival, directed by Peter Connor.

Thanks to you we've covered our festival fees and gotten a start on the funds we'll need to pay our performers and designers, but we still need your help to cover the entire $1600 nut.  This is your opportunity not only to contribute to the ongoing tradition of boldly independent theatre in Chicago, but also to become a part of the No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying production family.  All of our contributors will be invited and encouraged to participate in a number of events throughout the spring and summer in support of the production, including sneak-peek rehearsals, fund-raising parties, and more.

What We Need & What You Get

By helping us reach our $600 goal you've already covered our "festival fees" for the administrative support and services offered by the great folks at The Chicago Fringe Festival for our seven-show run, including but far-from-limited-to our performance space, general promotion, ticketing sales and services, and technical support. 

Above and beyond that $600 goal, we're going to need an additional $1000 by August to pay stipends to our performers and designers and to construct our set and costumes.  We're planning to throw parties and benefits throughout the summer to raise those funds, but early contributions will allow us to focus more time and energy on production as our opening approaches.

All of our contributors will receive the following:

$1 or more - Our eternal gratitude, and invitations to all of our promotional and fund-raising events throughout the spring and summer.

$25 or more - The above, and a pair of complimentary tickets to any one of the seven performances of our August production in the Chicago Fringe Festival, dates and precise location TBA.

$50 or more - All of the above, plus a "No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying" t-shirt.

$100 or more - All of the above, plus a "Co-Producer" credit in the show program.

$500 or more - Ten complementary tickets to the performance(s) of your choosing, a "No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying" t-shirt, plus an "Executive Producer" credit in the show program.

The Impact

You're going to help us bring a new work of art to the world, and along the way you'll help create professional opportunities for a half-dozen actors and designers, all for less than you might spend on dinner the night you come to see the show.

Be a part of our family, and help keep Chicago the most exciting theatre town in the world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends, your families, even your enemies... they can always attend a different performance. 

Link to this fundraiser on Facebook, and help make this unique and delightful play happen.

Above and beyond that $600 goal, we're going to need an additional $1000 by August to pay stipends to our performers and designers and to construct our set and costumes.  We're planning to throw parties and benefits throughout the summer to raise those funds, but early contributions will allow us to focus more time and energy on production as our opening approaches.
All of our contributors will receive the following:
$1 or more - Our eternal gratitude, and invitations to all of our promotional and fund-raising events throughout the spring and summer.
$25 or more - The above, and a pair of complimentary tickets to any one of the seven performances of our August production in the Chicago Fringe Festival, dates and precise location TBA.
$50 or more - All of the above, plus a "No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying" t-shirt.
$100 or more - All of the above, plus a "Co-Producer" credit in the show program.
$500 or more - Ten complementary tickets to the performance(s) of your choosing, a "No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying" t-shirt, plus an "Executive Producer" credit in the show program.


The Impact
You're going to help us bring a new work of art to the world, and along the way you'll help create professional opportunities for a half-dozen actors and designers, all for less than you might spend on dinner the night you come to see the show.
Be a part of our family, and help keep Chicago the most exciting theatre town in the world. 

Other Ways You Can Help



Tell your friends, your families, even your enemies... they can always attend a different performance. 
Link to this fundraiser on Facebook, and help make this unique and delightful play happen.

story:
THE PLAY

Spring Awakening is a story about what growth. Over the course of one full year, the play follows a group of young adults as they learn the most personal of lessons: what it means to love and be loved. 

A hero for the marginalized,  Wedekind's play darkly and beautifully explores the lives of those who grow up afraid of who they are. 

 

WHY WE'RE ASKING FOR SUPPORT 

The money raised in this campaign will go towards providing production costs for a two-week workshop, and staged reading performance of our adaptation of "Spring Awakening", to be read for an invited audience on November 20th.

The purpose of the reading is twofold.

Firstly, our hope is both to showcase the final version of the new script, and garner interest in the future production of the piece. It will also highlight conceptual and staging elements for the play, bought to life by a dynamic design team.

Secondly, we will be using the evening as a way to bring awareness to the need for support for youth in crisis by donating proceeds from the evening to Skylark Children and Family Services--a new agency in Toronto dedicated to bringing accessible support to families and youth in times of need. 

Most of the funding for this workshop and its artists has been made possible through generous sponsors. This last push for funding is to ensure the play can be seen as boldly as the artistic team assembled imagines it can be performed in. 

 

YOUR CONTRIBUTION

The $3,000.00 being asked for will not be used to pay for artists. Instead, it will be used to fill the rehearsal hall with the materials necessary to bring this vivid new interpretation to life. The items created and developed for this workshop will be used again in final production. 

The detailed breakdown of the funding is listed below.

Budget Breakdown:

Set: $800.00-$1000.00

Costumes: $800.00-$1,000.00

Sound Design/Instrument Rental/Recording: $800.00-$1,000.00

Anything over $3,000.00: Automatic donation to Skylark Children and Youth Services

story:
Our Current Situation

Like most dance organizations, we rent space from various dance studios in order to hold our classes.  The problem is, there are limited affordable options for this type of hourly studio rental in Richmond and competition for time slots can be pretty steep. There simply isn't enough consistently available studio time available to meet our needs. What we have right now is a hodgepodge of different locations (and often the inconvenient class times that no one else wants).  
Add into the mix Kyle & Dave's ongoing search for a new permanent home for their weekly dance, The Jazz Den, and you have a perfect stew of frustration.

What We Need Is Our Own Space.

We've found a fantastic location for our very own studio, but it will take some upfront investment to fit it out for dancers. We are fortunate to already own a pretty kickin' PA system, but there is a lot more we need to really make this a studio.  Here are just a few of our startup expenses:

  • Mirrors. Mirrors are hella expensive, did you know? Installing 30 ft of wall-mounted mirrors will cost us almost $2500.
  • Floors. Any swing dancer knows you need a smooth wood floor to really kick it.  We are looking into building our own dance floor, similar to what you might dance on at an event. $3300
  • Lights. No one wants to dance under harsh fluorescent bulbs. We'll need to install welcoming, energy-efficient ambient lighting for use during dance socials.  Let Ryan loose in the lamp room at IKEA: $300.
  • Fans. Central air is already installed, but we'll need a bit more oomph to help keep you cool. We are looking at some spiffy industrial fans.  $300 (Bonus: you can stand in front of them and pretend to be in an 80's music video. We won't judge you. Wait, no, Kyle will totally judge you.)
  • Furniture. We'll need somewhere for you to sit, storage cubbies for your big ol' dance bags, and a front desk for check-in. More fun at IKEA! $500. 
  • Curtains and fabric. No one wants to be stared at while dancing! We'll need some curtains for the front windows. We'd also like to do some draping on the ceiling to help with acoustics and ambiance. $300
  • Miscellaneous. There are lots of other less fun things that cost money: permits, applications, paying a deposit on the space, advertising, taking time off of work, and covering rent & operating expenses while we get the studio ready to go. There will also probably be some surprise expenses along the way, so we've made this a big catch-all category. $3000.


Stretch Goals

As we near our goal of $10,000, we still have over 3 weeks left in our campaign. We've identified some stretch goals, in the event that we exceed our overall campaign goal.
  • Visiting Instructors - Something we love to do is bring in out of town instructors for small workshops to give perspective and variety to our students.  Because they need to be affordable for students, but involve more costs than a local workshop, such ventures are generally a loss, which is subsidized by our regular class income.  With more income tied up in the studio, we will need to work extra hard to make these small special event workshops a reality. A budget of $500 - $1000 would enable us to subsidize 2 to 3 of these in 2017.
  • I *Heart* Balboa - Our big yearly Balboa workshop weekend attracts dancers from all over the country and builds local interest in learning Balboa.  This event gets roughly one third of it's budget from our class income throughout the year.  Since much of this income will now be dedicated to running the studio, there will be  less left over to invest in I *Heart* Balboa. This means we will need to make some alterations to the size and/or format for 2017 unless we can supplement that money.  (For example, to keep the format from 2016, we would need roughly $4500 in additional funds beyond what the event itself brings in). A more modest goal is to adjust our format to two instructor pairs, for which we would only need roughly $2000 of supplemental funds.

About the Space

(It's bigger on the inside!)
We've located a 750 square foot space in our price range near the Lakeside Farmer's Market. (For reference, that's 150 more square feet than Illumination Studio, which we currently use for several classes, the Sunday Shuffle and all of our Balboa dances).   The other businesses in this building will be closed in the evenings while we are conducting classes, meaning noise should not be an issue. There's tons of parking and there's even a brewery two doors down the street! It's going to be a fantastic location and the visibility may even snag us some new students.

What You Get (Show Me the Perks!)

I mean, a swing dance studio existing in Richmond is a pretty cool perk, buuuut we obviously want to give you some other thank-you gifts for helping fund our start-up costs! Here are just some of the things up for grabs:
  • RVA Swing baseball t-shirts 
  • Fuel Dave and Erica's DJ rivalry by choosing a selfie with Terrapin or Reginald Red Panda. May the best mascot win.
  • Your very own Terrapin Portcullis video
  • Custom Erica "Laser Fairy" Vess PhotoShop Shenanigans
  • Private lessons with Dave Barry & Kyle Kelley
  • Famous home-made pizza or ravioli from Ryan Lemar
  • DJ services from Erica & Dave
  • Life-time free admission to weekly social dances at the studio
What happens if we surpass our goal?
I'm pretty sure Ryan will eat one of his hats and perhaps a pig will fly. BUT, if something that amazing did happen, we would use the money to get better flooring & mirrors, advertise the studio, upgrade the decor from basic to bangin', and create a budgetary cushion for leaner times. We can also use campaign overages to create a budget for hiring visiting guest instructors!
What happens if we don't reach our goal?
If we don't reach our funding goal, Kyle will cry and Dave will make lawyer-face. But Ryan & Erica will be the most bummed out because that means they will be using their personal savings to fund the shortfall. Obviously, they can only fund a portion of these start-up costs, which is why your support is so important.
What happens if something falls through?
Again, tears and lawyer face, rude words, and emotional over-eating.  The landlord seems like a really cool dude and is eager to work with us.  Dave has used his magic lawyer pixie dust on all legal documents, and we have already signed the lease for this space, gotten our zoning approved and all that jazz. However, in the event that something unforeseen falls through with this space, we will save the money and  keep looking.  Whatever happens, this money will be used to benefit the Richmond swing dance community and will 100% not send Kyle to Aruba. (For realz, we hid her passport.)

Wait, what about The Dance Space? Will this affect current dances?

We love The Dance Space! It's like our second home.  We don't plan to hold activities that will conflict with the long-running Saturday swing dances there.  Our big goals are more weeknight classes and consistent weeknight social dancing. We want to add to the scene, not subtract from it!


The Impact

When we are done, local swing dancers will have a dedicated studio that is made just for them! Other benefits of this venture include:

  • RVA Swing can offer a full range of class curriculum at a consistent location and at convenient, consolidated times.  Best of all, the RVA Swing team will no longer need to overlap each other's classes. (Score!)
  • We will be able to bring back the Jazz Den and offer mid-week social dancing without the constant uncertainty of venue availability.
  • Our instructors and DJs will always be paid for their work, instead of working on a volunteer basis.
  • When we aren't using it, we can rent our space to dancers who teach other styles of dance at an affordable rate.

Risks & Challenges

Opening a new business is not without risks and challenges. We understand that this will not be easy. (If it was easy, it would already exist.) We also have no illusions about making big bucks as dance studio owners, in fact quite the opposite: this is a labor of love and we are prepared to put in the elbow grease to continue to nurture the scene that we love.

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you broke as a joke? Hey, we feel you. If you still want to help:

  • Share our campaign, make some noise, and spread the word!
  • Are you an event organizer who would be willing to donate an event pass that we can use as a perk? Contact us! We will advertise your event like crazy.
  • Are you a local with a skill or service you could donate as a perk? Contact us!
  • If you're local and handy, we may need assistance with floor installation, painting or other tasks. Come talk to us at a dance.
  • Most importantly, we will need your support after we open! This studio will only be successful if you attend classes and dances (and tell all your friends!) Make sure to support the things you love, so that they keep happening. 


Pictures of Perks!

(Because you might like that!)
RVA Swing Baseball Tee 


Terrapin Space Battle Sticker

(If you don't get it, we don't blame you. But you know you still want one.)


Laser Fairy Strikes Again

(So-Bad-It's-Good.  Get it for yourself or prank your friends.)

story:
Short Summary

I'm Emma Goldman-Sherman, a playwright, a woman, a survivor, and a parent. I wrote Whorticulture, a confrontational tragicomedy about how girls grow up in our culture today. When I first presented Whorticulture, a woman stood up afterwards and publicly and proudly described herself as a survivor. She said, "I've never told anyone before today, but this play makes me feel empowered." People tell me that the play is an eye-opener and an inspiration. Both men and women love this play. Whenever I run into someone who has seen it in development, they want to know when will it get produced. I am trying to get the play into the world because we need this play in the world. It brings people together. It heals. It helps us move forward. 

Dixon Place is an amazing space for experimenting with performance. Dixon Place is giving us Friday night, October 20th, on their mainstage to present Whorticulture to its biggest audience yet so we can give everyone a sense of how powerful this play can be. Cynthia Granville is directing! Janet Mervin is creating costumes!  We have 3 amazing actors: Twinke Burke, Teresa Hui and Sarah Kiefer. We want to pay everyone involved. 

With many small donations, or large donations, we can rent rehearsal space so we can work on this play; we can make costumes designed by a brilliant female designer; we can provide salaries for the actors (all women) and all the women working on this project, and the man who made this video, and the director; and we can hand-out water at all of the rehearsals, and we can print scripts, and we can probably even make some really cool visuals for the back wall of the stage at Dixon Place. 

Theatre is a powerful form of multi-dimensional art that works in time and space to create experience and community in audiences. Women's voices have been underprivileged for so long, we are used to our own silence. I cannot maintain this silence any longer. Please join me in empowering us all with a donation, and if you can't donate financially, share our work on social media. Give us a shout out and let people know that you support women theatre artists who are working to change the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising $3K. It goes toward salaries, rehearsal space, costumes, and visuals. 
  • Depending on the level at which you give, you will receive our personal thanks, our social media shout-out thanks, a Worticulture Pen so you can put your own voice into the world, Whorti-Tickets, Whorti-Kisses (your own personal, dramaturgical session with Emma), your own Flower Shower outside the theatre, Producer or Executive Producer credit, our Gratitude, and Whorti-Cult-Status which comes with the knowledge that you took a step to empower women making art to empower women!  
  • If we don't reach out entire goal, the funds will still go to empower women - this project is slated for Friday night, October 20th, and we will use whatever we raise to make our performance-in-progress a special, once-in-a-lifetime, inspiring, Whorticultural event! 

The Impact

Every time a woman speaks out, other women are inspired and emboldened. We move closer to a truthful, real world where real change can be made. Theatre is transformational. You can help us transform ourselves and each other!

story:
Short Summary

My background and myself:

I truly believe that most people arriving on this page already know most of what makes who I am, but I am more than happy to try to paint a picture here. My name is André Vauthey, I was born and grew up in Switzerland where I graduated from med School and so became a doctor. After some time, I decided to quit/pause to be sure I was in touch with myself first before either continuing or moving on to an other path. Following my instinct I went down the path and tried to become an actor. What I found was much more powerful and truthful: I found myself and with it the artist. I am more than happy to talk more about that face to face :)

Anyway, so here I am today, giving my heart and soul into life and doing projects I love. One of them being this one: The Nina Variations. This is going to be the sixth play I would be performing in. In the same world but on a different optic, I direct theater as well (I have directed so far three plays in NYC and am currently working on my fourth).

I think that gives you some ideas of whom I might be. 

 

Why is this important to me:

I guess, if you felt my being in the paragraph prior to this, you would already know why this is important to me :) Life and truth is all that matters to me and the theater is a place where those two collide and are sacred. I will give my heart, soul and bones to it, but, if you can help me, in one way or the other for me not to have to do that completely, I would truly appreciate as I would love this project not to be my last one :)

Cast and crew:

André Vauthey (Treplev)

Francesca Ravera (Nina):

Emma Arlauskas and Francesco Campari (Directors)

Cat Raynor (set designer)

xx (Light designer)

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need?

Money, of course, but not only and not particularly. Some love, for sure, there is plenty to give and to receive. More pragmatically? Words to mouths, support, come see the show :) and just anything else you feel like doing. One other great thing would be if anyone knows anyone who could come and write something about us; that would be amazing!

What you get?

 No money :) but again, love of course. And anything you feel you want. We will have official perks (sign fotos, free tickets, etc) but if you feel like you would like to donate but don’t like the perks, feel free to shoot me a text and see what we can find. Or if you feel like donating and don’t need anything, that’s beautiful too.

What We Need & What You Get

We seek to raise a flexible goal of $2500, to help us cover the last production expenses, such as allowing extra rehearsing time and stipend to cast and crew and finishing the set.

Every dollar helps in the founding of this project, and is greatly appreciated!

If you donate $15 or more, you will receive a poster signed from the actors, if you donate $1500 or more you’ll receive a producer credit.

If the goal of $2500 won’t be reached, the show must go on, and Nina and Treplev will still fully live their possibilities to meet and talk to each other.

 

The Impact

Through this campaign we are looking to enhance the production of this upcoming project, bringing you the absolute best version of this beautiful piece of Theatre.

This is the fourth play we are bringing to the stage in a NYC theater, and we have a deep understanding of what it takes to put up a great production!
story_txt:
Short Summary
My background and myself:
I truly believe that most people arriving on this page already know most of what makes who I am, but I am more than happy to try to paint a picture here. My name is André Vauthey, I was born and grew up in Switzerland where I graduated from med School and so became a doctor. After some time, I decided to quit/pause to be sure I was in touch with myself first before either continuing or moving on to an other path. Following my instinct I went down the path and tried to become an actor. What I found was much more powerful and truthful: I found myself and with it the artist. I am more than happy to talk more about that face to face :)
Anyway, so here I am today, giving my heart and soul into life and doing projects I love. One of them being this one: The Nina Variations. This is going to be the sixth play I would be performing in. In the same world but on a different optic, I direct theater as well (I have directed so far three plays in NYC and am currently working on my fourth).
I think that gives you some ideas of whom I might be. 
 
Why is this important to me:
I guess, if you felt my being in the paragraph prior to this, you would already know why this is important to me :) Life and truth is all that matters to me and the theater is a place where those two collide and are sacred. I will give my heart, soul and bones to it, but, if you can help me, in one way or the other for me not to have to do that completely, I would truly appreciate as I would love this project not to be my last one :)
Cast and crew:
André Vauthey (Treplev)
Francesca Ravera (Nina):
Emma Arlauskas and Francesco Campari (Directors)
Cat Raynor (set designer)
xx (Light designer)
 
What We Need & What You Get
What we need?
Money, of course, but not only and not particularly. Some love, for sure, there is plenty to give and to receive. More pragmatically? Words to mouths, support, come see the show :) and just anything else you feel like doing. One other great thing would be if anyone knows anyone who could come and write something about us; that would be amazing!
What you get?
 No money :) but again, love of course. And anything you feel you want. We will have official perks (sign fotos, free tickets, etc) but if you feel like you would like to donate but don’t like the perks, feel free to shoot me a text and see what we can find. Or if you feel like donating and don’t need anything, that’s beautiful too.

What We Need & What You Get
We seek to raise a flexible goal of $2500, to help us cover the last production expenses, such as allowing extra rehearsing time and stipend to cast and crew and finishing the set.
Every dollar helps in the founding of this project, and is greatly appreciated!
If you donate $15 or more, you will receive a poster signed from the actors, if you donate $1500 or more you’ll receive a producer credit.
If the goal of $2500 won’t be reached, the show must go on, and Nina and Treplev will still fully live their possibilities to meet and talk to each other.
 

The Impact
Through this campaign we are looking to enhance the production of this upcoming project, bringing you the absolute best version of this beautiful piece of Theatre.
This is the fourth play we are bringing to the stage in a NYC theater, and we have a deep understanding of what it takes to put up a great production!

story:
World Premier of The Terrible Legend of Victoria Woodhull

Why are we participating in the 18th Hollywood Fringe Festival, and why this story:

  • Ashley has been a professional actress for over a decade, but she has never had the opportunity to perform in a one-woman show.  
  • Theo has been writing and producing theater off and on for almost a decade, but he has never taken on the challenge of writing a show for a single performer. 
  • Karen directed repertory theater during her days in Nashville before moving to LA to pursue film. Her films have been shown in festivals across the country, but she's been longing for the raw power of theater which drew her to this project. 
  • With our combined enthusiasm for the subject matter, and our artistic aesthetic which believes theater should both be simple and have larger social ramifications, we are incredibly excited to bring this show into the world. One could argue that Victoria Woodhull is of greater importance than Susan B. Anthony with regards to the modern fights for equality that women are still facing, and we believe by pushing her name into the cultural limelight we can inspire more people to learn about her and become activists for this cause.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • While many venues offer discounted rates to facilitate Fringe Shows, we still need to pay for basic things like renting the space, getting insurance for the performances, rehearsal space, money for our tech stage manager, and finally a costume and some basic props. 
  • We firmly believe we can make this show simple and powerful without too many bells and whistles, so we are not looking for excess money - just enough to cover the necessities.
  • We are offering discounted seats for donations, and if you happen to have the monies and are feeling especially generous we also have some fun perks including signed scripts, recited poetry, and even the actress and writer cooking you a full 3-course dinner. 

The Impact

We hope this play will both cast a light on Victoria Woodhull's amazing life and her brazen and incredibly activism during a time when women were meant to be bound to their husbands and confined to their homes. In the light of the recent #MeToo movement it's obvious that equality for women still has a LONG way to go, and by giving a public audience a more comprehensive look at this past champion of women, we hope it will give insight and hope as our society continues to push forward. 

Both Ashley and Theo have run their own off-Broadway theater production companies and have had successful runs of a number of shows. They are committed to making theater as affordable and enjoyable as possible, and given their track records they know how to put together a savvy and reasonable budget. 

Risks & Challenges

We are not embarking upon this production with the hopes of great financial gain. What we aspire to is to fill the seats of the Hob Goblin Theater for what may be the last set of performances ever done there before the city of LA re-purposes it. 

The more people we reach, the more people who donate, will translate to a bigger audience to listen to this funny, dramatic, and comprehensive (slightly fictional) look at Victoria's incredible life. We are committed fully to this story and want to share it with as many people as we can. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, please consider joining us for one of our five performances: 

6/3, 6/10, 6/13, 6/16, 6/19

And, we not so humbly ask that you share this with as many people as you can. People who might donate, who might see the show, who might be willing to contribute goods or services we can use to help raise our necessary funds. 

It takes a village to put on a theater show, even if it's just a single performer, and we greatly value our community of fellow artists and patrons who still believe in the value of live story telling.

story:
Ottawa’s first annual Ukrainian summer festival intends to be one of the city’s premier events! 

It will be our first annual festival.  In order to bring to Ottawa the full spectrum of our glorious Ukrainian customs and traditions, we decided to launch this fundraiser so that we can bring more dancers and performers to our Inaugural Event.

We simply want our visitors (you) to leave the Festival breathless.  We want our programming to be inspiring enough to make you simultaneously laugh and cry, educational enough to give us insight into ourselves and others, and captivating enough to bring you back again next year to meet, greet and enjoy performances you may only see once in a lifetime at one of the best parties in town.  After all, this is Ottawa, home to some of the best Festivals in North America.

It is not just about the music and the costumes and the dancing and the food; it’s about all of them - at once.  It is about being immersed in the spirit and soul of Ukrainian arts, culture, history and heritage.

Contact: capitalukrainianfestival@gmail.com

Website: www.capitalukrainianfestival.com

Twitter: @CapUkrFestival

Facebookwww.facebook.com/CapUkrFestival


Ukrainian Customs, Values, History and Traditions

But we all know that the Capital Ukrainian Festival will be so much more than a fabulous party (Zabava), lively markets, and a courtyard full of mouth-watering Ukrainian cuisine! The Festival will provide a forum to preserve and promote shared cultural values and traditions.  It provides unique opportunities for immediate and long term community cultural development.  The Capital Ukrainian Festival is a building block for the Ukrainian community because it promotes ethnic understanding within Ottawa and beyond.  Doing so preserves and celebrates Ukrainian customs, values, traditions, history and culture.  Having a Ukrainian festival in Ottawa is of great importance not only because it will promote Ukrainian culture in Canada, but also because it will help internationally recognize Ukraine to be a modern, peace-loving, multicultural, tolerant and democratic country. 


Transparency and Accountability

The Capital Ukrainian Festival is organized by the Ukrainian Canadian Congress (UCC), a not-for-profit organization that brings together, under one umbrella, all the local Ukrainian Canadian organizations in Ottawa.  It is governed by Bylaws and a Constitution.   An annual, independent audit is performed annually to ensure that funds are managed appropriately and according to accounting rules and regulations.  Charitable Tax Receipts will be issued upon request.  Please submit proof of your donation to capitalukrainianfestival@gmail.com in order to receive a charitable tax receipt from the Ukrainian Canadian Congress.


Event Days

Pub Night - Friday, July 24,2015 8:30pm- 1:00am

19 and over.  ID will be checked at the door. $20.00 cover.

(1000 Byron Ave.)


Saturday, July 25, 2015 11am-11pm

Sunday, July 26,201511am-6 pm

(952 Green Valley Crescent)

Sat & Sun - Free, fun, family entertainment

story:
A Comedy About a Drama About a Tragedy

Squeaky Bicycle is back with another innovative, thought-provoking, and gutsy production: the world premiere of resident playwright Dylan Lamb's dark comedy Ten Ways On A Gun!

Squeaky Bicycle has been working with Lamb for over a year to develop this new piece that tackles topics at the forefront of social discussion with care and humor. Through our Reading Lab and subsequent workshopping of the piece, it’s only gotten better and braver.


So, What is This Play, Anyway?

Tommy bought a gun. It didn’t end well. 

Jessica devised a play about it. It didn’t end very well, either. 

Ten Ways on a Gun is Tommy’s story, Jessica’s story, and how each changes the other. It’s an exploration of many things - Love, control, capitalism, existential crises, loneliness, art, mental illness, the pressures of life as a young adult in New York. Most of all, though, it’s an exploration of how American gun culture has profoundly affected each of these concepts. Dylan Lamb has written a heartfelt, insightful, and in many ways universal story, told through the humorous lens that makes his work truly special. The result is a comedy about a drama about a tragedy that will leave you laughing, feeling, and thinking.

Every day, the conversation about gun control becomes more urgent. As our nation grapples with the realities of our existing gun culture, as the statistics become more and more alarming, we feel compelled to take part in the conversation the best way we know how. This production is how we give a human face to those statistics, and to encourage our society to approach the issue in a different way. 

With Ten Ways on a Gun, we add our voices to the millions across the country asking for change, and we hope you’ll help make our voices heard with a tax-deductible donation.



Photo Credit: TangySweet Photography

Early Praise for Ten Ways on a Gun

 “Ten Ways on a Gun deftly deals with our cultural baggage regarding guns, gun ownership and the tools we use to feel in control of our lives.” 

– charged.fm

“The ensemble of the piece had ease with the author’s words. Lamb himself plays Tommy Freely, and his last scene will send chills down your spine. The rest of the cast was dynamic…The set design by Kathryn Lieber gave the show its heart, and director Kathryn McConell did a great job exposing its soul. But at the end, this is Dylan Lamb’s show, and it will be a name I remember.” 

– Nelson Diaz-Marcano, Manhattan with a Twist

“The show works as a commentary on both the versatility and power of theatrical storytelling: here that power and versatility is turned on American obsession with guns.” 

– Artem Yatsunov, theasy.com

“A show with a great mixture of humor, baudiness, and none of the “Afterschool Special” preachiness so common with plays that deal with controversial subject matter.” 

– Monica Trombley, Woman Around Town

“The ensemble gels well together – uniformly sharp, comically dark, and at times outrageous, especially during blitzkrieg choreography.” 

– Sarah Matusek, New York Theatre Review

“Dylan Lamb has a knack for comedic writing. It's where he's at his finest.” 

– Theater in the Now

“Squeaky Bicycle’s collective creativity demonstrates something undeniably bold and ambitious.” 

– Sarah Matusek, New York Theatre Review

“Ten Ways on a Gun tackles the timely subject of this country’s relationship with guns and violence, placing us in the heart of the constant debate.” 

– Inna Tsyrlin, StageBuddy

“A testament to society’s ability to momentarily cede its fixation on the inconsequential and turn a studious eye on a sensitive, and highly divisive, subject matter.” 

– Willie Keaton, My Entertainment World






Squeaky Bike & Dylan Lamb: 

Reunited and it Feels So Good

The 2013 production of Alligator Summer proved that Squeaky Bicycle and Dylan Lamb are a theatrical dream team. But don’t take our word for it, check out what the critics had to say:

“Dylan Lamb can write. From the first lines, you're struck by the very unique way his characters talk, and how distinctive each of them are. In this talent, I don't think comparisons to the Coen Brothers and Christopher Durang are out of place. ... I will certainly be on the lookout for more from Lamb and Squeaky Bicycle Productions.” 
-Matt Roberson, nytheatre.com

“It’s a rare amalgam of first rate work from all artists involved. … Dylan Lamb is a playwright of extraordinary talent, and will undoubtedly be widely recognized in time. He never dwells on a moment, never skims over it; each dramatic element is given the weight it needs to balance the whole. … We’d like to see more from Lamb as soon as possible.” 
-Steve Capra

“Lamb’s words are in turn delicious and hilarious; he crafts an astute play with numerous moments of poignancy and hilarity. I was completely impressed by the caliber of the performances, the production, and the script.” 

- Joseph Samuel Wright, Theatre Is Easy

I was completely blown away by both the show and the performers. One of the best shows I have seen in years." 

- New York Times reader review

"If you really like some content to chew on, this play raises issues ripe for serious, long discussions afterward." 
- TheaterMania reader review

You Know We’re Good For It

We think the message of this play needs to be heard and we’re doing as so much to make that happen. True to form, Squeaky Bicycle Productions is doing some new and exciting things; new things like a big hip downtown location (Theater for the New City) with our biggest audience capacity to date, our largest cast, and a massive new marketing effort to cast a wider net than ever before. Plus, with the performances of 10 incredible actors and the work of passionate designers and creative personnel, Ten Ways on a Gun is already the biggest production in Squeaky Bicycle history!

The quality is easy to see long before you get to the theater: Playwright Dylan Lamb is a recipient of the Chair’s Award of Excellence in Dramatic Writing at NYU and a current member of Fresh Ground Pepper’s PlayGround PlayGroup. He and/or his work have previously been seen at the Edinburgh Fringe, Minnesota Fringe, 45 Bleecker Street, SoHo Rep Walkerspace, The Cherry Pit, EST/Youngblood, The Tank, The Gene Frankel Theater, and Horse Trade Theater. With Ten Ways on a Gun, he's delivering an outstanding play years in the making. It's been workshopped in Fresh Ground Pepper’s PlayGround and Squeaky Bicycle’s own annual Reading Lab Series - the latter of which has been the starting place for five years of successful productions.

Now in its 5th season, Squeaky Bicycle has achieved a reputation for bringing you rich, intelligent plays in high-quality productions. Find us at www.squeakybicycleproductions.com.  


What we Need and What You Get

The money we raise through our campaign will take care of a portion of the production costs associated with presenting Ten Ways on a Gun including:

  • Theater rental

  • Publicity and PR

  • Printing of programs and postcards

  • Prop and set materials

  • Actor and designer stipends

  • Insurance

  • Rehearsal space rental

In exchange, you get to be part of an incredible play, and part of the greater conversation about the consequences of our existing gun culture. This is our attempt to do our part, but we can’t do it without you!

Everything raised will go directly to production costs for Ten Ways on a Gun




You can find even more details about Ten Ways on A Gun at www.squeakybicycleproductions.com and http://www.facebook.com/squeakybicycle

Squeaky Bicycle Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Squeaky Bicycle Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

You can find even more details about Ten Ways on A Gun at www.squeakybicycleproductions.com and http://www.facebook.com/squeakybicycle
Squeaky Bicycle Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Squeaky Bicycle Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Whats the buzz?

The Acadiana Repertory is thrilled to announce the fall production that closes out our 2012 Season.

 In December, we will present our inagural holiday presentation of CAROL. Each year, CAROL will be a fresh, commissioned world premiere adaptation of Dickens’ A CHRISTMAS CAROL. Massachusetts playwright Ben Jolivet’s CAROL: A BROKEN CHAIN will be our 2012 piece. Ben’s work has been seen throughout the Northeast and he was a 2012 participant in the Stony Brook Summer Playwright's Conference.

We Need You!!!

We want to make sure both of this production gets the best chance at being awesome...for you. We have had such a great season and we cant think of a better way to end it with. But to make sure that it is amazing, we need a little leg up from our awesome audience and supporters. 

The Impact

Your contribution, no matter how big or small is going to help us focus on crafting two lovely shows that you will want to be a part of. And it will make you feel like you had a hand in our process. We have to build a set, print awesome posters and programs, make sure our playwright is taken care of and make sure our friends that are letting us use their space get what they need. As you can see, there are MANY ways that your donation will be used. And every little bit makes a huge impact, trust us. 

What if we dont reach our goal?

Its flexible funding! So what is donated goes to the project! Its a great deal for everyone involved.

Other Ways You Can Help

Dont feel like you can give a donation of treasure? Thats ok too! Time and talent rock as well.  Maybe you have a talent for building things..let us know. Maybe you want to find ways to help us backstage..let us know! Just get in touch with us to see how you can help. Or just share this campaign. 

Social media is a powerful thing! Help spread the word on facebook and twitter. Email your friends and family. Or even email us and tell us you want to get involved!

And of course BUY TICKETS!

 

Basically...we want to give you the best fall of theatre possible. So that we can give you the best 2013 of theatre possible. We just need a little help from our friends:)

story:
Why We’re Here

Out of more than 70 applicants, Caborca has been selected to present the new bilingual version of our play Zoetrope: Part 1 as part of Encuentro 2014, the largest national festival of Latino theatre in more than two decades, and we could not be more excited! Encuentro will take place at the famous Los Angeles Theater Center from October 12th to November 10th, during which we will perform the play 15 times. This production marks two major firsts for Caborca: our first time traveling with our work, and the first time either part of Zoetrope will receive more than 2 showings. It is a huge moment for the company!

But…

Traveling with a show is not cheap. Encuentro is flying us, housing us, feeding us, and paying a fee that covers some of our production costs, but the rest of our costs – primarily our artist salaries – are up to us. All members of the company (10 people) are taking a month off from work to travel to LA, and our designers are all coming for a week. While we are there, not only will we be performing Zoetrope: Part 1, but we will also be working on our days off with other festival participants to devise new performances to be presented at the end, engaging fully in Encuentro as guest artists. In order to make all of this possible, we need to raise $15,000.

And that’s where you come in. For those who saw the workshops of either part of Zoetrope at Pregones, we think you’d agree it is big step forward for Caborca, bringing together many of the elements we’ve been working with and refining for years. For those who didn’t but know our work, Zoetrope is a play of which we’re enormously proud and we hope to show it to you soon so you’ll see why. Traveling to LA for Encuentro will expose this play to a whole new audience as well as give it the momentum it needs to come back home with a New York production in the works. And then…who knows, Puerto Rico? Arkansas? Cartegena? 

Por qué estamos aquí...

De entre más de 70 solicitudes, Caborca ha sido seleccionada para presentar la nueva versión bilingue de Zoetrope: Part 1 como parte de Encuentro 2014, el festival de teatro latino más grande en los Estados Unidos en más de dos décadas, y no podríamos estar más contentos. Encuentro tomará lugar en el prestigioso Los Angeles Theater Center desde el 12 de octubre al 10 de noviembre, durante cuyo tiempo presentaremos la pieza 15 veces. Esta producción marca dos comienzos para Caborca: la primera vez que viajamos con nuestro trabajo, y la primera vez que Zoetrope tendrá más de dos funciones. Es un gran momento para la compañía! 

Pero... 

Viajar con una obra no es barato. Encuentro nos provee los pasajes de avión, la estadía y algunos de los costos de producción, pero el resto de los gastos– mayormente, la paga a los artistas, 14 en total–  nos toca a nosotros recaudar. Todos los miembros de la compañía se están tomando un mes libre de su trabajo para poder viajar a L.A., mas los diseñadores quienes viajarán por una semana. Durante nuestra estadía, no solo estaremos  presentando Zoetrope: Part 1, sino que también estaremos trabajando en nuestros días libres con miembros de otras compañías, desarrollando nuevas piezas para presentarse al final de Encuentro, compartiendo prácticas y participando a tiempo completo en el festival. A fin de hacer todo esto posible, necesitamos recaudar 15,000. 

¡Aquí es donde usted hace su entrada! Para aquellos que vieron las presentaciones de Zoetrope en Pregones, creemos que estarían de acuerdo en que es un gran paso para Caborca, ya que combinamos elementos que llevamos explorando y refinando por años. Para aquellos que se la perdieron, Zoetrope es una obra de la cual estamos enormemente orgullosos, y esperamos que la puedan ver pronto para que vean de lo que hablamos. Viajar a Los Angeles para Encuentro expondrá la obra a todo un nuevo público a la vez que le dará el momentum necesario para regresar a su hogar en Nueva York. Y después... ¿quién sabe? ¿Puerto Rico? ¿Arkansas? ¿Cartagena? 


Who We Are

Caborca is a New York based experimental theatre company working in two languages and multiple boroughs. We include (in occasionally overlapping combinations) a playwright/director, designer, a handful of actors, and two stage managers. Over 15 years, we have amassed members from the University of Puerto Rico, Columbia University, and beyond, though we were officially founded as a company in 2009. Our previous works include Barceloneta, de noche and FLORIDITA, my Love, both performed at IATI and LATEA Theatres, El correo de la noche, our international collaboration with Colombian director Eloisa Jaramillo, performed at IRT Theatre, and 2012’s immersive warehouse production of Open up, Hadrian, written by our Artistic Director, Javier Antonio González, and directed by Meiyin Wang at Magic Futurebox, which Time Out gave four stars and called “opulent” and “delightful.” Since Hadrian, we have been hard at work on various projects, including a reading series of our play THE FUTURE OF BOOKS, an original writers' workshop, and most importantly, two fully produced showings as part of the Artist Space at Pregones residency of Zoetrope: Parts 1 and 2, our next original play written and directed by González. The two years since Hadrian have also brought us five wonderful new members (except for Laura who’s ok). Caborca’s aesthetic influences and collaborators run the gamut between Latin American, Asian, European, and New York experimental traditions.

Caborca is: Michael Barringer, Brooke Bell, Laura Butler Rivera, Yaremis Félix, Javier Antonio González, Erin Koster, Jian Jung, Tania Molina, Pedro Leopoldo Sánchez-Tormes, Veraalba Santa, David Skeist, and Marcos Toledo.

What You Get

  • A multitude of creative and less creative perks including company art projects (an original zoetrope, anyone?), swag, and a very exclusive invitation. You might also get some postcards and pictures and all the pretty things.
  • An enormous amount of gratitude.
  • But perhaps more than all of that, you will have the knowledge that you are helping a group of artists who have been working extremely hard for years realize one of their dreams. You will also be helping Caborca take a major part in the most significant artistic interchange among members of the US Latino Theatre community in decades.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word like lice in a kindergarten:
  • Post and repost (and compost if you’re into that kind of thing)
  • Tweet
  • Shout about us from the hills (or at least the heights: Washington, Crown, Brooklyn, whatever)
  • Know anyone in LA? We don’t. Make a match and we’ll send you pictures from our honeymoon.
  • Rack your brain and your contact list for anyone who might want to support independent, experimental theatre at a Latino festival (remember Aunt Rita who married that Mexican circus performer in the 70’s)?
  • Wear a Caborca T-Shirt. That you can buy. With your money. Email us to find out how (caborca.theatre@gmail.com).

About the Play

Zoetrope tells the story of an underdog military postal officer with a dream. Until he dies. Then it tells the story of his ex-wife, her sister, his lover, her friend, his son, the playwright René Marqués, and el Grito de Lares.

That's the tantalizing blurb for the uninitiated. Here's a little more of a description: Inés and Francisca (don't call her Panchi) teach English in Lares, their small town in the mountains of Puerto Rico. Together with their best friend Celeste, they talk about the island's existential quagmire. A lot. Inés wears dresses. Francisca wears pants. Some of them fall in love. In New York, time is running out on Inés's husband, Severino, who is dying in the arms of another woman. In Lares, time seems to stand still even as the women plan for a revolution.

This production of Zoetrope: Part 1 will include at least several supertitled bilingual performances with the scenes that take place in Lares in Spanish and those in New York, in English.

Zoetrope: Parts 1 and 2 were developed at Pregones Theater as part of Artist Space at Pregones.

That’s our pitch. We love you all. Please help us if you can. Truly any amount helps. Like, seriously any. Seriously.

Besos y abrazos,

Caborca (Javier, Yaremis, Erin, Marcos, Brooke, Veraalba, Tania, Mikey, Laura, David, Pedro, Jian)

story:
Little Stitches 

by Isley Lynn, Karis E Halsall, Raul Quiros Molina & Bahar Brunton

**** The Evening Standard          **** The Independent

**** The Times                                 **** Theupcoming 

**** The Arts Desk

My name is Melissa Dean, I'm the Artistic Director of BAREtruth Theatre Company. 6 months ago, myself and co producer/writer Raul Quiros Molina, did a whole lot of thinking and research into what would be our next production. It was during this time that Bristol student Fahma Mohammed met Michael Gove to tell him of the number of girls affected by Female Genital Mutilation in the UK. 

Since then, we have spent the last 6 months interviewing survivors, nurses, teachers and others with a personal story to tell on their experience of FGM.

"An estimated 137,000 women are living with the effects of Female Genital Mutilation in the UK. "

The more we learnt and understood about FGM and the torture it puts women through; having their genitalia cut/removed for tradition, seen as a right of way into womanhood, the more we knew this was an issue that needed  to be voiced. I many circumstances females aged between 0 and 15 years are forced against their will to have the procedure, being held down by several women and are cut without anaesthetic.

It is so vital that we stop turning a blind eye to this procedure that is affecting not only our UK based girls but millions of women worldwide.

Your Contribution 

We have worked incredibly hard for on this, through research, interviews and now rehearsals, receiving no funding.  Your contribution whatever the amount, will help the show to move forward.

It will pay for:

Set/Props/Costume £ 1000

Venue Hire £2,600

Insurance £259

Print £200

Rehearsal space £600

Along with lighting equipment and minute salaries

We are the only theatre company currently using theatre to talk about FGM and we have some of the finest talent on board from cast to crew.

The Show 

Little Stitches will open at Theatre 503 on August 21-27 before moving on to the Arcola Tent from 29-30 August, finishing at the Gate Theatre on 10 Sept.
We plan to do a UK tour from 2015 for schools, depending on how well the show is received in this current tour.
There will be several library readings in the following libraries to reach out to wider communities:
Sept 1 Dagenham Library 
Sept 2 Hackney Central Library
Sept 3 Leyton Library
Sept 4 North Chingford Library
Sept 5 Walthamstow Library
Oct 6 Ealing Road Library
Oct 7 Streatham Tate Library

What is FGM?

There are 4 types of FGM.

Type 1 is the partial or total removal of the clitoris.

Tye 2 is partial or total removal of the clitoris and labia minora (the 'lips' surrounding the vagina)

Type 3 is the cutting and sewing of the outer labia with or without removal of the clitoris or inner labia.

Type 4 are all othr procedures to the female genitalia for non medical purposes ie piercing, stretching, pricking, scraping.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if you're not able to contribute to the project. Please do come and watch the shows if you can and spread the word. It's so imporant we raise as much awareness as possible and theatre can be a tactful way of bringing to light those much needed conversations.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and do follow us on twitter or Facebook to keep updated with what we're doing.

With Warm Thanks,

Melissa Dean

x

story:
Limelight Theatre is a young people's theatre group in Taunton, Somerset.

Limelight was started by myself; Charlie Hamilton, and my partner; Jonny Leach. Over the last three years we have grown from a group of 9 children between 7 and 11 years old to a group of over 60 children between 4 and 14 years old. In the last 2 years we have put on 12 shows all with fantastic audience response! 
However, the one thing we really need to make our performances better is microphones! The children we work with are incredibly talented and truly amazing performers but it is not always easy for them to project enough to be heard at the back of a large audience. We have wanted microphones since the word go but good mics are expensive and we are a fairly small company without the extra money to spend on them. 
If we could by one or two floor microphones to pick up general group vocals and spoken lines and two or three standing microphones for soloists this would make such a difference! 
We are still searching for the best deals but so far we have a quote of £138 for quality floor mics and £125 for standing mics. This is what all of our funding will go towards. 
If you are unsure whether we are worth funding please take a look at our website and facebook page - 
http://www.limelight-theatre.wild-reality.net/
https://www.facebook.com/LimelightTheatreCo
If you are unable to fund us but can offer us any advice about which microphones or companies to go for please get in touch.
Also, if you think we are worth funding please let other people know so we can try to reach/ exceed our target!!

Over the last three years we have grown from a group of 9 children between 7 and 11 years old to a group of over 60 children between 4 and 14 years old. In the last 2 years we have put on 12 shows all with fantastic audience response! However, the one thing we really need to make our performances better is microphones! The children we work with are incredibly talented and truly amazing performers but it is not always easy for them to project enough to be heard at the back of a large audience. We have wanted microphones since the word go but good mics are expensive and we are a fairly small company without the extra money to spend on them. If we could by one or two floor microphones to pick up general group vocals and spoken lines and two or three standing microphones for soloists this would make such a difference! We are still searching for the best deals but so far we have a quote of £138 for quality floor mics and £125 for standing mics. This is what all of our funding will go towards. If you are unsure whether we are worth funding please take a look at our website and facebook page - 
http://www.limelight-theatre.wild-reality.net/

https://www.facebook.com/LimelightTheatreCo
If you are unable to fund us but can offer us any advice about which microphones or companies to go for please get in touch.Also, if you think we are worth funding please let other people know so we can try to reach/ exceed our target!!

story:
Thank you so very much to everyone who has donated!  Great news - as of January 2014, we are almost halfway to our goal. 

Our fundraising campaign will continues directly through our website: www.apsisrequiem.com  

Please stay tuned for exciting news as we continue this journey forward together!  

WHAT IS APSIS REQUIEM?

Apsis Requiem is an immersive pop opera that explores the journey of grief and healing in community. Parts opera, musical theater, film, and chant, it draws the audience into a fantasy world as it cycles through the five basic stages of grief. Its central component is a multi-genre score, which weaves classical and pop music into a sweeping cinematic landscape.  


Inspired by the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, our team recognized the numbing effects of individual, collective and environmental tragedy. We envisioned a creative space where all could gather and begin to process pain. Drawing influence from traditional ceremonies of grief, we set out to create an experience in community healing - a Requiem for the living.  

ALBUM RECORDING & CONCERT

This campaign will fund a FULL ALBUM RECORDING of Apsis Requiem, as well as a live orchestral CONCERT STAGING in Los Angeles in Fall 2014.  The completed concept album will be the basis for the full theatrical production. 

THE SCORE

Apsis Requiem re-imagines the traditional Requiem as an operatic blend of chamber pop, beat-driven synths, and dramatic orchestral explosions.  The piece is written for live orchestra, chorus/ensemble, and featured soloists - as well as a liberal arsenal of percussion and production effects.   

Dialogue and lyrics merge contemporary English with the traditional Latin Requiem text and several additional languages. Its raw, intimate moments allow for tender pop narrative, while extravagant choral escalations provide the perfect setting to re-interpret age-old texts.  All of this while weaving moments of collective breath and mantra into a fluid soundscape of accessible and heart-opening melodies.  

THE STORY

A WRITER isolates himself in his studio as he struggles to deal with profound loss.  He escapes into a dark fantasy world, where his heroine ROSETTE is swept into an adventure based on the FIVE STAGES OF GRIEF.  The writer's difficult journey is revealed through intermittent film vignettes, mirrored in the mystical tale he creates. 

Rosette arrives in the bleak land of DENIAL, where the locals have been enslaved by EIDOLON, a chilling tyrant whose robot minions patrol the kingdom. 

The abduction of a child triggers dark memories from Rosette's past, and her ANGER is ignited. An epic battle ensues as she sparks the locals to revolt against their oppressive restraints.  

Rosette pursues the child's captors through the forest toward Eidolon's lair.  Along the way, she is entranced by the SACCHARINE WITCH, a shadowy outcast who craves control of the forest.  She struggles to continue as she fumbles through the bewitching haze of BARGAINING.

Rosette arrives at Eidolon's lair and is thrown into the cold dungeon of DEPRESSION. Here she encounters the archangel MYCHAL, whose power has been enchained and manipulated by Eidolon in this place of despair, hopelessness and regret.  

Rosette finally chooses to face her own traumatic past as she leads us into the cosmic space of ACCEPTANCE.  Along the way, the writer experiences his own catharsis, and we finally understand his connection to this imagined reality.  

The audience is invited to participate through movement, breath and chant.  We will ALL have the opportunity to contribute to this experience in collective healing.  

LISTEN

Check out highlights from our original demos here:


HOW YOUR TAX-DEDUCTIBLE DONATION HELPS

Recording costs:

  • Studio space and equipment rental
  • Talent - rehearsals and recording
  • Engineering, production, orchestration and copyist costs
  • Record distribution

Concert event costs:

  • Space and Facility rental
  • Talent - rehearsals and performance
  • Equipment rental including sound and lighting
  • Marketing - getting the word out!

Any additional funds will help us launch this piece into full production! 

THANK YOU!!!

Many, many thanks to the countless artists and volunteers who have given their time, talents and energy toward making this vision a reality.  Now, we gratefully welcome your help!

story:
La Cie Gazaille troisième est en pleine campagne de financement pour la production de la pièce Rabbit de Nina Raine. 

La pièce qui raconte un huis clos dans un bar entre cinq amis de différents horizons sera joué directement accoudés au comptoir-bar du Théâtre La Licorne. De cette façon Gazaille troisième privilégie un rapport de diffusion intime avec les spectateurs. Ceux-ci se retrouvant donc à passer la soirée, dans le même bar que les personnages. 


Voici le synopsis de Rabbit;

Épuisée des longues heures qu’elle passe au chevet de son père mourant, Bella fête son 29e anniversaire dans un bar de la ville. Elle a décidé que tous ses amis se rencontreraient. Pour l’occasion, elle réunit donc Richard, son ex-copain, Emilie, Sandy et Tom, un ancien amant croisé par hasard. Tous apprennent à connaître les secrets des uns au rythme de l’alcool qui les enivre. Rapidement, quelque chose les scindent. La confrontation s’envenime, le bar devient leur champs de bataille, des vérités sont dites jusqu’à ce que Bella révèle l’état de santé de son père qu’elle leur avait jusque-là caché.

story:
Help support the creation of Waterline 

Michaëla St-Pierre, is a Fourth-year student at Ryerson University's Performance Dance Program. Prior to living in Toront she was born and raised in Whitehorse, Yukon. 

Choreographer, Dancer, Artist.

As the culmination of her creative projects during her four years at Ryerson University, Micha is creating a 20 min theatre-dance, multimedia work to be presented at Ryerson's festival New Voices on April 4th, 2017. The piece is a comical yet touching exploration of human expression and the purpose of art. 

All the performers and production team are generously volunteering their time to make this project happen. 

Please help us cover any additional costs this project might bring such as poster printing, costuming, and purchasing content of the video creation. 

We are deeply appreciative of any shape or size of contribution.

story:
A Summer Stocking Filler

Having had a successful run of Twelfth Night in Soho in the Spring we are now looking ahead to prepare for a challenging AW16-17 season that will stretch the company in every direction. We have the potential to create something extraordinary, and without divulging all of our secrets now, we wish to begin our campaign to put the wheels in motion now to give us a fighting chance of achieving something magnificent.


This fund is the first stage of our campaign to create two bold AW16-17 London productions that are financially secure with a healthy publicity campaign and artistic freedom.

£3000 will cover day-to-day costs and the early development phase.


The Impact

Without Arts Council funding your help is invaluable to a company such as Scena Mundi. Our last fund raised £5,000 in 2015 and enabled the company to survive. We have big hopes for our potential to gain sponsorship and Arts Council funding with the AW16-17 season, yet until that becomes a reality we must continue to build our own security and seek the help of generous others.


Other Ways You Can Help

TALK ABOUT US: word of mouth is a wonderful thing and the more you chat about us and share your experiences of seeing us the better!

IDEAS: do you know of a interesting VENUE or have a great INDUSTRY CONTACT? Don't hold back! Email info@scenamundi.co.uk 

SPONSORSHIP: if you know of a company or individual who may be interested in sponsoring Scena Mundi please do not hesitate to get in touch. We will be able to send a sponsorship pack with detailed information on Scena Mundi, our goal and what we can offer.


PRIVATE HIRE: hire Scena Mundi to -

- put on a show, such as our 4-man Twelfth Night, for your event.

- deliver a poetry recital or reading.

- host a corporate event catered to your needs that could include presentation skills and communication skills work.

story:
I am Angeli Primlani, the Artistic Director of Accidental Shakespeare Theater Company. We wish to raise the money for our upcoming season. In 2016, we will spend a little time in the turn of the 20th century.

Our theme is Fidelity and Love and both of our shows show people reckoning with conflicts around keeping promises and following their hearts.

February - Boston Marriage, by David Mamet, directed by Angeli Primlani

Our company has a passion for language-based plays that the western classical canon just cannot contain. So this year, I am directing Boston Marriage, a relatively underperformed David Mamet play about a 19th century Lesbian couple and how they struggle with economic security, infidelity, the threat of prison, and their incredibly flawed natures.

Anna and Claire have been lovers for years, when Anna becomes the mistress of a wealthy man in order to support them both. But of course it is nowhere near that simple. What does fidelity mean when one's romantic partnership can barely be imagined as real? Does money distort women's sexual and personal integrity? Is chintz a sign of love or a form of psychological torture? Must we always hurt the ones we love? And what about ... the maid?

This is our first foray as a company into performing a play by a living playwright, but it won't be the last. We're excited about applying our classical skill-set to a contemporary play.

September - Love's Labour's Lost, by William Shakespeare, directed by Sherry Legare

“They lived and laughed and loved and left.” – James Joyce, Finnegans Wake

Ferdinand, the King of Navarre and his three noble companions, the lords Berowne, Dumaine, and Longaville, are on a bit of a spiritual bender. They swear to devote themselves to study and prayer and avoid the tempting company of women. This goes as well as you might expect. Once the Princess of France and her ladies arrive, the men must decide whether or not to stay faithful to their vows. Our show places this comedy in 1914, just as the shadow of World War I falls.

How Your Support will Help Us:

We need $3000 for Boston Marriage and are looking to raise another $3500 for remainder of  the 2016 season.  The total we are looking to raise for the season is $6500.  If we reach our goal we will be well on our way to our goal for the season.

 We need the money to pay for the performance rights for Boston Marriage, publicity for both shows, cast and crew stipends, and the cost of renting the space, the beautiful 19th century Coach House in Edgewater's Berger Park, 6205 N. Sheridan Road.
