Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t contribute monetarily, here are some ways you can help out:



Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or your social media of choice!


Hand out the little business cards we have with our Indiegogo link!

Comment, like, and share content on our page. With lots of activity comes more exposure in the Indiegogo community!

Simple word of mouth can never go wrong!

Come see the shows! We'd love to see your smiling face (or scowling face, but we'll leave that up to you!)



Thank you in advance for your investment of love and support through this process! You guys are the best!

story:
About EverScape

In the play, an online world of epic fantasy battles helps four gamers escape their bleak realities. But when EverScape offers them a chance to win jobs as game developers, lines get crossed between what's more real: the game or their lives? Epic fight scenes ensue, love blossoms among strangers, avatars start to influence day-to-day behavior and winning quickly becomes the only solution.

From The Director

Hi there, I'm Ashley Gunsteens, the director of EverScape. Thank you for visiting our page! If you've watched our video, you've gotten just a peek into how awesome this project is. When Allan's script first landed on my (metaphorical) director's desk, I was truly skeptical. Would a play about an online, role-playing video game speak to all audiences?

But what I read was a play that is somehow both funny and poignant, fantastical and grounded. It deals with the realities of addiction and escapism, very real issues within my generation today, but is filled with so many action-packed fight scenes and hilarious(ly real) characters that speak to you whether you are an avid WoW player or have never even touched an Xbox. One of the first comments after the New York reading of the show was from an actor who said, "he didn't think he'd ever laughed so hard at just a reading of a play." The show is fun. It is exciting and funny and troubling and redeeming. How often do you find new work that is all of those things?

I submitted this play to the NY Fringe Festival because I believe in the script, and I am passionate about creating a jaw-dropping theatrical experience, from the stylized dance and fight choreography, to the lighting, sound, weaponry and amazing cast that was needed to complement this story. I've assembled a team of young NYC creatives who are being paid peanuts (if at all) to work on this project. We are doing this because we believe in the show, and in each other, and we hope you will join us in supporting our production by donating whatever you can.

What We Need & What You Get

$8000 sounds like a lot, so where does that money go? It adds up surprisingly fast when we have to pay for festival fees, rehearsal space, insurance, travel stipends and cover marketing costs in addition to the usual props, sets and costumes you expect to see onstage! In an effort to make our project entirely transparent, below is our no-frills budget in its entirety:

*Any money donated beyond our minimum budget will be split amongst the actors, designers and rest of creative team, many of whom are working for free.

All of our exclusive donator perks are listed on the right-hand side of this page and are yours for the taking! Click on the perk to claim it, or simply donate using the link at the top of the page if you don't wish to receive any perks.

Help Out Any Way You Can!

Sometimes you just can't afford to donate financially. Believe me, we get it (we're starving artists too you know). But there are still ways you can help the EverScape team!

  • Share this campaign with friends, family and coworkers who might be interested in donating, or share it on your social media for everyone to see! (There are a whole bunch of social media share buttons at the top left of this page to make that easy!)
  • You can also share links to our social media and website (and follow along with us this summer):
  • Our website is www.EverScapeThePlay.com (updates, bios, show info and links to FringeNYC ticket sales are all here!)
  • Find us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram @EverscapeNYC

Thank you for your support of a show and an art form that is important. And welcome to the EverScape family, we're glad you're here!

story:
Our journey to Auschwitz is a pilgrimage that reverberates with story, foremost that of bringing the hero and writer Etty Hillesum's words to life where her life was taken, and ending in Belgium, where we have been invited to perform at the International Etty Hillesum Congress, celebrating the 100th anniversary of her birth this January. 

By its nature, this story is bigger, certainly bigger than us, others having returned her words at Auschwitz as well as others surely to follow, our own performances of Etty, The Thinking Heart, hopefully inspiring still others to find new ways to tell her story, whether in film, dance, music or words. And what words!—because to read and get to know Etty is to have a humanistic encounter of life-changing proportions. She is an avatar of all that it means to be and remain human under the most corrosive and oppressive circumstances.

And there are several stories here, stories within stories: first of all, of course, Etty’s and the life of her voice over and through time and space, crossing national borders, crossing and re-crossing continents and oceans, the Atlantic and Pacific, crossing the borders of language (her journal and letters are read from her native Netherlands to Japan); and it is the story of her voice through and over the Nazi juggernaut; it is the story too of the mystery of time and space, how it happens she lived and wrote her Holocaust journey, ending with her death in the camps at age 29, and we get to experience it in the bosom of safe communities, rather than vice versa, that is, our perishing in the concentration camp and Etty living to tell about it. We might ask, how is this possible. We swim in the miracle of language like the air that sustains us. Returning her voice to Auschwitz is also the story of the mystery of language itself, how a voice might travel through a line of prose or poetry, a life be lived again in sound and light, in words or in film, crossing that other border between life as we know it and death, that seeming impermeable border between the world and spirit.

So we make a pilgrimage to breathe Etty Hillesum’s words where her life was taken—at Auschwitz. Oswiecim in Polish. Auschwitz is German. It leaves an aftertaste I don’t want in my mouth. Better the Poles take back the name. Oswiecim, yes, even though some Poles were complicit. Complicit. That word, too, leaves an unwanted aftertaste. It is hard to get the taste of these words out of the mouth, because we know them, they are part of us.

Then there is this woman, Etty Hillesum—words flow from her. They flow out, first like a little brook, then a stream. She can’t stop them. We don’t know where they come from. They become a river, a river of words, a river of freshness, and they flow into her notebooks and letters, even from inside that other word, Auschwitz. Etty’s words burst the dam of Auschwitz, and now they flow out of us, and we shudder as they wash us, at the warmth and light they leave in our mouth, in our heart.

So this is a story—brook, stream, river into story. We will go there, our small ensemble, to speak her words, and with our musician swell them in the strains of the cello. It will be winter in Auschwitz, and we will bring Etty’s voice there to wash the snow.                             

Copyright © 2013 Martin Steingesser

Short Summary

Pilgrimage to the Heart (http://www.pilgrimagetotheheart.org) combines theater, dialogue, a book and visual art to tell the story of a woman who moves through romantic love to a deeper, more inclusive one, refusing to allow her love of life to be diminished by the oppression to which she is subjected during the Holocaust, 1942-43. 

The Pilgrimage to the Heart Project is an expansion of an original, proven ensemble performance work (and more recently a book) that has toured throughout Maine to over 40 diverse venues, including high schools, libraries, colleges, public theaters, churches, temples, museums, the Maine Holocaust and Human Right Center and the Maine State Prison.

The performance work and book are called The Thinking Heart: the Life and Loves of Etty Hillesum, and the ensemble is comprised of two actors and a cellist who perform an hour of poetry and music. The inspiration for the work originated from the extraordinary journals and letters of Etty Hillesum, a young Jewish woman who kept a journal during the Nazi occupation of Holland and was killed at Auschwitz. Etty Hillesum’s journal and correspondence, published in An Interrupted Life and Letters from Westerbork, was adapted into a sequence of 48 poems and arranged for performance by Martin Steingesser in collaboration with another actor, Judy Tierney, and a cellist, Robin Jellis. The ensemble is committed to bringing Etty’s words and exemplary life to audiences for an enriching and thought provoking experience, best summed up by Edward van Voolen, Chairman of the Etty Hillesum Foundation, “Etty confronts us all with what it means to be and remain human under the most extreme circumstances. That is a form of resistance no oppressor can withstand. Not then, and not now.”

The performance work creates a communal experience of this woman’s vision, wisdom and humanity and an opportunity for post performance exploration and dialogue with  audiences about what her example and courage mean to each of us in our lives now. Keeping alive the story of a single, courageous woman, not famous or in a position of power, provides a model for all of us, and an opportunity to be moved to small actions in our daily life, which have the power of rippling out into the greater life around us. Hence, our project title: pilgrimage, which means “the course of life on Earth” for each person, and heart, symbol for courage, love, compassion.

Birth and Death form a continuum, the way or path we call Life. We are all travelers. Pilgrimage is for all who long and search for a way to the heart.

Copyright © 2013 Martin Steingesser & Judy Tierney
story_txt:
Our journey to Auschwitz is a pilgrimage that reverberates with story, foremost that of
bringing the hero and writer Etty Hillesum's words to life where her life was taken, and ending in Belgium, where we have been invited to perform at the International Etty Hillesum Congress, celebrating the 100th anniversary of her
birth this January. 
By its nature, this story is bigger,
certainly bigger than us, others having returned her words at Auschwitz as well as others surely to
follow, our own performances of Etty, The Thinking Heart, hopefully inspiring still
others to find new ways to tell her story, whether in film, dance, music or words. And what words!—because
to read and get to know Etty is to have a humanistic encounter of life-changing proportions. She is an
avatar of all that it means to be and remain human under the most corrosive and oppressive
circumstances.
And there are several stories here, stories within stories: first of all, of course, Etty’s and the life of her
voice over and through time and space, crossing national borders, crossing and re-crossing continents
and oceans, the Atlantic and Pacific, crossing the borders of language (her journal and letters are read
from her native Netherlands to Japan); and it is the story of her voice through and over the Nazi
juggernaut; it is the story too of the mystery of time and space, how it happens she lived and wrote
her Holocaust journey, ending with her death in the camps at age 29, and we get to experience it in
the bosom of safe communities, rather than vice versa, that is, our perishing in the concentration
camp and Etty living to tell about it. We might ask, how is this possible. We swim in the miracle of
language like the air that sustains us. Returning her voice to Auschwitz is also the story of the mystery
of language itself, how a voice might travel through a line of prose or poetry, a life be lived again in
sound and light, in words or in film, crossing that other border between life as we know it and death,
that seeming impermeable border between the world and spirit.

So we make a pilgrimage to breathe Etty Hillesum’s words where her life was taken—at Auschwitz.
Oswiecim in Polish. Auschwitz is German. It leaves an aftertaste I don’t want in my mouth. Better the
Poles take back the name. Oswiecim, yes, even though some Poles were complicit. Complicit. That
word, too, leaves an unwanted aftertaste. It is hard to get the taste of these words out of the mouth,
because we know them, they are part of us.

Then there is this woman, Etty Hillesum—words flow from her. They flow out, first like a little brook,
then a stream. She can’t stop them. We don’t know where they come from. They become a river, a
river of words, a river of freshness, and they flow into her notebooks and letters, even from inside
that other word, Auschwitz. Etty’s words burst the dam of Auschwitz, and now they flow out of us,
and we shudder as they wash us, at the warmth and light they leave in our mouth, in our heart.

So this is a story—brook, stream, river into story. We will go there, our small ensemble, to speak her
words, and with our musician swell them in the strains of the cello. It will be winter in Auschwitz, and
we will bring Etty’s voice there to wash the snow.                             
Copyright © 2013 Martin Steingesser




Short Summary










Pilgrimage to the Heart (http://www.pilgrimagetotheheart.org) combines theater, dialogue, a book and visual art to tell the story of a woman who moves through romantic love to a deeper, more
inclusive one, refusing to allow her love of life to be diminished by the oppression to
which she is subjected during the Holocaust, 1942-43. 


The
Pilgrimage to the Heart Project is an expansion of an original, proven ensemble
performance work (and more recently a book) that has toured throughout Maine
to over 40 diverse venues, including high schools, libraries, colleges, public
theaters, churches, temples, museums, the Maine Holocaust and Human Right
Center and the Maine State Prison.
The
performance work and book are called The Thinking Heart: the Life and Loves of
Etty Hillesum,
and the ensemble is comprised of two actors and a cellist who perform an hour
of poetry and music. The inspiration for the work originated from the
extraordinary journals and letters of Etty Hillesum, a young Jewish woman who
kept a journal during the Nazi occupation of Holland and was killed at
Auschwitz. Etty Hillesum’s journal and correspondence, published in An
Interrupted Life and Letters from Westerbork, was adapted into a
sequence of 48 poems and arranged for performance by Martin Steingesser in collaboration with
another actor, Judy Tierney, and a cellist, Robin Jellis. The ensemble is
committed to bringing Etty’s words and exemplary life to audiences for an
enriching and thought provoking experience, best summed up by Edward van
Voolen, Chairman of the Etty Hillesum Foundation, “Etty confronts us all with
what it means to be and remain human under the most extreme circumstances. That
is a form of resistance no oppressor can withstand. Not then, and not now.”
The
performance work creates a communal experience of this woman’s vision, wisdom
and humanity and an opportunity for post performance exploration and dialogue
with  audiences about what her example and courage mean to each of us in our
lives now. Keeping alive the story of a single, courageous woman, not famous or
in a position of power, provides a model for all of us, and an opportunity to
be moved to small actions in our daily life, which have the power of rippling out into the
greater life around us. Hence, our project title: pilgrimage, which means “the
course of life on Earth” for each person, and heart, symbol for courage,
love, compassion.
Birth and Death form a continuum, the way or path we call Life. We are all
travelers. Pilgrimage is for all who long and search for a way to the heart.
Copyright © 2013 Martin Steingesser & Judy Tierney

story:
Our Vision

Kinima is a dance collective that strives to connect the human experience through movement. In our premiere work we have set the bar high. Creating a dance based film that authentically explores and represents the journey for individuals facing Bipolar Disorder.  Instead of creating work that focuses on stereotypes, we strive to connect our own experiences and potential for the disorder.  Using the medium of water as a catalyst we have researched the permeability and fluidity of the mind. The film will be soaking wet (literally) with raw physicality, and a constant flow between manic desire and exhaustive melancholy.

So far it has been an exhausting journey, but has made us steadfast in our vision as a collective; to connect and to grow as human beings through movement.

What We Need
Our goal is to raise $750 dollars to support the production and post-production of the film. The creation phrase is complete, and as a non-profit organization we need funding for the basic necessities of film production. These include but are not limited to: 
  • Lights
  • Costumes 
  • Camera and sound equipment
  • Props
  • Transportation
  • Colour Correction
  • Editing
  • Screening Venue Rental

Impact

  • Mental illnesses, particularly when experienced by women are often stereotyped by popular culture. The film is pioneering artistic practices that authentically connect the viewers to the experience of mental illness as opposed to a stereotype.  This can have a tremendous impact on how the community relates to vulnerable members within its own walls. As well as leaving the audience with the opportunity for self reflection towards their own mental state of being.

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD! We are creating this film to bridge connections, so support from the artistic community as well as mental health is much needed. Also...
  • We are always looking for mentorship opportunities as Kinima is an emerging collective and appreciates guidance.  
  • Connect with us on Facebook, Instagram and our website.
  • Come and view the film! We have at least one TBA screening in the spring but would love to know about any other festivals or opportunities that we are unaware of of.

Thank you for any support you give!!

story:
WHO WE ARE

Off the Grid is a collective of artists committed to pushing the boundaries of artistic ability and engendering social empathy by developing and producing new works and re-imagining classical and contemporary repertoire. We strive to feed the artistic hunger of our company members and cultivate a breeding ground for well-rounded, innovative, and courageous artists.

SEASON FOUR

EQUUS - by Peter Shaffer. Directed by Christopher Webb.
This critically acclaimed play is returning to the Boston stage. Featuring a mix of local theatre scene favorites and up and coming artists.
MACK - by Alexis Scheer. A developmental reading.
A contemporary look at Shakespeare's Macbeth, Mack examines the struggle of power in 2008 Iraq. Join us for a post show talkback with the playwright, mediated by Dr. Helen Deborah Lewis.
MCSWEENEY'S BLOG - by various authors. A mixer.
Part reading. Part social mixer. Mingle with members of the Boston theatre scene in a lounge setting and enjoy live readings of your favorite essays from McSweeney's Internet Tendency. 

THE TEAM

Alexis Scheer - Producing Artistic Director
  • Originally from Miami, FL.
  • BFA. The Boston Conservatory
  • New World School of the Arts alum.
  • Actors' Playhouse Conservatory alum.
Evan Michael Haas - Managing Director
  • Originally from Overland Park, KS.
  • BFA. The Boston Conservatory.
Esteban Esquivel - Marketing Director
  • Originally from Cantaura, Venezuela.
  • BA. Suffolk University.
Carly Rose Straubing - Development & Outreach Coordinator
  • Originally from Rochester, NY.
  • BFA candidate. The Boston Conservatory.
  • The Harley School alum.

DONATIONS OVER $1.5K

Season sponsorship levels available for donations over $1.5K. Please contact Evan, our Managing Director, at evan@offthegridtheatre.com to discover the benefits of becoming a season sponsor.

story:
The Show

5th - 13th December  (THEATRE UPSTAIRS)

The Snow Queen

by Hans Christian Andersen

Adapted and directed by Andrew Allen

As the dark nights draw in, we invite you to a palace of snow and ice! Join Gerda as she journeys across the world and through the seasons to save her best friend Kai from the cold clutches of the Snow Queen. On her way, she meets all manner of magical creatures and enchanting friends to help in her quest. 

A story for all ages, told for this age. 

Lock your windows, and wrap up warm... because the Snow Queen is on her way...


The Theatre

This production of The Snow Queen will take place at New Venture Theatre, a charity theatre based in Brighton, East Sussex and run entirely by volunteers. It has won several local awards for the high quality of its productions. Along with the many productions, The NVT runs a Youth Theatre, acting classes and workshops.

The NVT was founded over fifty years ago to provide education and experience to anyone wanting to get involved in theatre and to bring affordable performing arts to the local community.


Why We Need Your Funding

No matter what happens, New Venture Theatre’s Snow Queen is going to be a magical production. We have a huge team of wonderfully talented cast and crew who have fallen in love with the story.

Yet with your help we can make The Snow Queen truly awe-inspiring.  Our dream is that children and adults come to the show and are utterly blown away by the magnificent effects, fall in love with our spectacularly costumed cast and are enchanted by the Snow Queen’s palace.

You can make our Christmas dreams come true by giving us the means to get one more flurry of snow, or help give the Snow Queen a spectacular crown and perhaps provide us with yet another cog or wheel for one of the delightful inventions of our steampunk princess.


What We Need – The Breakdown:

Snow: lots of it, and in many different styles and shapes.

Animations, which will mainly be created by local children. 

A shattering mirror: which we hope to specially create for the show … which can break again and again .. 

Snow Queen’s Throne: a magnificent ‘snow globe’ that will be our villainess’ centerpiece.

Lighting Effects – Some physical and mobile effects to be used on stage. 

Puppets for some of our smaller characters.

Costumes and props for many varied characters. 

Steampunk Princess’ Invention (which we could tell you about, but we’d rather keep the surprise for the show!).

story:
WHAT'S HAPPENING?

Defibrillator is taking a play to New York. Not just any play; a classic, British, award winning drama that happens to feature four incredibly famous people.

Imagine if Marilyn Monroe and Albert Einstein met in a hotel room. Just briefly. Just for one night. What would they talk about? And what if they were interrupted by the 'two Joes' - McCarthy and DiMaggio?

Insignificance by Olivier and Tony award winning dramatist, Terry Johnson, is the intriguing, hilarious, and heartbreaking story of the Senator, the Ballplayer, the Professor and the Actress. Four icons of American history meeting one night, in one hotel room, in New York City. 

Defibrillator invites New York audiences to see this play in the intimate surrounds of an actual hotel room at Langham Place, Fifth Avenue.

Artistic Director, James Hillier, who will direct Insignificance, and Executive Producer Trish Wadley are joined by New York Theatre Company, Hang A Tale on this exciting production.

Check out our website!


WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Defibrillator have staged a series of commercially successful and critically acclaimed hotel productions including The Hotel Plays by Tennessee Williams at the Langham, London.

Their passion for bringing dynamic, fluid theatre to a versatile contemporary audience in site specific settings, can now be seen in New York.

Audiences will be taken on a journey from the lobby, to the fifth floor for just under two hours of first class entertainment including the performance and a secret bar full of surprises!

Previews start 19th Feb 2016

Opening night is 24th Feb 2016

The play runs for just four weeks until March 20th,  so don't miss out!

"A deeply impressive new theatre company” - Time Out London


WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

We want to revive fantastic plays that have fallen out of notice, and show their enduring relevance; socially, politically and emotionally. 

We love this play, and the opportunity to stage a story that takes place in a New York hotel room in an ACTUAL New York hotel room, was too good to pass up!

We know the risks and challenges that come with putting on a play, especially one that is not staged in the traditional way. Furthermore, to make it even tougher on ourselves, we're taking it to America! We're confident that we have  cracked the formula to make a Hotel Play work; we just need your help to show the rest of the world what we can do!

‘The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious’ - Albert Einstein


HOW YOU CAN HELP?

Any contribution is appreciated! We have some great rewards, including an overnight stay at the five star Langham hotel on Fifth Avenue.

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute in a monetary way, but you can still help! 

•Get the word out by telling your friends about our campaign.

•Create some buzz for us on Facebook and Twitter

We hope you can join us on our journey to bring this fantastic British play to the Big Apple!

Thanks!

story:
What's the show about?

“What a fine persecution - to be kept intrigued without ever quite being enlightened…”

In Tom Stoppard’s quintessential comedy, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern wander through the plot of Hamlet as they discover their helplessness against their own fate. The play questions life, death, and theatre, while ultimately exposing the absurdity of it all.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead goes up October 8-10 in historic Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University.

Where is my money going?

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead and Lovers & Madmen are entirely non-profit and student-produced. On top of that, we receive very limited funding from the university. As a donor to the show, your money will help fund various aspects of our production. Your donation will help us buy plywood and foam to build our set, rent lights, buy fabric for costumes, and . Our cast and team are working incredibly hard to create a beautiful piece of theatre, and every dollar donated will help us realize this vision. 

Who's working on this project?

Our cast features...

  • Dominick Mugavero as Rosencrantz
  • Kali Skatchke as Guildenstern
  • Marin Nass as Player
  • Helena Scholz-Carlson as Hamlet
  • Alex Kohanski as Ophelia
  • Shara Feit as Gertrude
  • Max Spitz as Claudius
  • Alex Milinazzo as Polonius
  • Andrea Canizares-Fernandez, Neal Davidson, and Heather Strauss as the Players

Behind the scenes, you can find...

  • Producer: Rob Cassie
  • Director: Abby Weissman
  • Assistant Director: Nathan Selinger
  • Stage Manager: Michael Herwitz
  • Assistant Stage Manager: Manon Blackman
  • Dramaturg: Noah Perkins
  • Scenic Designer: Axel Mark
  • Assistant Scenic Designer: Brianna Downs
  • Technical Director: Nick Raef
  • Master Carpenter: Ryan Miller
  • Scenic Painter: Preston Choi
  • Costume Designer: Emily Blim
  • Assistant Costume Designer: Miles Blim
  • Props Designer: Chris Porter
  • Lighting Designer: Tatyana Aravena
  • Assistant Lighting Designers: Dinnie Jay & Mari Uchida
  • Sound Designer: Doug Pinckney
  • Graphic Designer: Jason Yuan
  • Marketing Director: Becca Ehlers
  • Photographer: Mari Uchida
  • Production Assistants: Abrahm Oxley-Hase & Marley Smith

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead is presented by Lovers & Madmen, a student theatre group at Northwestern University that produces a full season of classical and classically-inspired works each year.

How else can I help?

If you are unable to donate, or if you just want to keep helping, here are some other ways to support our show:

  • Come and see the show! 
  • Spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, and tell your friends and family about the show!

Thank you so much!

story:
Short Summary

Working with a group of Nigerian and Cameroonian footballers, Australian artist Ahilan Ratnamohan has been invited to present his new football-dance-theatre work, Michael Essien I want to play as you... as part of the opening ceremony for Antwerp European Capital of Sport in February 2013.

The financial explosion of football coupled with the growing success of African players in Europe has led to many Africans genuinely believing in football as a way out of poverty. African players are now a commodity perpetually shipped out to Europe, the Middle East and Asia. While the majority of African players displayed by the media are on million-dollar contracts, there is a growing under-class of football-aspirants living in harsh conditions in foreign lands chasing the dream of a decent football contract. 

The performers have all had different experiences in their attempt at gaining a professional contract in a foreign land ; from trials with big clubs and matches for the Nigerian U19 team to being abandonned by agents and seeking asylum in Belgium.

Through this production the team is attempting to explore the lines between hope and desperation of African football migrants all over the world trying to make a living from football. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need support for our production we will be able to adequetly fund the production. We are currenty $15,000 short and need assistance to pay for:

- Lighting and Sound

- The Venue

- Accomodation for the artists while they rehearse.

- Stage Settings

The project presents a unique opportunity for the development of a new performance work and a network of relationships and discussions over three continents regarding an important social issue.  In addition to this the performance’s combination of football, theatre and dance provokes interesting discussions on cross-cultural and collaborative arts practices.

Ahilan Ratnamohan has begun to create a body of work, which looks at football as a cultural phenomena and art.  His first major work The Football Diaries was critically acclaimed and toured South Africa in 2010 at the National Arts and Football For Hope festivals.  Michael Essien I want to play as you... represents a second step in Ahil's practice, as he looks to create an international work, which also engages community.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Join our Facebook page and become a friend. Promote our story and message to your  football fanatic friends as ask them to support our cause.

story:
Hi, we hope you find our story as exciting as we do!

BROADWAY HERE WE COME!!!!

Hi, my name is Olivia McLeod, and I am an 11 year old grade 5 student at Sherwood Elementry School in Charlottetown Prince Edward Island. My name is Grace Rowan-Quansah, and I am a 10 year old grade 6 studen at Prince Street Elementry School also in Charlottetown Prince Edward Island.

Our passion is dance, and we have had training in many forms which include: tap, ballet, a small amount of highland so that we were able to do a performance, jazz (2 years), and hip hop (4 years)

Grace also enjoys singing, playing guitar, acting, gymnastics and has won awards for her art work.

Olivia also enjoys running, cross country, art class, acting, and has recently won awards and the provincial level science fair.

This past winter we were both dancers with the Storm Chasers which was a dance team that performed for the Summerside Storm NBL (National Pro basketball team of Canada). We both invested more than 150 volunteer hours between rehersals, and performances, we loved every minute of it, and developed some life long friendships and were looking forward to the same thing in NYC.

We were 2 lucky children on PEI who had the opportunity to listen to Mr. Peter Sklar speak about how to persue your aspiration of a career in the performing arts, and after an interview we were both offered a position in his prestigous Beginnings workshop camp that is being held on Braodway in New York City this August!!! This really is a once in a lifetime opportunity for us.

Mr. Peter Sklar is a noted talent scout, educator, and producer who has discovered or coached thousands of young performers including Sarah Jessica Parker, Reese Winterspoon, Mischa Barton, Zachary Ty Bryan, Ricki Lake, and numerous other young stars of Broadway, TV & Film.

The highlights to this training for us include some of our mentors, coaches, and instructors. They include but are not limited to Laura Osnes who stared in Broadway's Grease, Tony Award-winning star Sutton Foster, Tracy Edwards who was in Broadway's Hairspray. and currently featured in Broadway's Legally Blonde, and Ben Cameron who was featured in Broadway's Wicken and Footloose.

As if that's not exciting enough or week will end with a performance on the Off-Broadway Orpheum theatre. So really you are helping us get our "break in the bizz"

The best part of all of this, is the fact that we have been planning to move to NYC so that we could pursue our dreams in the theatre arts, after we complete high school, imagine when you were a child had you been given the chance to follow your dreams...Well this is our once in a lifetime chance!

 

The breakdown of our costs are as follows

 

$1890.00 x 2 people this includes our tuition, 6 nights/7days of accommodations, and all our meals.

$400 x2 for airfair to NYC and home again for both Olivia and Grace

Every nickle that is donated will be going directly towards our trip to New York. To thank you for your donations please first and foremost know you have our upmost appreciation. We will also send you a autographed photo of us on Broadway...why autographed you ask?? Well we WILL be famous one day, so that signature will be worth something! Also seeing you are being sweet enough to donate to us, we will be providing you with PEI's best homade fudge or some fantastic cupcakes, and also some memorabilia from a popular NYC landmark.

 

We understand not everyone can donate, but just know that if only $1, we appreciate it more than you know, as every dollar counts.

If your able to donate an item please let us know as we would be more than happy to raffle it off.

Also please please please share this page with EVERYONE you know, and ask them to do the exact same thing, social media is an amazing thing and can really get the word out, email the link, share it on facebook, or tweet it. With your help we will go to Broadway and we promise to make you all proud.

 

Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

 

Grace Rowan-Quansah & Olivia McLeod

(just imagine how great our names will look in lights on Broadway)

story:
Short Summary


Mind The Gap Theatre will present Jessica Fleitman’s comedy Deuteranomaly: A One-Act in Two Parts as part of the 4th Annual Planet Connections Theatre Festivity in New York City.  The production will be directed by Mind The Gap’s Artistic Director, Paula D’Alessandris.

The production will feature Dee Dee Friedman*, David J. Goldberg*, Vinnie Penna*, and Erika Lee. John Michael Crotty is Production Stage Manager (*These actors are appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association).

Deuteranomaly is a comedic look at the challenges in loving someone who quite literally will never see the world the way you do. When a couple discovers that their son suffers from red-green colorblindness, this seemingly innocuous diagnosis reveals dangerous rifts in their relationship. Years later, the boy is now a man struggling to relate to his talented painter girlfriend whose work he can never truly see. Worlds will collide in this colorful comedy of Jews and hues.

 

The Impact

We want to tell a great story in a fabulous festival with the best cast and crew we can find! When the first part of Deuteranomaly was produced at Manhattan Theatre Source in 2011, it was praised as "a rich comedy of ideas" (Ben Trawick-Smith, nytheatre.com). Unfortunately, we can't pay our collaborators or rent rehearsal space with "comedy" or "ideas," so we need your help with the "riches" to get this show onstage!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Any contribution at any level counts! $50 pays for space for one complete three-hour rehearsal. Your donation of $175 means we can rehearse for a week! $200 covers the cost of printing postcards to market the show. $500 allows us to pay our fabulous actors and production team! And so on...

Please note: All contributions to the Planet Connections production of Deuteranomaly are tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law.

Look to the right to check out our FABULOUS PERKS at different levels of giving! You may be the recipient of a unique drawing by an Actual Untalented Artist, an original audition monologue written especially for you, free audition coaching, comp tickets and MORE!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the show, and please follow our Deuteranomaly show blog (deuteranomaly.blogspot.com) for pictures, updates, and special offers! And please do come and see the show at Planet Connections this June!

Thank you for your support! It is appreciated more than you know!

story:
O U R  S T O R Y

SIX SEEDS: The Persephone Project has been selected as the final production for Theatre at The Tank, The Tank's new curated series, set for June 2011!  It takes a village to raise a goddess up from the underworld, and we are continuing the collective effort that has nurtured SIX SEEDS to raise funds for this upcoming production.  We need your help!  For six years, 45 actors, directors, writers, designers, technicians and students donated their time, ideas and words and now we need some seed money to produce a full-fledged two week production.


Join us in support of new theatre created, written and directed by women. This is a difficult time to fund new art, but a passionate effort through years of readings, workshops and rewrites has prepared us for this challenge. We are committed to bringing Persephone’s voice to life.


About  T H E  S H O W


Persephone, a young woman trapped in a marriage she didn't agree to, tells her own story for the first time in SIX SEEDS: The Persephone Project. A psychological journey of a kidnapping, a marriage and a mother/daughter relationship, SIX SEEDS is intimate and epic, a beautiful retelling of a classic story that continues to deeply influence our modern world. Creator and director Annie G. Levy brings her signature visual flair to the age-old myth of Persephone in this sensitive and poetic production.

Runs June 2, 3, 4,  9, 10 & 11, 2011 at 7:30 at Theatre at the Tank.


Help us make  S I X  S E E D S happen

We need your contributions to produce SIX SEEDS!


$6 sponsors one actor's transportation to and from a rehearsal or performance on public transit

$24 sponsors three photocopies of the script

$60 sponsors space rental for one rehearsal

$96 sponsors one rental truck to transport borrowed lighting and set pieces from storage to venue

$366 sponsors the work of one theatre artist or technician

$600 sponsors the creation of all of our props

When the curtain goes up on SIX SEEDS this June, your contribution will be responsible for the sound, lights, publicity materials, actors, program and costumes. Every dollar you invest will be stretched, used and reused as we use all our creative energies to borrow and recycle. Best of all your gift is tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)3 non-profit.


Tell your  F R I E N D S 

Spreading the word is a huge help to this project. Blog, email, tweet and post this on facebook! Tell your neighbors, your college classics professor, your mom and your local pomegranate supplier and we'll see you at the theater! We are incredibly grateful for whatever you can donate, including your continued enthusiasm and encouragement.


Visit us on facebook, twitter, our website or at The Tank.


The  S I X  S E E D S  C O M P A N Y

Conceived and Directed by Annie G. Levy  

Cast: Emily Taplin Boyd, Haley Channing*, Joya Mia Italiano, Ean Sheehy*, Franny Silverman*, and Emily Warshaw


Designers and Production Team: Kate Ashton, Jonathan Collins, Lara de Bruijn, Will Fulton, Samantha Hirsch, Anna Kroup, Mara Leventhal, and Kate Marvin

* Appearing courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association.

Artists who have contributed to workshops: (2005) Haley Channing, Louise Flory, Alyson Gibson, Mara Leventhal, Annie Levy,  Deanna Neil, Franny Silverman, Stephanie Skaff, and Kate Turnbull (2006) Rachel Brown, Lindsay Doleshal, Audra George, Katie Hartman, Daniel Kelley, Sarah Levine, Annie Levy, Marisa Levy, Bronwen Mullin,  Alison Walls, Ashley Weaver, Randall Whittinghill and Lauren Wilson (2009) Michelle Bialeck, Anni Bruno, Haley Channing, Louise Flory, Audra George, Jake Goodman, Daliya Karnofsky, Maria Kelly, Annie Levy, Elizabeth Miller, Yael Miriam, Deanna Neil, Shawn Shafner, and Franny Silverman

(2010) Kate Ashton, Emily Taplin Boyd, Haley Channing, Jonathan Collins, Lara de Bruijn, Will Fulton, Joya Mia Italiano, Annie Levy, Kate Marvin, Ean Sheehy, Chet Siegel, Franny Silverman, and Emily Warshaw


We are excited to welcome you to our family of supporters and collaborators!

Produced by Warner | Shaw

For more information about the history of this project and the participants visit http://warnershaw.com.

story:
Short Summary

Pitfalls and Promises testifies to the boundless potential of the human spirit with a message of hope and perseverance. The story follows the life of a woman who overcomes a harsh childhood, a teachers "stupid" label, dyslexia, cancer and other life traumas to achieve prominence in her career and make a difference in the life of hundreds of men and woman. 

Who Are The Creators of Pitfalls and Promises?

We are Natalie and Al Winters, a retired couple in our seventies, aurthor's, directors and producers of this musical play,  proving that creativity knows no age limit.

I'm Natalie and I wrote the music and lyrics for all thirteen songs in the show even though I don't read music. The music just flows into me and I then have a musician do the sheet music and arrangements.This may seem a long step from my 35-year career in mental health but it's simply another way of being creative.

My husband, Al, retired from a long corporate career in public relations. He was a speech writer and employee communications specialist. He is now pursuing his passion for theater and playwrighting.

We took the risk of staging the show for two performances in a small theater in the town we now live in, Cary, NC. Both performances were sold out and many people in the audience were deeply moved and urged us to mount the production again in larger venues. The problem is that we have lost a few thousand dollars producing the show. As a retired couple on fixed income, our rescources are limited. But we fervently believe that Pitfalls and Promises delivers a message that people want and need to hear. Our desire is to leave an audience believing that just like the main character in the show, Emma, they too can perservere and triumph over adversity.

The importance of your contribution!

At a time when many are struggling  to cope with life's challenges, it's crucial to deliver a message of inspiraton. You can help deliver that message through your contribution. You can help us help others know that it's important to dream and that dreams can be realized.

 

What We Need & What You Can Do!

We lost a considerable amount of money producing the premier of the show even though it sold out both nights. The expenses were beyond what we had expected.

Now we have a larger venue for the production and expect to incur the following costs:

  • Venue rental----------------------------------------------$1,500
  • Playbill design and printing------------------------------$1,200
  • Music director/pianist------------------------------------ $2,000
  • Production technicians----------------------------------- $1,000
  • Lighting design------------------------------------------   $1,200
  • Costumes------------------------------------------------- $400
  • Vidiography (to replace poor quality original video)---$800
  • Props-------------------------------------------------------$200
  • TOTAL------------------------------------------------------$8,300

 

The Impact

Your generousity will allow hundreds of people to experience the messages the production sends. Here are some audience responses found on Facebook after the first show:

"We were absolutely spellbound by the show. It was professional on every level, as well as beautifully executed. I agree with Elke, I hope you can stage it many more times and share this work with others. Congrats to you both!! -Jill and Larry Goldberg, Cary NC"

"Congratulations to you and to all involved on your fantastic play! I hope that many more people get to see and experience this beautiful emotional roller coaster ride with a happy ending. You are an inspiration to all of us! Elke Brand, Cary NC"

 As people walk out the door we hope they'll think "If that woman made it after all of her problems, maybe I can do it too!" 

As a line in the show says, "When you're ready, the universe conspires on your behalf."

Other Ways You Can Help

YOU CAN HELP BY SHARING THE WORD THROUGH EMAIL, FACEBOOK OR ANY OTHER SOCIAL MEDIUM. WE WOULD BE EVER SO GRATEFUL FOR YOUR SHARING!

Word of mouth goes a long way as well.

Please use the Indiegogo tools to share withl.

As a line in the show says, "When you're ready, the universe conspires on your behalf."


Other Ways You Can Help
YOU CAN HELP BY SHARING THE WORD THROUGH EMAIL, FACEBOOK OR ANY OTHER SOCIAL MEDIUM. WE WOULD BE EVER SO GRATEFUL FOR YOUR SHARING!
Word of mouth goes a long way as well.
Please use the Indiegogo tools to share withl.

story:
Let's Stack Some Paper

We are asking for $750 that will go directly toward our latest project BACKSTAGE AT HORROR DRAG at The Incubator Arts Project February 21st - 24th, with a special encore performance at JACK Arts Center February 28th-March 1st.  As of right now, every bit of funding toward our work has come out of our own pockets.

This funding would provide :

  • Props! Lots of glitter, blood, gore and pistachios are going to be needed every single night in order to deliver the most fabulous horror your eyes won't be able to unsee.
  • Costumes! We need short shorts for our Ball Boys and wedding gowns brides were buried in. 
  • Rehearsal space! Real estate in this city doesn't come cheap babies, and although we rehearse in back alleys whenever possible, it's gotten cold outside.

The Show

Inspired by the real-life Filipino drag sensation Ryan Robles, "Backstage at Horror Drag" imagines a flourishing niche of performance and the community of people who give their lives to it, despite the nearly total lack of recognition or reward. Through a series of live drag sets intercut with scenes of backstage intrigue, “Backstage at Horror Drag” is made of glamour, stage blood, glitter explosions, and above all; lip-syncing.

Who We Are

Founded in 2010, we are ANIMALS: NIKKI CALONGE, MIKE MIKOS, MICHAEL DE ANGELIS. Utilizing various modes of visual art and performance, ANIMALS move through dance, puppetry, script and video in order to create moments that question the flexibility of the world around us and the nature of humans through irreverence, instinct, ability and play.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Like us on Facebook! Check us out at https://www.facebook.com/AnimalsPerformanceGroup
  • Share this page on IndieGoGo
  • COME SEE OUR SHOW

story:
Short Summary

Tiny Bliss Productions was founded in NYC with the goal of helping people to transform their tiny blisses into big realities. Our first production will be of Neil LaBute's ROMANCE.

Eddy Out Productions (formerly MSCDTP), co-producing ROMANCE by Neil LaBute, is devoted to challenging and nurturing the human spirit through a union of contemporary theater, film, fine art, movement, and mixed media… Eddy's are hydraulics in a river that one uses to navigate the current, pull over, pause or stop to check out something interesting… so Eddy Out!  

"Romance was written as an exercise during an acting workshop in Spain.  The ... actors and ... actresses involved used the text to explore the limits of gender and power on stage.  Any actor can play either role as the material was specifically written without gender - the new dynamic in each performance is brought to the surface by who that actor is and what they try to achieve with their given character" (Neil LaBute, 2010 ).
 
In the spirit of all of Neil LaBute's work we've decided to explore every aspect of the text. Discovering what really is power within relationships regardless of gender or sexual preference.
 
This show is as much about the audience's perception of gender and power as it is about the performance we will show you. 
 
Learn more, view actor/director bios, see pictures!!! on our website !  
 

What We Need

We are looking to raise $3,000 to fund the cost of the production.  This will cover:

  • Theater space rental
  • Rights fees
  • Set and costume
  • Promotional

During the current political climate we feel this kind of show is important to open up dialogue about gender relations, perceived power, and  the role this plays not only in relationships but outside of the bedroom as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You will notice we have perks, but GIVE WHAT YOU CAN!!! Those donations that do not receive perks are TAX DECUCTIBLE!!! 
  • Buy a ticket to come see our show and bring some friends !
  • Send a check: Romance the Play Production (payable to Mara Gilbert), 300 Reservoir Place, Apt. 4D, Bronx, NY 10467 
  • If you can't give money - we still love you! Get the word out and make some noise about our show!!

story:
Our Story

We are The NYC Cooperative Theatre Co.  We are an entirely volunteer-run organization dedicated to producing high-quality musical theatre at low ticket prices.  As a cooperative organization, all of our members (actors, dancers, musicians and technicians) play an active role in all aspects of production.  We are embarking on our inaugural season.  We need to raise $5,000 by June 18th in order to launch our first show.  Help us to realize our goal by contributing to our community theatre. 

 

By helping us to raise $5,000, you will be giving us the funds we need to create an entire season of shows.  Our season will consist of 4 famous and exciting musicals:  "Little Shop of Horrors", "Jekyll & Hyde", "The Wedding Singer" and "Sweeney Todd".  We are so excited about having the opportunity to bring these musicals to life again on a New York City stage!

What We Need & What You Get

Just $1 will help us to get where we need to go.  Each time a person donates, it brings us closer to our goal and closer to curtain time. So, here's how your donation will be spent:  Costumes, Royalties, Music, Props and Sets.

While we are depending on the generosity of you to help us reach our goal, our volunteers are all reaching deep into their own pockets as well.  As a non-profit organziation, our members will not benefit financially from any production, but our audience members will!  Theatre patrons who would otherwise be unable to afford theatre tickets will be able to see our dynamic productions. Help us today by donating $1, $10, $20 or $100.  From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you for your generosity. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us to get the word out!  Let your Facebook friends, Twitter followers and all others know about our campaign.  Thank you for all your support!

story:
My Name is Marianne Delehanty and I am the artistic director of MarDelDance. MarDelDance is a new and rising company full of fresh ideas, passion, and a desire for change. The primarily contemporary company aims to introduce audiences and society as a whole to dance-drama. I also hope to touch others with my work in putting them on the path towards self-discovery. I combine dance with music, acting, singing and film, producing dance-drama.

MarDelDance has been accepted as 1 of 4 companies to present work at the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater as part of Jump on the DanceWagon. Jump on the DanceWagon (J/DW) is an innovative split-bill for choregraphers at any point in their career. J/DW provides four choreographers with 20-minutes to show work in any arrangement of their choice. Along with the producer/presenter, choreographers invest a percentage in the production costs and, in turn, receive that same percentage back from the box office sales.

With your help MarDelDance will be able to perform at this presitigous venue and be catipulted to the next level their career. Having this opportunity to perform on this renowned stage is a dream of the company's since it's inception and with your help we can fulfill this goal!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

We need to raise a total of $1,500.00 to get us on that stage! This money will go toward technical fees of the theater, costumes, and set designs. 

If we do not reach our goal, all funds raised will still go towards getting us on that stage! 100% of all money raised will go towards this one event! 

Any amount helps us and with any amount you will recieve a gift from us, such as a signed postcard, magnet, stickers, DVD, and even merchandise!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

We simply ask that sharing our project with friends and families can help aid us in reaching our goal!

One again thank you for always helping us share our story!

story:
Sasquatch: The Musical premieres in New York with a professional reading on Thursday, August 1 at 8:00 PM in the National Comedy Theatre!

Your donation directly contributes to this production!

 

What This Is

The Story:

Scientist Kenneth Henderson is called upon to help the struggling town of Spoons, Washington solve the mystery of a haunting prophecy that has led to the disappearance of several children. The locals believe it to be the work of the mysterious creature in the woods, the Sasquatch. Kenneth works reluctantly alongside cryptozoologist Jane Goodall to solve the case while prejudice and hysteria in the down threaten to destroy their progress. As they grow ever closer to the truth, and to each other, they discover a shocking surprise, and only the Sasquatch himself – with the help of an unlikely young hero – will be able to save the day for them and the missing children.  A comedic musical journey defying genre and time, Sasquatch: the Musical explores that most beloved of North American folk myths, Bigfoot, and celebrates the power of belief in everyone.

The Authors:

Book, music, and lyrics by Matthew Lucas and Patrick McElroy, and orchestration by Matt Shervey.

The Legend:

Now that Sasquatch: The Musical has had its hugely successful world premier on stage at Grove City High School, it's time to take the next big-footed step in the Squatch journey, with script and music revisions and a professional staged reading.  That's where you come in... 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Developing a new musical isn't cheap, what with gas prices the way they are.  So we need some help.  In addition to fostering our eternal gratitude and a secure place in North American Sasquatch lore, your contributions will help us do the following:

-Book a rehearsal and performance space in New York City
-Pay performers, a director, and an accompanist
-Pay for accommodations and nourishment for performers during rehearsals and performances
-Cover travel costs for out-of-town performers and members of the creative team
-Continue to publicize the project to potential producers, publishers, and collaborators

Check out the list of perks to see what your gift will get you, including signed posters, personalized video messages from the Sasquatch, and soap provided by our friends at Sasquatch Soap Co.! 

(Merchandise to be delivered by September 01, 2013.)

The Impact

We feel that the world needs to know the story of Sasquatch, and we intend to tell it...tell it well and true.

A professional reading is an important step in making this musical the best it can be.  We hope to find a publisher and potential investors in future productions, so that Sasquatch can find the audience he deserves.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't give anything?  No problem!  Help us by spreading the word about Sasquatch: The Musical!  Use the Indiegogo share tool, or find us on facebook or twitter.  Don't forget to check out the sizzle reel and check in at www.sasquatchthemusical.com.

story:
I adore you, and I adore Shakespeare.

Have you noticed I’ve been doing a lot of Shakespeare recently? In the last couple years, I have done Romeo & Juliet, A Midsummer Night’s Dream (three times!), As You Like It, The Taming of the Shrew and I am currently rehearsing All’s Well That Ends Well. I love Shakespeare intensely and it has changed my life in so many ways.  I feel crazy lucky.

Here’s the kicker- all my knowledge of how to approach acting in Shakespeare plays comes from the following: instinct, watching other people do it, or making it up. And it terrifies me. I love these plays so much and want to do them justice. Once I’ve been cast in a show, it’s so exciting and scary because I never know what my process is going to be like. Shakespeare & Company offers a month long program where I can get the tools, inspiration and support I need to approach the Bard fearlessly! It is in Lenox, MA! The program is in January 2014, but I need to pay by October.

Here is a link to the program if you'd like to read more about it:

http://www.shakespeare.org/training/comprehensi...

The program costs a total of $3,700. It includes housing! 

My amazing parents have offered to pay $700 of that, and help me buy a plane ticket. The reason that the campaign is for $3,200 is because indiegogo and paypal both have some fees, so I will be funded about $200 less than the ultimate campaign goal.

If for some insanely wonderful reason, I exceed my funding goal, I will use the rest of the money to feed myself and put it towards my airfare! That would be really incredible.

I would be forever grateful if you could help me come up with the money for this incredible program!

A little bit more about me and my passion:

If you know me, you probably know that all my education has been pretty non traditional! I homeschooled my whole life, didn’t go to college, and chose to move to the bay area in 2008 to become a working theatre actor.

Guess what?! It worked. I have been working for the last five years on INCREDIBLE projects with AMAZING companies.  To mention a few: Marin Shakes, Cal Shakes, Livermore Shakes, New Conservatory Theatre, SF Shakes, Berkeley Rep and Shotgun Players. And last but not least, Impact Theatre- where I am a proud resident actor and company member.

I’m running around and getting cast in shows and working my butt off. BUT. I know that I am at a point where there are companies and roles that I cannot achieve without additional training and growth. I want to build and sustain my career as an actor in the Bay Area. I love living here and want to be able to stay here and continue to find work.

What you will get out of this:

By helping me get this training, which is so important to my growth, you are helping me achieve my crazy goal of sustaining myself through being an actor. This will not go unnoticed. My heart is already so very full of love for the people and companies who I get to work with- you people amaze me with your generosity and warmth already. I will be so grateful, so thrilled, so full of love and admiration for you.

I also love to bake you snickerdoodles and make you handmade cards.

What if you love this idea but have no money:

I really get it! I live paycheck to paycheck which is why I'm asking for this money in the first place :-)

I totally understand if you don’t have money to donate to this project! No need to fret. I would just be so happy if you could share this with people you know who might be interested in helping out!

I love you all already.

Thank you for taking the time to check this out!

Huge hugs and kisses.

 

Always,

Luisa

story:
Somos las femmes fatales que no piden perdón ni permiso. ***Yes, "unapologetic" is our middle name...

                EDMI DE JESÚS... Karla /  EDNA LEE FIGUEROA... Cristina

Entre cajas de pizza, whiskey, hamsters, celulares, Facebook, horóscopos, velones y Santa Bárbara somos cómplices de los amores, maldeamores, soledad y solidaridad de Karla y Cristina. En momentos de crisis lo que la realidad no cura, lo sobrenatural viene al rescate. Dos mujeres solteras en busca de amor y placer acuden a Santa Bárbara sin saber que Santa Bárbara… es una femme fatale.

***Among pizza boxes, whiskey, hamsters, cell phones, Facebook, horoscopes, candles and Santa Bárbara we are accomplices of love, lovesicknes, solitude and solidarity of Karla and Cristina. In times of crisis what reality can't cure, the supernatural comes to the rescue. Two single women looking for love and pleasure come to Santa Bárbara without knowing that Santa Bárbara ... is a femme fatale.

-----

Camila Monclova & Mariana Monclova escribieron esta obra de teatro, una comedia irreverente de 45 minutos que presentamos en Nueva York en abril de 2016 en un festival de teatro de comedias. 

***These two, the Monclovas, wrote this 45-minute irreverent comedy, play that we presented in New York in April 2016 as part of a comedy theater festival. 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que hay para ti    ***What We Need & What You Get

Empezando en el otoño de este año hacemos las maletas y nos vamos de gira fuera de Nueva York. La primera parada es Miami. Allí presentaremos SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE (con traducción en inglés). Edmi De Jesús y Edna Lee Figueroa junto con Producciones El Barrio vuelven a la carga.

***Beginning in the Fall of this year we pack our bags and go on tour outside New York. The first stop is Miami. There we will present SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE (with English translation). Edmi De Jesús and Edna Lee Figueroa along with Producciones El Barrio return to the fray.

-----

Ésta es una gran oportunidad para contribuir a nuestro proyecto. Mira a la derecha arriba de la pantalla, los "Perks", puedes hacerlo así o donar la cantidad que te haga feliz. No nos vamos a sentir mal si quieres contribuir con un poco más. Gracias.

*** This is a great opportunity to contribute to our project. Take a look at the up right side of the screen, "Perks", you can do it like that or donate any amount that makes you happy. We are not going to feel bad if you feel like contributing a bit more. Thank you.

----

Tenemos como objetivo recaudar $2500 en nuestra campaña para cubrir el costo de los pasajes de avión, transportación, alojamiento, arrendamiento del teatro, y otros gastos misceláneos e imprevistos. Ya tenemos el vestuario y la utilería. La compañía de teatro en la que nos presentaremos nos va a facilitar los elementos de escenografía.

***We hope to raise $2500 through this campaign to cover the cost of airfare, transportation, lodging, rental of the theater, and other miscellaneous and unforeseen expenses. We have the costumes and props already. The theater company in which we will present our play will facilitate us the set elements.

Photos credit: Michael Palma

Con tus $5, $10, $30, $50, los $300 o la cantidad con la que puedas/quieras contribuir vas a ser parte integral de SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE. Pondremos fotos, videos y actualizaciones de todo lo que estemos haciendo en nuestra página de Facebook, Edmi y Edna Lee lo harán en sus cuentas de Instagram y Twitter, en sus sitios cibernéticos, en sus páginas de Facebook... Y todo eso lo podremos lograr gracias a ti.

***With your $5, $10, $30, $50, the $300 or the amount that you can/want to contribute you'll be an integral part of SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE. We will post photos, videos and updates of all that we are doing on our Facebook page, Edmi and Edna Lee will on their Instagram and Twitter accounts, on their websites, on their Facebook pages... All of that it will be possible because of you.

------

Producciones El Barrio promueve y desarrolla el arte entre las comunidades bilingües (español e inglés) de Nueva York. Por medio del teatro, la música, producciones de baile y exhibiciones de artes plásticas aspiramos a unir las diferencias culturales entre las comunidades de la diáspora y sus países de origen. 

***Producciones El Barrio promotes art for New York's Spanish- English speaking communities. Trough theater, music, dance productions as well as fine arts exhibits we aim to bridge the cultural differences between diaspora communities and their countries of origin. 

¿Y cómo más podrías ayudar?                        ***And in what other ways you could help? 

Sabemos que no todo el mundo puede contribuir económicamente pero eso no quiere decir que no puedas ayudar de otra manera...

***We know that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean that you couldn't help...

-----

1. Haz ruido sobre nuestra obra y nuestra campaña para que otros se enteren, comparte el cariño.

2. Dale "Like" (Me gusta) a nuestra campaña en Indiegogo y en Facebook, comparte nuestro enlance en tu perfil de Facebook y en tu cuenta de Twitter. 

-----

***Make some noise about our play and our campaign, get the word out, share some love.

***Like our campaign on Indiegogo and Facebook, post our link to your Facebook profile or Twitter account.

GRACIAS, corazón, eres una maravilla.

***THANK YOU, sweetie, you're so awesome.                                                                   

SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE
story_txt:
Somos las femmes fatales que no piden perdón ni permiso. ***Yes, "unapologetic" is our middle name...
                EDMI DE JESÚS... Karla /  EDNA LEE FIGUEROA... Cristina
Entre cajas de pizza, whiskey, hamsters, celulares, Facebook, horóscopos, velones y Santa Bárbara somos cómplices de los amores, maldeamores, soledad y solidaridad de Karla y Cristina. En momentos de crisis lo que la realidad no cura, lo sobrenatural viene al rescate. Dos mujeres solteras en busca de amor y placer acuden a Santa Bárbara sin saber que Santa Bárbara… es una femme fatale.
***Among pizza boxes, whiskey, hamsters, cell phones, Facebook, horoscopes, candles and Santa Bárbara we are accomplices of love, lovesicknes, solitude and solidarity of Karla and Cristina. In times of crisis what reality can't cure, the supernatural comes to the rescue. Two single women looking for love and pleasure come to Santa Bárbara without knowing that Santa Bárbara ... is a femme fatale.
-----
Camila Monclova & Mariana Monclova escribieron esta obra de teatro, una comedia irreverente de 45 minutos que presentamos en Nueva York en abril de 2016 en un festival de teatro de comedias. 



***These two, the Monclovas, wrote this 45-minute irreverent comedy, play that we presented in New York in April 2016 as part of a comedy theater festival.    Lo que necesitamos y lo que hay para ti    ***What We Need & What You Get
 Empezando en el otoño de este año hacemos las maletas y nos vamos de gira fuera de Nueva York. La primera parada es Miami. Allí presentaremos SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE (con traducción en inglés). Edmi De Jesús y Edna Lee Figueroa junto con Producciones El Barrio vuelven a la carga.
***Beginning in the Fall of this year we pack our bags and go on tour outside New York. The first stop is Miami. There we will present SANTA BÁRBARA ES UNA FEMME FATALE (with English translation). Edmi De Jesús and Edna Lee Figueroa along with Producciones El Barrio return to the fray.
-----

story: ...

When Eyes Speak 

Last year, we had the idea along with SAFEhouse Arts to bring an Indian Choreography Festival to San Francisco. This year, along with American Conservatory Theatre's Art Share program and the Zellerbach Foundation, we are thrilled to bring you the second festival, now four days long with incredible artists from New York, India, and Malaysia.  

Artists presented this year include, Preeti Vasudevan, Rasika Kumar and Ensemble, Vaibhav Arekar, Arun Mathai, Ananya Ashok and Inner Space Dance - Temple of Fine Arts Malaysia.

 

The Curators 

Preethi Ramaprasad, Shruti Abhishek, and Sri Thina Subramaniam are three Indian classical dancers with very different backgrounds.  All three of these dancers perform passionately all over the world and came together with one unified vision:  to make the Indian arts accessible by way of music, dance, and storytelling. When Eyes Speak Festival is their contribution towards achieving this goal.  

Preethi grew up in the United States but trained in Bharatanatyam from Sudharani Raghupathy in Chennai.  She is currently pursuing her Ph.D. in Critical Dance Studies.  Shruti Abhishek grew up and studied Bharatanatyam and Theatre in Mumbai under the guidance of her guru Vaibhav Arekar.  Today, she runs her own school in the Bay Area.  Sri Thina is from Malaysia where she trained intensely in Bharatanatyam and Odissi at the Temple of Fine Arts.  She has lived in and collaborated with artists in London (where she worked with Mavin Khoo), Vancouver, San Francisco, and now New York. 

This year at When Eyes Speak, the collective will be presenting an ensemble work together, "The Affair."  This piece tells the story of an empowered woman, Radha, as she navigates her relationship with Krishna.  

 

What We Need

Your contributions will go towards the remuneration for the artists in this festival.  Although we are fortunate to receive some grants, in order for the productions to be at their best quality, we need your help to be able to pay all these artists.

 

The Impact

This festival is significant to us because it places Indian diasporic movement and choreography in a different environment; for it to be valued and understood.  We hope to foster conversations about social justice, understanding, and camaraderie through our performances and panel discussions.  Last year, When Eyes Speak helped garner curiosity in the Indian arts from the San Francisco community, and we aim to nurture this interest going forward. Our aim is to have Indian dance seen in the same light as other contemporary dance forms.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about the festival and this campaign via social media or personal messages!
  • Attend our performances, we would love to meet you!

story:
Thank you to everyone who has donated so far! Below is a video showing what your contribution has helped us work towards!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=em-upload...

Expectations

Tate and Max, both in their early twenties, chaotically co-exist in an inherited flat in Balham. The two are united by a certainty that they are special, but the world hasn't recognised it yet. Into their lives walks Billie, thirty years their senior. The boys invite her to stay with them, and secretly bet on who can sleep with her first. She doesn't know the spare room she sleeps in is already taken. 

'Expectations' is a beautifully subtle play about the tensions and tenderness between generations and genders. The writer, Matilda Curtis, was partly inspired to write the play when she saw the tagline of a Boots campaign aimed at older women: 'we are not invisible. Our age is perfect'.

We believe that the lives of older women are severely under-represented in art and culture. At a certain age, many women talk about becoming invisible, their specialness less seen, their voice less heard. This dearth of older women on stage and screen can no longer be ignored or accepted.

Expectations is a site-specific piece, set above the Bedford Pub in Balham where the production takes place.

What We Need & What You Get

We very much need your help to make this production a reality. A great deal of London fringe theatre gets put on without proper pay for the actors, and we passionately believe this should not be the case. We have met with Equity and are therefore paying actors a proper fee, but to do this we need your help. We already have some private investment to cover most of the actors' fees but we are looking for £2500 more. This will go towards:

- Publicity so as many people can hear about the show as possible

- A small fee for the theatre technician's time

- Insurance to cover the audience and actors

- Travel for the Stage Manager

- Costume, set and props

- Script printing

- Music rights

- The remainder of the actors' fees and producer fee. 

The Impact

This play is important because it touches on urgent and relevant themes: society's treatment of older women; the sexual pressure put on both genders; the frustrations and loneliness of early-20s life and the disparity between what adult life promises and the current reality. It deals with these ideas in a much more subtle and complex way than we often see on stage or screen.

The impact that your donation will give will not only allow this play to be put on, but it will also show that London fringe theatre can put on interesting new work, without treating its actors unfairly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donation, of any size, is massively appreciated. However if you can't help out financially that's fine! We are equally grateful for anyone who can give us a hand by tweeting at us, following us on Facebook, telling their friends and family, and generally helping us get the word out.

And of course there is no greater way to show your support for those project than coming along to see the show. We hope to see you there!


http://www.theatren16.co.uk/#!expectations/t77p1


The Team

Director: Grace Joseph
Assistant Director: Tilly Fletcher
Writer: Matilda Curtis
Producer: Laura Sedgwick
Assistant Producer/ Dramaturg: John King
Designer: Hannah Mac
Publicity Designer: Hannah Grace Taylor
Cinematographer: Constance Meath Baker

Cast

Billie: Denise Stephenson

Tate: Dan Furlonger

Max: George Weightman

Evie: Adele James

story:
Why We Need Your Support
This project is an incredible opportunity for Ellie Aldegheri and Lunas Dance Project to work with audiences in theatres, schools, care homes, parent groups and local public spaces. By performing in lots of different spaces and talking to a wide variety of people, the project will become truly interactive and bring the community together.  
Your donations will raise funds to cover expenses for our dancers to attend rehearsals, and to pay for performance expenses such as venue hire, technician time and promotional materials. Without this campaign, we wouldn’t be able to bring the piece to new audiences, so your support is vital to help us put this project on the map, and to share the experience with as many people as possible.

A Unique Performance to Explore and Challenge Motherhood
Motherhood is unique - from the wide variety of ways to become a mother to the multitude of mother-child relationships. Our performance piece challenges motherhood and all that comes with it: its traditions, expectations and the complex and rocky relationship between mother and daughter.

How You Can Help
All donations, small and large, bring us closer to our goal. We have some great rewards too, so don’t hesitate to press the Donate button and get your hands on them!
Even if you can’t donate, you can help us by sharing this campaign on social media, via email and by word of mouth. Don’t forget to use our hashtag #supportlunas when you share.

Thank you for visiting our page, your support is greatly appreciated!

#supportlunas
