story:
Hi all, Megan Bandelt, here. 

After a sold-out debut of GARBAGE at UNDER St. Marks Theatre in NYC in May 2016, Nj, Conor and I brought it to PortFringe Theater Festival in Portland, ME, where we were favorably reviewed, a Fringe Pick, and my face was on a magazine. After a hiatus due to Nj and I's academic obligations and my health, we're proud to be part of the 2018 FRIGID Festival, taking back residence at UNDER St. Marks Theater in the East Village.  We are unbelievably lucky  to be joined by an amazing team of talent that will be onstage and backstage to bring this show to life. 

We know theatre. We are unapologetic in making you uncomfortable.

We also know mental illness. 

I have been the most vocal about living with mental illness and the challenges faced because of it. My master's thesis was on the communal aspect healing in Greek theatre and combat-based PTSD. As a writer, I am forever in search of healing and investigating difficult topics that deserve space to be understood in our culture. 

"what she found" is about Fiona, a shadow of a girl, who is trapped in a looking-glass world that tests her ability to walk through dissociation unharmed. With influences from Lewis Carroll's darling Alice Liddell, I seek to explore one of the scariest aspects of mental illness I have experienced.

Producing this type of work is important. It is more than just another show to us. We are letting others knows they are not alone in their suffering and eradicating the stigma of mental illness that looms over us every single day. To make good on our commitment to mental health advocacy, we pledge to donate 20% of our box office sales to The Suicide Prevention Lifeline, which shares funding with the Veterans Crisis Line. 

Additionally I am not taking any funds or profit from this production, all funds raised will go to covering production costs, stipends and to our charity partner. 

Quite Simply, We need your help! 

What we have in place: 
An amazing Festival and venue awaiting our arrival! 
Our Story & Script!
An Awesome Director!
A Beautiful Choreographer
A Visionary Tech Director and Designer!
Our Captain Stage Manager! 
Our Brave & Talented Cast!

Now we need funds to put all of the elements together.

Funds from this campaign will go to:
Venue/Festival Fee
An amazing Festival and venue awaiting our arrival! 
Props, Costumes, & Special Effects
Most importantly Funds for Artist Stipends for their time & work

We would love to exceed our immediate fundraising goal!

Please join us in our quest to resume our journey through fighting the stigma and #followfiona. She needs you, and so do we. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially right now? That’s OK, just by visiting our page you have already helped! Here are some BIG ways that you can make a difference in our campaign! 

Help us go viral!  Spread the word about our campaign, share it on Facebook and Twitter, invite your friends to view our campaign, and ask them to share it too! Be an online cheerleader for Fiona. She needs it!

Every time our campaign is shared and viewed it brings us up higher in our category and helps get potential donors outside our network. IT REALLY DOES HELP! And, don’t forget that Indie Go Go has made sharing and promoting our campaign super easy! 

Want to help in other ways? WOW! Thanks you rock! Handy with a needle & thread? Like to paint or bang nails? Drive a large car or van? Want to be hands on in the making of our show? Sign up to volunteer with us! Email whatshefoundpr@gmail.com and we’ll put you to work!

THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN & FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

The what she found team
Megan, NJ, Ashleigh, Conor, Gregory, Akia, Helena, Bella, & Brenden

IT REALLY DOES HELP! And, don’t forget that Indie Go Go has made sharing and promoting our campaign super easy! Want to help in other ways? WOW! Thanks you rock! Handy with a needle & thread? Like to paint or bang nails? Drive a large car or van? Want to be hands on in the making of our show? Sign up to volunteer with us! Email whatshefoundpr@gmail.com and we’ll put you to work!THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN & FOR YOUR SUPPORT!The what she found teamMegan, NJ, Ashleigh, Conor, Gregory, Akia, Helena, Bella, & Brenden

story:
VIVO BALLET & #VIVO2K19

After an extremely successful first Fall Season, Vivo Ballet is moving into 2019 with exciting new projects and opportunities to share our love for dance and storytelling with you and the community at large.

VIVO Ballet, founded by acclaimed choreographer Enzo Celli, is a virtuosic group of artists who are working passionately to bring Celli's work and visions to new audiences everywhere.

What we need and what you get!

In the coming year, VIVO Ballet plans to produce new repertoire for the Spring Season in March 2019.  Off the heels of our last season, we are seeking a new theater opportunity with greater theatrical capabilities, rehearsal space, costumes, and increased compensation for both the dancers and the administrative staff.

We set our goal at $10,000 to guarantee the development our company needs in  order to reach national and international audiences starting with you… New York!  

To match the generosity of your contributions, we are pleased to offer a number of unique gifts in exchange for your love and support. For example, those donating at least $100.00+ receive a guest pass to one of Enzo Celli's classes (which can be gifted to a dancer you know ), a free t-shirt, and one free ticket to our Spring Season 2019.

Should we fall short of our goal this time, any money gained will be directed to the cost of the theater, with ticket sales and private donations making up payment for the dancers.

As to now, VIVO Ballet has been a labor of love for both Celli and his amazing team. All of the tools to create great art are in place, all that is missing is your support to make this dream a reality.

The Impact

VIVO Ballet's presence in New York City is very important. Our work combines European sensibility with the technical prowess and artistry of American trained dancers. This rare combination allows us to bridge cultural gaps, and expose New York to something that it has never seen before.  

In 2019, VIVO Ballet will be implementing an outreach program to support education in the arts for New York Public Schools. With the resources to allot to our show, we will be able to help provide children with the benefits that an education in the arts cultivates. Additionally, this will provide our dancers with additional work, serving to recognize their expertise, train them as educators, and develop them as caretakers for their community.

Going forward, we also plan to create new opportunities for dancers in New York City to train with artists from Europe.

Risks & Challenges

The largest challenge we face in our success is the extreme concentration of dance in New York City. There is so much work to support and sometimes people aren't sure where their contributions will be useful.

What separates us from others is that the stories we make are not just for the dance world or for ourselves. The stories we tell are for everyone. Your contribution to our campaign can help us have a lasting impression on audiences for years to come. That starts with your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

While donating is the best way you can contribute there are many other ways to help us out as well!

  • Ask someone to donate on your behalf
  • Follow us on social media 
  • Share the campaign on your own Facebook and Twitter
  • Share our videos and thank you messages on any social media platform, including Instagram
  • Include the hashtag #VIVO2K19 on social media to help guide people to the campaign

Indiegogo has tools to help you share this wherever you like!

Thanks for reading to the bottom of the campaign! We'll see you at the top!

story:
Summary

Your support will not only allow us to bring to life a new and relevant play, but also officially kick off our theatre company! Indomitus Theatre was founded on the notion that all art must be brave, compassionate, and captivating. As young artists, we wanted to create our own opportunity to create, direct, act, and produce our own work. This production of Start Swimming directed by Alexandra Fiallos was workshopped earlier this year at LACC Theatre Academy and was a hit! With your help, we will be able remount this production and share this vital story with a broader audience.

What We Need 

All the money raised through Indiegogo fundraiser will cover:

  • The rights of the show
  • Renting the venue 
  • Marketing
  • Expenses of Fringe 
  • Production aspects of the show such as costumes and set. etc.

It definitely takes more than a village to produce a show and that is it why we need your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you live in the Los Angeles area, come check out the show! We open June 7th at the Hollywood Fringe Festival and run all the way to the 29th. In addition, share this page with all of your friends and family to help spread the word.

Thank you so much for your time and supporting young artists.

story:
January Is For Making Dances

NACHMO is an annual choreography challenge open to everyone. Inspired by National Novel Writing Month, Sharyn and Anna started it in the fall of 2009 as a way to push ourselves to do creative work and hold ourselves to a deadline. At the time, we were two busy dancers without a lot of time or money to devote to choreographing. But we thought if we gave ourselves a deadline and worked alongside a group of fellow dance artists, we could each create a dance in a month. We recruited four friends to join us, and launched National Choreography Month.

Each year, more participants join, attracted by the challenge, the community it builds, and the opportunity to show new dance work as part of a mixed bill. In the past 8 years, there have been NACHMO shows in Brooklyn, Boston, DC, San Francisco, and Columbus. Last season, we had over 230 people participate and this season we hope to have over 300.

Making a new dance can be quite expensive and time consuming - paying for studio space to rehearse in, finding and compensating dancers, renting a performance venue, marketing the show, employing a photographer or videographer to document the performance - it can be a daunting process to jump into. That's why we take care of the production side of things so participants can focus on the dance making.

 

What We Need To Make NACHMO Happen...

The NACHMO challenge can be done on a shoestring. Every year some awesome solos are crafted in bedrooms at no expense to anyone. But bringing people together and producing the shows that celebrate the new dances takes some cash. Specifically:

  • Participants register for the challenge through the website. It's updated by our volunteer staff, but we do have to pay GoDaddy ($60) and Squarespace ($180).
  • The theater we rent for our Brooklyn shows costs $1600 for two nights. It's a great deal because they provide front of house staff, an awesome lighting designer, and tech rehearsal the afternoon before each show. But we have to buy event insurance ($125).
  • We rely heavily on social media and word of mouth to let people know about NACHMO, but some well-placed postcards are critical to attracting participants and audience ($35).

 

The Impact

We'll let our 2016 participants speak for us here:

"It connects me to others who have the creative gene but don't act on it nearly enough. It is a yearly reminder to expand myself, and do something with my ideas."

"I think as artists we tend to be dreamers. This opportunity forced us to move forward with our thoughts and sometimes we need that push to just get out of our heads and go for it."

"NACHMO provided me with the push (hello one month deadline!) I needed to move past my doubts, excuses, and insecurities and just create work! It then went further and gave me a platform to share this work. The reason this was especially important to me is because I find that it can be very challenging to find opportunities such as this for choreographers that are not established. NACHMO also connected me to a community of dancers, choreographers, and artists that have inspired me and provided invaluable advice on continuing to navigate what it means to be a dancer and the myriad ways dance can be pursued."

 

Perks!

We're grateful for a gift of any amount, and we'd love to thank you with a postcard, a glossy printed dance photo, a personalized senryu, or any of the perks listed at right.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes there's no cash to spare, but there's always a way to help:

  • Send us some love on Facebook and Twitter
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Want to volunteer for NACHMO? email us at info@nachmo.org
  • Or perhaps you've been so inspired by the video, photos and enthusiastic quotes that you want to try your hand at making a dance. Do it!

 NACHMO is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of NACHMO must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Hi, there. I'm Peter Foldy. I hope you’ve had a chance to look at our video presentation, but in case you’ve skipped it, here some info on myself and the project. I’m a writer / director with a number of feature films under my belt. Prior to my life in film I had the good fortune to enjoy some success in the music business.

Life in the arts is always a roller coaster ride but it’s what I love to do. I’m now making a foray into the world of theater with a cheeky little comedy that I am directing called Penetration. It is scheduled for seven performances during the Hollywood Fringe Festival and I’m here on Indiegogo because I need your help. The venue has been booked, the wheels are in motion but the production is currently $3,250 underfunded and we now have 15 days in which to raise this money.

It’s not a huge amount but essential to making the project happen. The funds we raise will go toward rehearsal space rentals, poster design, printing of cards, programs and posters, essential crew such as Stage Managers - as well as the all important promotion and publicity. Myself, the producer and the actors are not taking any of the cash that we hope to raise. It's all going into making this show happen.

So why does this matter, and why should you give us a helping hand?

Because Art Matters.

It helps us see the world from different perspectives. It allows us to reflect on our own lives and it brings people together. By contributing to this production you would become a part of something unique -  your support immensely appreciated.

About The Play

It’s the night before the 2016 Presidential election. Though Cody Weber has taken a purity pledge with his conservative fiancé, Linda, to not have sex until they are married, he can’t help but secretly visit an internet chat room where he meets an attractive young model named Amanda. Overcome by guilt he doesn’t go through with the video encounter but is shocked when the girl shows up in his apartment. With Cody’s fiancé returning in the morning and Amanda unable (or unwilling) to leave, Cody has a life changing decision to make.

Our Producer:

Cas Hodges, an experienced UK theater producer with over 20 productions under her belt, including a number of Edinburgh Fringe productions.

Our Cast:

Trent Brown, Julia Henning, Alex Sturman and Swayde McCoy are extremely talented actors, all working hard on this play in order to showcase their talent and this production at the 2017 Hollywood Fringe Festival.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute financially, please help us by sharing the link for this campaign. Tell a friend. Post it on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

https://www.facebook.com/ptheplay/

https://twitter.com/penetration2017

THANK YOU!!!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Spencer Frankeberger, and I received a BM in Music Therapy and an MFA in Film Production from Florida State University where I created a zany, drag queen-filled short musical film that I felt had more of a story to it than being just a "fun, campy show," and I decide to write and compose my own live stage show version of it to express topics of masculinity, acceptance, and keeping hope alive.

This project is a labor of love filled with an array of quirkiness, fun, and some of the catchiest songs you can imagine!

What We Need & What You Get

As putting up a theatrical production can be expensive, Hollywood Fringe adds additional rates, such as registration fees and specific marketing requirements.  That being said, here's what your gracious donations go toward:

~$400/performance x5 = $2000

stipend/cast and crew = $3500

scripts and props = $100

marketing assistance (flyering, printing postcards, additional marketing, impressions) = $500

rehearsal space = $500

registration fee = $250

insurance = $200

IndieGoGo taxes = $500

Additional Expenses = $550

Total: $8, 100

While this is a lot to ask, any and ALL donations do help me reach the goal that I hope to achieve with this fundraising campaign.

We have some really unique and individual perks including YOUR VERY OWN, PERSONALIZED JINGLE on GUITAR, PIANO, A CAPPELLA, or with PERCUSSION as well as some other perks such as soundtrack downloads, a download of the performance, comp tickets to the show, etc.

The Impact

I want to share this project to provide another production that pushes the boundaries of musical theatre and promotes more than just a fluffy musical--proving that musicals can have depth and engaging subject matter while also being fun, quirky, catchy, and campy as well.

Risks & Challenges

One of the biggest risks with producing theatre is the budget.  Having recently been the supervising producer for a theatrical production, I understand how much work is put into a production (I've stage managed, assistant directing, been props master, etc. for other productions) and how much others are willing to sacrifice to make your vision become a reality.  I understand that long hours will pay off, but that it's a long road to get there, and I'm willing to do whatever it takes, even saving up to put on this production myself, even if it takes more time--but it's ready now.

Other Ways You Can Help

While these donations won't necessarily break the bank, I completely understand if your financial situation is not beneficial for your ability to donate right now, and all I ask is that, even if you cannot donate even just a dollar or two, that you like our FB page and follow us on Twitter and Instagram and then share this project with everyone you know.

story:
ABOUT US

Theater 2020 is the only professional Equity theater based in Brooklyn Heights. Founded in 2010, Theater 2020’s mission is dedicated to reaching out to the community and to producing quality theater that is affordable or FREE, utilizing established professionals and fostering young artists as they emerge into the theatrical mainstream.

We are committed to diversity and inclusion, always seeking ways to cast, as our union says, “Non-traditionally,” and we are particularly aware of the gender disparity in our profession, so we have a particular emphasis on providing more opportunities for women in theater.

We produce classic and contemporary plays and musicals for a 21st Century audience and provide a nurturing atmosphere for emerging artists to work alongside seasoned professionals in a positive program of creativity.

We founded “Shakespeare at Sunset,” in 2011 and we continue to- provide FREE performances outdoors for our community, now in Cadman Plaza Park. We present our FREE “Hearthside Reading Series,” stage readings of new plays and neglected classics, every few months at the Brooklyn Heights Public Library. We produce a full scale musical each winter in our neighborhood, offering tickets at prices well below Off Broadway, including deeply discounted tickets to seniors and students, plus FREE tickets to certain groups as well. Our two recent musicals: the multi-nominated and award winning, audience adored and critically acclaimed “A Little Night Music” in 2016 and “Sweeney Todd” in 2017. We plan to continue our foray into the world of Sondheim with “Assassins” in 2018. But we need your help to continue!

Theater 2020, Visions for a new Millennium is guided by award winning theater artists David Fuller and Judith Jarosz who have produced and directed well over a hundred shows, Regionally, Off Broadway, and in NYC’s Indie Theatre (Off Off Broadway). They have been recognized with multiple awards and nominations including The National GLAAD awards, OOBR Awards, NYtheatre.com People of the Year, and New York Innovative Theater Awards.

We believe live performance is an important part of a healthy culture and we are committed to diversity, remaining dedicated to our multi-cultural Brooklyn audiences and artists alike. Please help us to continue this vital work by making a tax-deductible donation today and play a huge part in supporting Theater 2020’s continuing vision!

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Theater 2020's first home was damaged in a storm requiring extensive interior rehabilitation that is ongoing. We lost our rehearsal and performance space! Our recent venue had NO availability for 2018. But through your generosity we were able to secure the beautiful Founders Theater at St. Frances College in Brooklyn Heights for Sondheim's ASSASSINS and the critically acclaimed production was wonderful! However, rental costs continue to rise everywhere and we still need your help to cover the rent for our 2018 season. For new donations - all of the perks continue to apply however - tickets awarded will be for AS U LIKE IT instead of ASSASSINS which has completed a successful run. 

Theater 2020, Inc. is officially incorporated as a 501(c)(3) non-profit, so ANY donation you make to us a TAX DEDUCTIBLE contribution for you! We are also offering all kinds of “thank you” incentives at multiple levels of giving! Check them out!

YOUR IMPACT

Thanks to you - hundreds of people can continue to see low cost or FREE Theater 2020 professional level events and productions and we would be able to continue our support for emerging performers, diversity in our community and greater opportunities for women artists.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to contribute even $10, there are many other ways that you can still help! Help spread the word about our campaign to others, follow Theater 2020 on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, or just attend an event!  We would love to have you be a part of our community. Reservations for tickets for “Assassins” can be made at https://th2020assassins.bpt.me

We are always looking for volunteers for various aspects of our productions. Additionally if you have any services, materials, or other in-kind donations in lieu of monetary contributions, please email us at theater2020 at gmail.com to learn more!
story_txt: ABOUT USTheater 2020 is the only professional Equity theater based in Brooklyn Heights. Founded in 2010, Theater 2020’s mission is dedicated to reaching out to the community and to producing quality theater that is affordable or FREE, utilizing established professionals and fostering young artists as they emerge into the theatrical mainstream.We are committed to diversity and inclusion, always seeking ways to cast, as our union says, “Non-traditionally,” and we are particularly aware of the gender disparity in our profession, so we have a particular emphasis on providing more opportunities for women in theater.We produce classic and contemporary plays and musicals for a 21st Century audience and provide a nurturing atmosphere for emerging artists to work alongside seasoned professionals in a positive program of creativity.We founded “Shakespeare at Sunset,” in 2011 and we continue to- provide FREE performances outdoors for our community, now in Cadman Plaza Park. We present our FREE “Hearthside Reading Series,” stage readings of new plays and neglected classics, every few months at the Brooklyn Heights Public Library. We produce a full scale musical each winter in our neighborhood, offering tickets at prices well below Off Broadway, including deeply discounted tickets to seniors and students, plus FREE tickets to certain groups as well. Our two recent musicals: the multi-nominated and award winning, audience adored and critically acclaimed “A Little Night Music” in 2016 and “Sweeney Todd” in 2017. We plan to continue our foray into the world of Sondheim with “Assassins” in 2018. But we need your help to continue!Theater 2020, Visions for a new Millennium is guided by award winning theater artists David Fuller and Judith Jarosz who have produced and directed well over a hundred shows, Regionally, Off Broadway, and in NYC’s Indie Theatre (Off Off Broadway). They have been recognized with multiple awards and nominations including The National GLAAD awards, OOBR Awards, NYtheatre.com People of the Year, and New York Innovative Theater Awards.We believe live performance is an important part of a healthy culture and we are committed to diversity, remaining dedicated to our multi-cultural Brooklyn audiences and artists alike. Please help us to continue this vital work by making a tax-deductible donation today and play a huge part in supporting Theater 2020’s continuing vision!WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GETTheater 2020's first home was damaged in a storm requiring extensive interior rehabilitation that is ongoing. We lost our rehearsal and performance space! Our recent venue had NO availability for 2018. But through your generosity we were able to secure the beautiful Founders Theater at St. Frances College in Brooklyn Heights for Sondheim's ASSASSINS and the critically acclaimed production was wonderful! However, rental costs continue to rise everywhere and we still need your help to cover the rent for our 2018 season. For new donations - all of the perks continue to apply however - tickets awarded will be for AS U LIKE IT instead of ASSASSINS which has completed a successful run. Theater 2020, Inc. is officially incorporated as a 501(c)(3) non-profit, so ANY donation you make to us a TAX DEDUCTIBLE contribution for you! We are also offering all kinds of “thank you” incentives at multiple levels of giving! Check them out!YOUR IMPACTThanks to you - hundreds of people can continue to see low cost or FREE Theater 2020 professional level events and productions and we would be able to continue our support for emerging performers, diversity in our community and greater opportunities for women artists.OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPIf you are unable to contribute even $10, there are many other ways that you can still help! Help spread the word about our campaign to others, follow Theater 2020 on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, or just attend an event!  We would love to have you be a part of our community. Reservations for tickets for “Assassins” can be made at https://th2020assassins.bpt.meWe are always looking for volunteers for various aspects of our productions. Additionally if you have any services, materials, or other in-kind donations in lieu of monetary contributions, please email us at theater2020 at gmail.com to learn more!

story:
What is Together We Gather?

We're a group of performers, friends, former teachers and students, youth and adults, who have come together this summer to make art again. It's a reaction to the past 18 months, but mostly it's about what has come up for us in the now. Informally, in several meetings over the course of the summer, we started with exploring the idea of what is ordinary and what is extraordinary. How something can be one or the other, or both. We gathered outside in parks and backyards when we could, played theater games, had conversations, created scenes and characters, and let ourselves explore. 

What we've workshopped from that time is a series of observations that have branched out from our initial ordinary/extraordinary theme. Some became silly sketches, others more introspective monologues and some are a little bit of both. It's not a play in the way we often think of a play, with a beginning, middle and end, perfectly polished and perfected. But, it is play. 

Our commitment to each other.

You'll see that in some moments actors may have a script in their hand or read from their phone. Some nights one actor will step in for another to play a part in order to accommodate schedules and other life obligations. Part of our process was to also be supportive of where each artist was at throughout our time together and not let other priorities or obligations preclude anyone from participating. 

How can you help?

Together We Gather is free for all audiences! We wanted to make financially accessible art while also respecting our performers' contributions by providing them with a modest stipend. Your donation will help cover stipend amounts, as well as the cost of props and other incidentals. Any money contributed beyond our $500 campaign goal and donations at the show will be split evenly among artists. 

How do I see the show?

Performances will be held over four nights at the end of this month.

Saturday, August 21st  & Sunday August 22nd  at a home in Lincoln Square 

Saturday, August 28th  & Sunday 29th at the Ridgeville Park District in Evanston

There  is limited seating for 8/21 & 8/22  and unlimited open seating on 8/28 & 8/29

For the Lincoln Square performances reservations are required for Evanston performances reservations are suggested so we can best plan how to lay out our space in a safe, socially distanced fashion. 

YOU CAN RESERVE SEATS HERE.

Thank You!

Together we gather. We invite you to gather too.

Krista D'Agostino

Christina Lepri

John Taflan

Lily Benjamin

Lauren Guevara

Foster Pratt

Jeremiah Davis

Moira Begale

Vincent Perez

Honor Weinman

story:
Vincent Van Gogh...the original emo...

My name is Matt DeMaria.  I'm a musician from Long Island.  I've been working in theater as long as I could be working.  Both on stage as an actor as well as a music director.  I've had the privilege of touring with the Rent 20th Anniversary Tour as its music director.  But now i'm finally attempting to pursue my true passion: storytelling.  

I've spent the better part of 2 years writing a musical about famed artists Vincent Van Gogh.  Utilizing a mix of emo, punk rock, and progressive rock to tell his tragic, yet beautiful story.  Earlier this year I was able to release a concept album (available on all stream services!) whose proceeds were donated to charity.  Now it's time to workshop a real production.

After a full year without live theater...I'm excited to bring this to a small audience.  

We want to get some real artists who have been sitting around for a year waiting for their industry to come back some work!  

We need funds to hire the following positions:

• An audio engineer who can mix the show live

• A videographer to capture the performance

• A lighting designer

• A music director who will teach vocals and conductor the band

• 9 musicians to play the show

• Pay for the actors!

Our $5000 goal will allow us to hire these artists and provide them with the work they've been sorely missing!

If you're unable to contribute...that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Help us get word out and make some noise about the show!
  • Check out the album on Spotify, Apple Music or any preferred streaming service.

story:
Contributions for the purposes of Heathens must be made payable to Theater for the New City and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 

The Basics

 

In March 2012, Theater for the New City, an Obie-winning performance venue in downtown Manhattan, will present the world premiere of Heather Hill's play Heathens, directed by Stefanie Sertich.


Set on an isolated farm in eastern Kentucky, Heathens is an unsettling comedy that makes the term "family values" take on new meaning. When a wandering laborer follows a woman home for the night, he finds a lot more than he bargains for in the home she shares with her sister and her Mamaw. The play explores mourning, faith, and the dangers of isolation as the characters do battle with themselves and each other.

 

Our team has been collaborating on this play for over a year and a half in workshops and readings.  We have put together a fabulous group. The cast includes Lisa Roberts Gillan, Linda Larkin, Trevor Long, and Andy Powers. Edward Ross is the set designer, and Dan Jobbins is the lighting designer.

 

What We're Asking for and What You Receive

 

Theater for the New City is providing the performance and rehearsal space, but we must still raise the funds for all of the production elements -- creating a set evocative of the sisters' Kentucky home, the guys' costumes (as Andy so eloquently says in the video), a Christmas tree.... Yes, we said a Christmas tree. Come see the play and you'll see why! And we also need to pay for the set build, sound equipment, a stage manager... the list is very specific, but rather lengthy.

 

In thanks for your support, besides our unending gratitude, we have all of the fabulous perks listed to the side, ranging from trendy Heathens baseball caps to your own private harp concert!


  • Heathens Website
  • Theater for the New City Website

 


The Team



Heather Hill

Playwright

 

Heather Hill, a native of Kentucky, is a playwright, lyricist, and librettist.  Her plays have received readings and workshops at numerous theaters, including the Royal Court, the Orange Tree Playhouse in Richmond, England, the New Group, Primary Stages, the Vineyard Theater, the Kitchen Theater, the Belt, and the Horizon Theater in Atlanta. 


Her play Notes from the Confederacy was developed under the mentorship of A.R. Gurney and the Cherry Lane Theater.  Her play Eulogy for Boris the Relic Hunter, commissioned by The Regional Theater Company, was included in RTC's festival of shorts. Ms. Hill directed and co-wrote That Play, a one-man Macbeth, which enjoyed a sold out run at the Midtown International Fringe Festival.


Bruce Weber of the New York Times wrote of That Play, "Tom Gualtieri and his co-adapter and director, Heather Hill, have hit on an effective story-telling formula."  Ms. Hill went on to direct That Play at the Kitchen Theater in Ithaca, as well as the Belt in New York. 

 

Ms. Hill is the recipient of two Hopwood Drama Awards, as well as a grant from the Kentucky Foundation for Women.  In addition, she is a two-time finalist for the Princess Grace Award and a finalist for the Manhattan Theatre Club Fellowship.  She received her M.F.A. from Columbia University where she was a Presidential Scholar.  She is a member of the BMI Musical Theater Workshop.


  • Heather Hill Website
  • Heather Hill Facebook Page


Stefanie Sertich

Director


Stefanie is a director and choreographer, living in Brooklyn, NY.   She is in her first year as an Assistant Professor at LaGuardia Community College in Queens.  She will be directing Dead Man's Cell Phone (Waterfront Playhouse, Key West FL) in February 2011 and the world premiere of Heathens, by Heather Hill in March 2011 ( Theatre for the New City, New York City).  Last fall, she directed Picnic at Western Oregon University where she was a guest artist and faculty member.  In spring 2010, she directed the world premiere of Eduardo Machado's Havana Journal, 2004 (INTAR Theatre/ Theater for the New City). Other NY directing credits include: Like You Like It (The Broadway Workshop), Animal Farm (The Neighborhood Playhouse), The Dome (Prospect Theatre), Museum Pieces (Prospect Theatre), Do Gooder (The Public- NYU MFA workshop), The Useless Man (INTAR New Works Lab). Regional: Animal Farm (The New Rep in Boston), Electra, (Classic Greek Theatre of Oregon- Winner KC/ACTF Directing Award), Kimberly Akimbo (Salem Rep Theatre).  Asst. directing includes Artfuckers (dir. Eduardo Machado, DR2) West Moon Street (dir. Davis McCallum, Prospect Theatre) Napoli Millionaria! (dir. Libby Appel, Oregon Shakespeare Festival).  Summer Stock:  Cole Porter's You Never Know and Annie (Millbrook Playhouse). Stef has directed pilot workshops for ITheatrics and Disney Theatricals which include Disney's High School Musical JR., Disney's Aladdin Kids, Disney's Beauty and the Beast JR, and The Musical Adventures of Flat Stanley.  Stef also assistant directed the National Tour of A Year with Frog and Toad and The Musical Adventures of Flat Stanley (dir. Tim McDonald).

Stef was a F.A.I.R recipient in directing at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in 2005, Alternate Winner for the SSDC Directing Fellowship (Region VII), KC/ACTF, 2005, Meritorious Achievement Award for Direction of Electra, KC/ACTF, 2005, Runner-Up, SSDC Directing Fellowship (Region VII), KC/ACTF 2004. BA Acting (Western Michigan University), MFA Directing (University of Portland).

 

  • Stefanie Sertich Website

story:
Magnet Theatre  has been committed to transformation in the theatre industry  in South Africa for the past 25 years. They are an award winning physical theatre company based in Cape Town in South Africa. Magnet Theatre believes that we all have a responsibility to develop a more just, free and peaceful South African society. Transformation can never be only about developing skill. Fundamentally it involves developing  creativity, the ability to imagine alternative realities and dream different futures.

Magnet Theatre runs a full time training program for young township performers who cannot for one reason or another gain access to tertiary institutions like the university or the theatre profession. The 2 year training acts as a bridge into the universities and into the professional performance industry as a whole.

Lat year as part of their training , with support from ASSITEJ and Roberto Frabetti from La Barracca, the trainees made a theatre project for 3 -5 years old to take to the most forgotten child care centres and crèches of the Cape Town townships.  TREE/ BOOM/ UMTHI is a delicate tender performance about the relationship between a man and a tree and the seasons. It is performed in three different languages depending on the audience and uses song, image and the physical body to tell the story .


Theatre for the very young is a new territory of performance that is opening up in South Africa thanks to the efforts of ASSITEJ South Africa. Magnet Theatre understands it to be extremely important as a way to nourish intelligence and to develop sensibility and competencies in the very young.


TREE/ BOOM/ UMTHI has now been invited to perform at the FESTIVAL FOR EARLY YEARS IN Bologna Italy in March 2014. For all 5 performers it will be the very first time that they have the opportunity to travel outside of South Africa.

By helping these young people you will:

  • Support their first ever trip outside of South Africa
  • Allow them to showcase their work on an international platform
  • Allow them to gain in confidence and visibility not only to themselves but to an international audience
  • Allow them to observe and learn  from other baby theatre projects
  • Help them learn grow and access the inspiration so that they can follow their dreams to come back to South Africa and grow theatre for the very young in their own communities

ITALIAN:

Giovani attori delle township del Capo, in Sud Africa, invitati a presentare il loro spettacolo in Italia.

5 giovani attori delle township del Capo, che non hanno mai viaggiato fuori dal Sud Africa, sono stati invitati a presentare il loro spettacolo a un festival internazionale di teatro per l'infanzia in Italia.

Lo spettacolo ALBERO / BOOM / UMTHI è stato invitato al festival “VISIONI DI FUTURO, VISIONI DI TEATRO”- FESTIVAL INTERNAZIONALE DI TEATRO E CULTURA PER LA PRIMA INFANZIA a Bologna, in Italia,  nel marzo 2014.

I 5 giovani attori avranno per la prima volta l'opportunità di viaggiare fuori dal Sudafrica.

Aiutando questi giovani potrete:

  • Sostenere il loro primo viaggio fuori del Sud Africa
  • Consentirgli di mostrare il loro lavoro ad un festival internazionale
  • Permettergli o di acquisire fiducia e visibilità non solo per loro stessi, ma anche di fronte a un pubblico internazionale
  • Consentirgli di osservare e acquisire altre conoscenze sul teatro per la prima infanzia

Aiutarli a imparare, a crescere e a coltivare l'ispirazione, in modo che possano seguire il loro sogno di tornare in Sudafrica e far crescere il teatro per i più piccoli nelle loro comunità



THIS IS THE BUDGET

Salaries  for 2 weeks (1 week rehearsal , 1 week performance)

4 performers @ R2000 per week

$1600 (covered by La Barracca and Magnet THeatre)

1 technician @ R2000 per week

$400 (covered by Magnet Theatre and La Barraca)

Directors Fee

$1000 (Covered by Magnet Theatre)

Transport for 6 company members (4 performers, 1 technician, Director)

Flights from CT to Bologna @ R14 000 per flight

$8400

VISAS

Approx $70 X6 = $420 ( Possibly Covered by the Italian Embassy in SA)

Accommodation

Accommodation for 6 people in single rooms for 5 nights and 6 days

Covered by La Baracca

S&T  for 6 days for 6 company members @ R150 per day

$540 (covered by La Baracca)

TOTAL

$12360

AMOUNT REQUESTED

$8400

THIS IS WHAT WE NEED

We need $8400 to cover the cost of the Air flights for  the 4 performers, the Technician and the Director from Cape Town, South Africa to Bologna in Italy.

Please help by posting on you facebook page, twitter and send to your data bases. Use the indiegogo sharing tools!!

  members (4 performers, 1 technician, Director)




Flights from CT to Bologna @ R14 000 per flight 


$8400




VISAS


Approx $70 X6 = $420 (
  Possibly Covered by the Italian Embassy in SA)




Accommodation




Accommodation for 6 people in single rooms for 5 nights and 6 days


Covered by La Baracca




S&T  for 6 days for 6
  company members @ R150 per day 


$540 (covered by La
  Baracca)




TOTAL


$12360




AMOUNT REQUESTED


$8400



THIS IS
WHAT WE NEED
We need
$8400 to cover the cost of the Air flights for 
the 4 performers, the Technician and the Director from Cape Town, South Africa to Bologna in Italy.


Please help by posting on you facebook page, twitter and send to your data bases. Use the indiegogo sharing tools!!

story:
Your contribution will help us win a full theatrical production at the legendary Teatro La Tea in NYC!

The One Festival

One performer… One stage… One winner!

The festival seeks the best of local New York City based and international actors for a one person performance where nightly audience vote for their favorite festival participant. The festival is designed for multiethnic audiences and is staffed by experienced and skilled Latinos, as directors, producers and writers.

The winner will receive a full theatrical production at the legendary Teatro La Tea in New York's Lower East Side!

We are putting all our efforts with this play toward that goal, and your contribution will help us create a great production to win.

Ron Sarcos will perform in the play Efectos Personales at this event. We're currently in the first phase of our fundraising, and we need your help to make it happen!

The ONE Festival will have a two-week theatrical run, with multi-talented playwrights and performing artists from all over the world. This annual event will showcase theatrical works from men and women of solo performances.

What We Need

Money raised will be used towards:

  • Paying for the Legal Rights to perform the play
  • Stage/set design
  • Basic catering for crew 
  • Purchasing and/or renting props, costume, and accessories. 
  • Provision of crew stipends. (i.e. tech crew)
  • Advertising and promotion (i.e. posters, postcards...)
  • Rental Space rehearsal 

Keep in mind that the more money we raise, the cooler play we can make.

The Play

A musician arrives to an empty station from where he plans to return home. During his long wait for the train, the man begins pondering his own existence, his condition as an artist, his decisions, the meaning of things. He reconsiders his life and he questions what he is doing in that place and even the reasons for so much luggage. He knows exactly what is in each bag except one, the smallest one. That one who reveals to him the reality of being.

(The actor will use the original script of the play, so he will use the Spanish language)

Other Ways You Can Help

We thank you for any and all monetary support you're able to provide; however, we understand that many of you are unable to contribute financially to our campaign. Regardless, we'd so appreciate your help spreading the word about our project via Facebook and Twitter! You can help by spreading the link to this Indiegogo page in a status update or a tweet.
 
If you would like to help in any other capacity, please contact sokchu@gmail.com or 917-586-2077.
 
Thank you so much for your support!
 
The performance with the highest votes will be the ONE winner so please remember to see the show and vote for Efectos Personales.
 
The One Festival presents
Efectos Personales by Griselda Gambaro
Teatro La Tea
107 Suffolk St. New York, NY 10002
April 3, 9, 12 @ 8pm
 
Buy tickets here: http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?EID=&showCode=ONE62&BundleCode=&PackageCode=&GUID=47c8ab7f-66b8-4f0b-9c12-abe8bbaf428f

story:
In Haitian oral storytelling, the griot- or storyteller- invites its audience to listen by saying " Krik?", the audience, if they choose to listen respond with " Krak!".

Welcome to Krik Krak Collective's Indiegogo page!

Our names are Cassandre Mentor and Bryan James;  together we have founded Krik Krak Collective because we have a story to share with you...

...but we need your help!

We have already received a generous amount of support from the MAI (Montreal, arts interculturels) mentorship program but we still need a little ways to go in order to bring this piece to life. We need a minimum of 545$ in order to:

1) Pay for the rental of our set and costumes ( 350$)

2) Pay for our advertising and promotional materials (195$)

 

Please know that ANY support helps- including spreading the word to your friends and family about the show :)

 

We are forever grateful to all of you for your support, thank you for believing in our project- we can't wait for you to see the show!

Peace & Love,

Cassandre Mentor and Bryan James

story:
THANK YOU to everyone who helped us surpass our support goal!

This site will remain up to provide up-to-date information regarding the show.

TICKETS are now available at www.cupcaketheater.com - click "Tickets" at the top of the home page, then click forward on the calendar to reach February or March, and select the show you would like to attend!

SHOW DATES:  

(All performances are at The Cupcake Theater at 6520 Hollywood Blvd, Hollywood, CA 90028)

Sat February 15th ~ Opening Night Gala ~ 7pm Gala, 8pm Show SOLD OUT
Sun February 16th ~ 2pm
Sat February 22nd ~ 8pm
Sun February 23rd ~ 2pm ~ Talkback immediately following
Fri February 28th ~ 8pm
Sat March 1st ~ 8pm 
Sun March 2nd ~ 2pm ~ Talkback immediately following 
Fri March 7th ~ 8pm 
Sat March 8th ~ 8pm 
Sun March 9th ~ 2pm  ~ Talkback immediately following

Talk-Back Series

We have officially scheduled three talk-backs with Holocaust survivors after the show.  They will occur immediately following our February 23rd, March 2nd, and March 9th matinee performances.  All audience members are encouraged to remain after the show to participate.  Talk-Backs will be moderated by third generation Holocaust survivor Sigi Gradwohl, and will feature additional cast members as well.  


If you have any questions regarding this production of The Diary of Anne Frank, or this campaign, please email annefrankcupcake@gmail.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Producer's Note

Hello, I'm Caity, producer of The Diary of Anne Frank at The Cupcake Theater. Sigi approached me a few months ago with the desire to put up this production. My answer was immediately yes, not only because of Sigi's talent and experience as an actress, or the fact that she has almost booked this role several times in the past decade, but because of her incredibly close connection to Anne. Since then, we have been collaborating to create not just a show, but an eclectic experience, complementing the play with talkbacks and process groups aimed at involving the community in this production and opening a conversation about the Holocaust. With the commitment of our cast and crew, director Sabrina Lloyd,The Cupcake Theater, and you, we look forward to bringing it all to life!

Sigi Gradwohl and Anne Frank

At our first cast read-through, one of our cast members said to Sigi, "Wow, you really look like Anne!" Sigi shares many similarities with Anne; she's talkative, the youngest in the family, impatient, creative, feisty, the girl everyone knows, and has a shared disinterest in math.

                                       Anne Frank and Sigi Gradwohl

But it is her family's connection to Anne Frank that really drove her desire to play this role. Sigi's grandfather, Peter Neuhaus, was in Anne's class, pictured below, in what was likely the last photo taken with Anne in it.

Anne's class at Montessori Primary School in Amsterdam. She can be seen standing in the back right wearing white, next to her teacher. Sigi's grandfather, Peter, is seated in the middle of the classroom, grinning. Click here for an article about Peter and Anne.

For much of her life, Sigi's connection to Anne was simply a stated fact. Over the past few years, Sigi's older sister Nirit Gradwohl Pisano, a psychologist who specializes in the intergenerational transmission of trauma, started delving into the trauma inherited by the third generation of the Holocaust. Nirit's work inspired Sigi to begin contemplating the effects on her own life as a third generation survivor. Were it not for the luck of her grandfather's father having a Swiss passport, and her grandmother (pictured below) escaping Germany on one of the last Kindertransports to England, her family's fate could have been the same as that of the Franks. Sigi began to comprehend why she so strongly relates to the material.

Sigi's grandmother, Esther Gradwohl-Wajsblat (second from the left), escaped Germany at the age of seven with her older sister, Fani (second from the right), on one of the last Kindertransports to London. Her mother (left), eldest sister Toni (middle), and father (right) perished in the Holocaust.

Why help this particular production?

Because of Sigi's close connection to Anne Frank, and, coincidentally, the close connection to the Holocaust of many of our additional cast members, we do not simply want this to be a good show. We will be incorporating various elements to bring the experience to life, and open up a dialogue about the Holocaust and its lingering effects today. To do all this, we need support to cover both basic expenses and our enhanced concept for this production. These expenses include:

  • Materials to transform the stage into the annex where Anne and her family and the Van Daans hid for two years, including lighting and period-appropriate wardrobe
  • Performance rights through Dramatists Play Services and use of the Cupcake Theater
  • Scheduled talkbacks by invited guests, including Holocaust survivors
  • Process group with the cast led by psychologist, Holocaust-researcher, and author Dr. Nirit Gradwohl Pisano (Sigi's sister)
  • Material needed for live web stream sessions to reach a wider audience

The rights have been purchased and our performance dates are set, so even if we are unable to reach our fundraising goal, this production will move forward. We hope that you see the value in providing the community with this dialogue, and choose to support our efforts! Either way we hope to see you at the show!

Perks

  • Tickets! (Producer will contact Supporters for reservations)
  • Recognition!
  • Signed books!

As you can see to the right, all support levels come with tickets to a performance (which may be divided among more than one performance). Our goal is for you to be a part of the experience with us. For our out of town supporters, we are exploring live web streaming of each talkback and process group, and for those local to Los Angeles, we look forward to having you participate in the discussions. We will show our appreciation of each person's support with recognition in our lobby and program, as this show certainly will not reach its full potential without you!  (If you are an out-of-towner, so don't need tickets, but would like to support, you may choose the $1 support option, and then enter any amount you'd like to give!)

This is a production to support the creative community of Los Angeles, while at the same time highlighting and processing Holocaust-specific experiences and recognizing the lingering effects of the trauma. The aim is to connect survivors and their descendants with each other and with those who are not directly linked to the history -- allowing all to participate in a dialogue that keeps the memory of the Holocaust alive. As we are quickly approaching a time when first generation survivors will no longer be with us, we honor their memory, their struggle and persistence, that allows us to be here today.

Thank you for your support of The Diary of Anne Frank at The Cupcake Theater!

Best,

Caity Engler, Producer

Sigi Gradwohl, Exec Producer; "Anne Frank"

Sabrina Lloyd, Director


CAST:

Sigi Gradwohl ~ Anne Frank

Frank Krueger ~ Otto Frank

Maria Mastroyannis ~ Edith Frank

Becca Leigh Gellman ~ Margot Frank

Neil Miller ~ Mr. Van Daan

Sabrina Hill ~ Mrs. Van Daan

Max Lichtig ~ Peter Van Daan

Robert Paterno ~ Mr. Dussel

Alejandra Bursik-Cervantes ~ Miep

Terry Tocantins ~ Mr. Kraler

Brynn Sillyman ~ Foley
